Europe was not built and there was a war. There was a war and Europe was built. Let us not deconstruct it, let us not fall back into the mistakes of the past, in nationalism and in populism. We have talked a lot about external risks, but the real risks to the European Union are inside, as in 1939: they are old nationalism and old populism.  The European Union is the only vaccine available to us, I repeat. Let's not weaken her.  Europe needs the UK. But understand me well, England, Wales, Scotland, Northern Ireland, together or separately, need the European Union much more, because outside the European Union it is very cold.  And let me say one thing to finish: the referendum will be held. The British will decide whether or not they follow, but I tell them one thing, and we must all repeat it: "Europe, whatever the British do, it will go on." Like this afternoon, we're talking about the UK without Englishmen in the room. It's a good metaphor.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: – Mr President, the settlement that has been negotiated and unanimously agreed by all 28 Member States is, I think, a fair and balanced deal. All the institutions should be proud that the EU has been able to deliver in a timely manner. The settlement recognises that the UK can continue to benefit from the single market without being bound to the principle of ever closer union and to further political integration, while this principle remains fully valid for the others. The settlement guarantees against the pound suffering discrimination and, at the same time, is fully in line with the Treaties and with the need to preserve a level playing field across the single market and within the single rule book. Furthermore, the settlement recognises, at the same time, the need for further euro area integration. For these reasons, if British citizens decide to stay, we will examine the Commission proposal with the highest respect. We will respect the agreement and we will not prevent or delay its implementation. Legally speaking, of course, Parliament can only formally speak in an appropriate procedure on the basis of the Commission proposal but, politically speaking, I think that this debate clearly shows that the settlement commands a broad majority in this House. So we will be fair. We will keep our word. Now it is time for British citizens to safeguard their prosperity and their future.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the EU leaders for their tolerance for yet more British demands. They recognise the importance of a deal for Mr Cameron, but mostly for his own party. Now the battle begins: the referendum is under way, but it is not yet safely won. We have been fed lies and scare stories over 20 years from a largely foreign-owned media and comical characters such as Mr Farage. The stakes could not be higher. People I speak to want to know their future will be prosperous, stable and secure. Staying in Europe is the best way to guarantee that. Businesses know that access to the world’s largest single market far outweighs any free trade deals, but the work of the EU is so much more – it is migration, climate change, terrorists – all these. We must work together on these issues. Those calling for EU exit are like lemmings running to the cliff’s edge, but they cannot tell us what is on the other side. That is not patriotic; it is idiotic. Let us remain in, together, with a Britain to be proud of to hand on to our future generations.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: – We can organise summit after summit on the refugee crisis. With Turkey, without Turkey. With Greece, without Greece. With Austria, with the Balkans and again without Greece. But we will not be able to control the asylum crisis, the refugee crisis if we refuse to talk about the fact that a million people came here last year and that we can expect it again in the coming year. When we talk about closing borders, the external borders and internal borders, we are looking away. That is what the Ministers of Justice and Home Affairs will do again tomorrow when they discuss the possibility of using a new article in the Schengen Convention to impose border controls for a little longer. Mr Tusk, leadership is recognising that we must give refugees a place and not shift this problem to Greece or Turkey. [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE), blue card question. I listened carefully to what you said, Mrs Sargentini. For you, the refugee problem is due to the summits to which you referred, or to the fact that there is no will for all Member States to agree to the relocation decisions, but also for the European Union to pursue a more pressing policy in Turkey in order to comply with what it has signed for the readmission of economic migrants?

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: "blue card" answer. I insist that we are talking about a refugee crisis and not a migrant crisis. Almost all of the people arriving in Europe are granted asylum status. Furthermore, I think you are right that there is a problem with political will and Member States that do not bear their share. But the suggestion that we can take a little harder on Turkey is nonsense. Because let us be honest, that EUR 3 billion has not yet been transferred. In fact, we do not want to open any new chapters for Turkey. Because we don't really want the country to become a member at all. We do not really want to offer visa-free travel at all, and we want the Turks to keep those two and a half million refugees there. We have no negotiating position, ma'am.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this debate has not convinced me that there is anything wrong with the British people being able to decide whether to stay or leave Europe, and all these advantages do not seem to me to be seen. The Council has not decided anything significant about immigration, it has given Turkey three billion without imposing constraints, controls. But there is one issue that I would like to bring to the attention of President Tusk here and also of you, Mr President, and above all of the Commission. There is a European citizen who was killed after being barbarically tortured: he is an Italian, a young man of twenty-eight years, Giulio Regeni. And Europe, which deals with human rights on all sides, does not dare to make its voice heard. It's a disgrace! We want to know from Egypt how things have gone, when they will tell the truth requested several times, especially, of course, by the Italian Government. The voice of Europe and Of High Commissioner Mogherini is absent. It's a disgrace!

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Mr President, the recent European Council has shown that the construction of the European Union has no future in its present form. At some point, soon, developments will run much faster than this dysfunctional organism can react.  Britain requires special status if and when it remains in the Union, because in this way it safeguards the interests of its citizens and its national sovereignty. But other countries should also be entitled to achieve the same. Of course the Member States, but also the Union itself, easily succumbed to the demands of the United Kingdom, but not long ago they strangled Greece by forcing its people into poverty. But this is neither equal treatment, nor European solidarity, nor any other of the lies on which this Union has been built.  With regard to the other Council conclusions, as much as you are pleased with NATO's arrival in the Aegean, be aware that the Greek people regard this move as a betrayal, both on the part of the government and on behalf of our so-called allies, who caress Turkey, a donor state of terrorists that has no place in Europe.  Make as many plans as you want to co-manage the Aegean Sea, to turn Greece into a warehouse for illegal immigrants, the Greeks will very soon give the proper answer to your plans.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, Mr President of the European Council, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work I would like to thank President Tusk and Mr Juncker for the good cooperation they offered and implemented to the European Parliament during the summit. I believe that we have not sold the European soul and the interests of Europe in the negotiations, and that Britain has got what it needs for a successful referendum. We have also committed ourselves to complying with the rules of legislative independence, but that we are politically committed to carrying the project to a constructive end together. I believe that this is important and that the atmosphere of the negotiations has made this clear. I believe that this deal is also legally tenable, and we will also have to see this in the legislation according to the fact that we are carrying out legislation that is legally tenable. On this basis, we can also fulfil what David Cameron said at the end of the negotiations: in this changing world, Britain, too, has no chance of any influence unless it is together with Europe – in the fight against terror and much more. If we see these days that the Americans and the Russians are doing a deal without us, then that should finally make us aware that the nation states can no longer look into our interests alone. We can do it together, or we will all not be able to do it. That is why this is a way of regaining sovereignty for our peoples – over Europe. I hope that this deal will also reinforce the recognition among the British people who have to decide. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: blue-card question. – Mr Brok, I believe that the deal, which lacks recognition of the moral right of non-eurozone countries to stay outside the failed experiment of the euro, is lacking something. Would you agree that a deal in due course needs to be completed on that?

name: Elmar BROK
text: blue-card answer. – The Treaty of Lisbon clearly says that 26 countries have obligations and commitments to the euro. Nineteen have fulfilled them, seven are on their way to doing so – and we have made this differentiation that they have to do that – and only two countries have opt-outs and opt-ins. We have kept the stability of the development of the euro; it is agreed that the eurozone can be deepened, and it is agreed that everyone here has the same right and a level playing field. But it was also agreed that these seven countries will have all the advantages of future member countries of the eurozone. We have also said that there is no multi-currency union; the euro is the currency of the European Union. That is the result, and it is accepted.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, you spoke about investing in Schengen, and I think this is a very good idea, because the current fragmentation of the Schengen area requires very urgent action and we need to build up a real European border. But what is a real European border? I think it should not be a wire wall, just building a kind of fortress Europe. A real European border with a 21st-century concept should rather be an infrastructure able to organise and develop the relationship between Europe and its neighbouring partners in such a way that a real European border should be an advanced infrastructure with logistics and intelligence and able to provide basic safety for European citizens, also to manage flows and provide assistance to refugees with decent standards. So I believe this is a big investment for the future, and I think this kind of investment should be decided quite soon.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to welcome some constituents who are here from the South-East of England. I hope you have enjoyed the debate. Well that was a successful negotiation. David Cameron got precisely 1% of what he asked for, and only if there is Treaty change. I represented the ENF in the Conference of Presidents last week along with Mr Brok, but our arrogant Prime Minister decided he only wanted to meet half the MEPs and the EU leaders represented there, despite us actually representing hundreds of MEPs. That meeting told me what the British people need to know. There will be no Treaty change; there will be no taking back control of our borders. There will be no restriction on the free movement of people; the so-called in-work benefits brake can be challenged by the EU courts; and the only vote on the deal by the MEPs in this Chamber is only indicative and not legally binding. So, Mr Brok, the Prime Minister’s deal is not worth the paper it is written on, and that was told to him by his Justice Secretary, Michael Gove, today. The EU courts and the EU politicians can rip it up straight after the referendum, and the only way to get real change is to vote leave.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – I welcome the European Union's agreement with the United Kingdom as an expression of the common will of the 28 countries to continue working together, on terms that are acceptable to both the United Kingdom and the remaining 27 Member States and make sense.  Of course, we must be aware that the agreement also implies the need to negotiate changes to legislation, which will be discussed here in the European Parliament. I think that the limit is common values and treaties that will not be changed, and this condition has been respected.  I respect politicians who are capable of resisting populism, and I am glad that there are also MEMBERS from the UK who have joined the campaign to keep Britain in the EU, as Mr Fox of the ECR has said. In contrast, there is strong populism, e.g. from Mr Farage, who misinterpreted the czech Prime Minister's comments, which highlighted the possible wave of disintegration that a British referendum may have, but of course the Czech Government does not plan such a referendum. However, of course, there is this risk if the referendum does not go positively.  I personally appreciate the great work of President Donald Tusk and I want him to work with the same activity, with the same energy, to tackle the migration crisis.  (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mr President, dear colleague, I too agree that Britain must remain in the European Union, and I understand that you too. I would like to ask you the following question: do you think that, after the concessions made in the limited term by the Council of Great Britain – and hopefully the answer will be yes – the purpose and meaning of the existence of the European Union, namely the single market, equal rights and free movement, can be respected?

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – I believe that the agreement is within the limits of maintaining the common market and the values you have mentioned. Of course, it is certain that we will be discussing legislative measures here, but those principles of the common single market should not be undermined.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is good that we have a basis for the referendum in the United Kingdom, and it is up to the British people to make the right decision, and I am convinced that it will make it. Unfortunately, other important decisions have been postponed: this is the refugee issue that is really very much of a concern for us at the moment, and it is a pity that this can only be decided at the summit on 5 March. This is the last chance we have, and we finally need support for capacity in the countries of origin, more money structures, real money, more security at borders. We cannot produce this by making an excessive expansion of internal borders, but we need the support of Greece – not only because of security standards – but we also need human rights in this context, and finally we must finally achieve this much-vaunted European solution. A survey by the Bertelsmann Foundation has shown us that citizens expect this. It is time for Europe, not for national solo actions.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the president for his excellent work and for the work she has said. Both issues – the refugee issue and the question of the REFERENDUM in the United Kingdom – have something in common, namely that there are too many politicians who show a lack of seriousness, a lack of sincerity that plays with people's concerns and fears, rather than standing out with the solution. Both issues have in common that there are people from our political camps who live out domestic, internal problems and conflicts, national egoisms, personal attempts at profiling at the expense of European solidarity and the European project. I urge you all to stop this game! It is too serious, on the refugee issue as well as on the question of the United Kingdom! It is about the unification of Europe, it is about this Community. It is not a question of renationalisation and of living out one's own selfishness and attempts at profiling. It must be said very clearly that it is unacceptable that the breach of the law of one is justified by the breaking of the law of the other. It is unacceptable that the fences of one should be justified by the fences of the other. European and international law, our values and decisions are sufficient to bring into these problems a movement of solution and more credibility instead of chaos. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: the blue card. – Mr Karas, it seems to me that you have actually said a lot, but many of us here are convinced that the United Kingdom should stay, and I believe that common sense should be defeated. But nothing is better when we are ready for this right away. Does it not seem to you that the European Commission should start preparing a certain plan of measures that the United Kingdom will face if they actually leave the European Union. We need to talk about the need to establish a future London City, as we once set up rating agencies for ourselves in the European Union, we need to start talking about changes in trade agreements, that if they use our infrastructure, then how Norway will have to pay some contributions to our budget. Everything needs to be said to the British people who they will face if they make such a decision. What do you think?

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. In view of the negotiations of the last few days, I would also like to thank Mr Brok, Gualtieri and Verhofstadt from this Parliament, who helped to reach an agreement. This guaranteed that, together with the Commission, the common European whole would not be sacrificed on the altar of national interests. And that is why I assume that the citizens – Manfred Weber has quoted them – want to strengthen the community and not go out. If the UK says no, there is a process anyway. The vote is not on the agreement, but on 'no' or 'yes'. In general, however, I would like to say that any referendum initiated by governments is an escape from responsibility and a weakening of parliamentary democracy. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, Mr Karas, I must confess that I am being violent to consider that the agreement agreed this weekend between our Heads of State and Government and Mr Cameron is a success, because this theatre gives a terrible image of political impotence, as if Europe were affected by a lack of leadership, a lack of vision , a lack of will, and this image is not conducive to the British people's accession to a European project. Is there not, then, an image of national selfishness that adds up without a real perspective? Dear colleges, I must tell you that I am not satisfied with this agreement, because it opens the door to all demands and negotiations. For four months, we will not be able to make any decisions because the referendum did not take place.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – Again, the two issues have in common: there are decisions, and the problem is that there is a lack of seriousness in the way the decisions are handled. That is because of the people who take these decisions. You have to take yourself seriously. For those who do not take themselves seriously are not taken seriously. This applies to the refugee issue as well as to the agreement with the United Kingdom, and I say that it is not the agreement that is under discussion, but the 'yes' or 'no' to the European Union. I call on politicians to be more serious, including in the implementation of their decisions. We have the problems in the Member States because there is a lack of sincerity with regard to the decisions and because one is being played off against the other. Stand by what you have said and promised! Then we would all be better off.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: It is in everyone's interest for the United Kingdom to remain part of the European Union. Still, reading the text of the agreement leaves a lot of bitterness in you. Primarily because of the curtailment of social benefits, which is clearly discriminatory. The taste of our mouths is bitter because we know that the outrageous campaign against eastern European workers was launched by Mr Farage and his far-right comrades. The taste of our mouths is bitter because we know that Poles, Hungarians and others do not go to work in the UK because of social benefits, but because they do not have a job at home. No social benefit can compensate these people for not stroking their children's heads at night. The taste of our mouths is bitter, because once again we make those who are most needy pay the price for a conflict. The curtailment of social benefits mainly affects the working poor. Today, however, this seems to be the Europe we live in. When conflicts pop up, the first thing that comes to mind is to cut some of the social spending. It didn't happen any differently this time. There are already Member States considering whether they should follow suit. I am fighting for a Europe that is not united by the abolition of social benefits.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: "Mr. President, we have built a European Union to prevent conflicts, to live in peace, and not to be left with populizms. Those who created this Union were brave enough to make both the Schengen zone and the eurozone and unite Europe. It's up to us to preserve that. Earlier, our President Weber said well that when we were at war in Libya, Ukraine, Syria, we were prioritizing this British issue. Unfortunately, we deal with this as a priority, but we rightly question whether this is the right priority in the crisis we live in in Europe, with the number of unemployed we have in the European Union. However, we have to deal with it and we are ready for it. Mr Juncker said recently: "Either we will be brave, or everything will collapse." I believe that we should be brave and that the EU must not collapse and I believe in the British people who will make a decision in June this year. I believe that it will be prudent enough and that the answer will be positive, that it will remain in the European Union, because this is the only solution for both the Union and the United Kingdom. However, you have told Mr Tusk and I thank you, that we are in one of the most dangerous phases since the emergence of the European Union. I would say that's true, but we are also in a terrible humanitarian migrant crisis, perhaps the worst since World War II, and that is why I look with optimism at 7 March when you have a summit with Turkey and I expect results and, finally, implementation so that we do not have the same discussions anymore.  (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the EEA). Rules of Procedure))

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Before asking you whether you accept a blue card from Mr Jakovčić, I have to announce that we will ask our colleague Ms Guillaume to take the floor and then we will listen to President Tusk because he has to leave. We will then continue our discussion. So this is the scenario.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question by raising the blue card. – Mrs. Šuica, I have listened carefully to you and I know that you are in for Britain to remain in the European Union, as I am for it.  However, it will not be up to you, not me, not this Parliament, but the British people. So if the British people decide that they do not want to be within the European Union, do you agree with me that this is then a definite exit of the United Kingdom from the European Union and that no more negotiations must take place, because one day this situation must come to an end.  So, in that case, the United Kingdom will also have to renegotiate eventual entry into the European Union.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. Jakovcic, I agree with you that this is the final deal that has been reached, because we cannot say that this is a success. These were concessions that the European Council reached by majority or consensus, and I believe that no new negotiations should be given, that is, if they want to re-enter. This is also the final position of our club.  So the answer is positive.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Mr President, whether it is Brexit or migrants, the underlying question is often the same: is the Union able to remain united in diversity, or rather here in adversity? On the "migration" part of this Council, we are struck by the lack of progress. What was decided? Absolutely nothing! What was done that night was to endorse what was supposed to be already in place, even if the efficiency on the ground is not always there. Reception and registration centres are finally being established, but relocations from Italy and Greece are being made on a drip. Worse still, the search for common solutions is hampered by unilateral decisions across Europe: the setting of quotas for asylum seekers for some, the re-establishment of internal border controls for others. The Europe of cooperation seems to be facing a Europe of isolation.  This isolation is first and foremost that of Greece, because the cascading failures along the Western Balkans route have already had their effects. UNHCR talks about chaos at border crossings. The Commission and the Presidency of the Council are also talking about a possible humanitarian crisis.  So the question is: why multiply European summits when major decisions are missing? It is dangerous to use migration issues as an instrument of political communication. Unfortunately, this Council has not escaped the rule.

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, thank you for your understanding. I will make just two remarks. The two issues we are discussing today – the UK settlement and migration – are strictly interconnected. I have absolutely no doubt that how we challenge the migration crisis will be of key significance for the referendum campaign.  All those who want to keep the unity of the European Union – the unity of the whole of the West – and who feel that we have found ourselves in an epic moment should fight for a common plan with the fullest determination possible. What I mean by a common plan is an effective implementation of our decisions, full respect of the Schengen code and common action with Turkey. If this emerging unity of action on the migration crisis is violated by anyone, they may in fact contribute to the UK leaving the EU. As I have already said, the UK settlement will enter into force only if the British people vote to stay. If they vote to leave, the settlement will cease to exist. No one should have any illusions in this case: it was not one of many rounds of negotiations on the UK settlement in the EU; it was the first round and the last. There will be no more.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: PPE). Mr President, it is difficult to disagree with Mr Juncker and Mr Tusk's positions on a fair deal with the European states and the United Kingdom. If it comes out of the referendum, there's no other negotiation. The United Kingdom, Great Britain as we have called it for a long time, Winston Churchill's 1947 speech in Zurich, which first spoke of the United States of Europe, the will of the peoples of Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland raises a question: this referendum puts at risk the United Kingdom, Great Britain, becoming little England , marginalised in Europe and the world? Migration: we are investing in strengthening Schengen, we are investing in protecting European borders and not closing European borders. Turkey is part of the problem, but also part of the solution. It equates migration with its accession path, leaves illegal traffickers unchecked, accepts all citizens of north African countries without a visa, does not implement the Readmission Protocol, does not accept any of the illegal refugees back.  Together with responsibility and seriousness we must find solutions. I am sure that Europe wants and can and is able to achieve this.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have witnessed yet another European Council that ends in nothing and with the ritual update to next month on immigration, a test of the Union's crisis. But do we really believe that, in order to cope with the migration crisis, the European Union's objective must be to contain flows, protect external borders and reduce irregular migration? Is this the European Council's much-vaunted global approach? And what about a long-term policy to manage migration, to guarantee safe legal access routes, to create channels of legal immigration, and to integrate migrants into the political, economic and social fabric of our country? The European Parliament's draft report on migration provides concrete answers to these questions. For us, this is the global approach to migration, with more solidarity and a fair distribution of responsibilities. Mr President, in the absence of a forward-looking vision on the part of Europe, we will be the victims of an unprecedented political failure, as well as deprived of the European Union's main achievement: the free movement of persons.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Madam President, I think it is striking that, in the discussions we have had this afternoon, very few of the points put forward by the ‘antis’ are discussing the problems we are facing. This is not only about the European Union and how we would like the European Union to develop. This is about Europe and its stability, security and prosperity and its challenges – Putin, Russia and Ukraine and provocations against a number of European Member States. Of course, we know that a lot of those who are ‘anti’ would be happy to give in to Putin: they have voted that way here. We have the need for economic recovery and prosperity, but of course a lot of those on that side do not want open markets. But if we look upon the problems regarding stability – Putin, the fall of states in the Middle East and Northern Africa, the refugee crisis and climate policies – I do not think anyone can see how we can solve these problems or deal with these problems without being unified. Those who would like to see fragmentation would only honour the hopes of the Putins, the Le Pens and the extremists in the Middle East and in Europe. We must defeat them, and the United Kingdom must understand how important the United Kingdom is in Europe. (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Thank you for what you said about the threat Russia poses to Europe, especially to the part where our countries are located. But do you not see that it is not really the people who want to discuss the European Union, its state and the crisis that are to blame for selfishness, but the governments and the great interest groups that tolerate projects such as Nord Stream 2 that undermine the interests of your country and my country? Therefore, let us not blame nations and public opinion, let us work together to mobilise governments to give up (...). (The President has received the speaker's vote)

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: blue-card answer. – I must say, I am quite convinced that the people of Europe give priority to the stability and security of our part of the world. They want peace and they see the threats. They want us to have a responsible energy policy, climate policy and environmental policy, and it is up to us to ensure that we can deal with that and show the way. It is interesting that no one in this Chamber has said this afternoon that we can solve these problems better by going alone, because when you are alone you are alone in a world that needs unity.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: – Madam President, we have spent a lot of time trying to prevent the UK from exiting the European Union, and I think we have done well, which we do well in trying to avoid Brexit. But I am surprised at the short time and the few energies we have devoted to trying to avoid what I would call Eurexit, that is, the departure of the governments of the European Union from the defence of the values and principles that animate us. It's the refugee crisis. The refugee crisis represents the real crisis of what Europe is right now, what Europe has intended to do and what it is achieving. A crisis that calls into question everything we have fought for and which we have defended. So, while we have worked to avoid Brexit, we have forgotten to avoid eurexit, the demise of the principles of solidarity and justice that the European Union has represented so far. No more.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Madam President, I must say that the outcome of this Council on the question of the United Kingdom and the agreement reached is frankly satisfactory. I believe that it manages to maintain the core values of the European Union and, in some way, to meet those which were the perplexities that were put by the United Kingdom Government and the people of the United Kingdom, and therefore we have a meeting of positions, which is balanced, which is balanced and acceptable. What seems decisive to me on this issue is that the European Union – which must of course not interfere in any way in the sovereign will of the British people, who will decide freely whether to remain or leave the European Union – will make it very clear that if the option is for exit, this has consequences – and irreversible consequences. It is essential that British voters and that, deep down, all European citizens understand that there are advantages and disadvantages – there are, in essence, good things and bad things – in being within the European Union, there are duties and there are rights. And it is therefore essential, from my point of view, that it should be made clear that there is no second negotiation and, more than that, what are the consequences of leaving a State of the European Union. This is key. With this, I believe that the decisions of the British people, like those of other peoples of Europe, if they wish to do so, will be free and sovereign.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: For the following catch-the-eye procedure, As it stands now, I have about 14 messages. I think I'll be able to take about ten. I'll look at that from the time. If you all stick to the one minute of speaking time, I will find it easier to take more. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, the Council meeting discussed migration, and yet most of our debate here is talking about the UK referendum. So I want to begin by addressing this migration question, because it is linked to what is happening in terms of the UK and the potential outcome of that vote. I think that the European Union has been found wanting. If you look at the neighbouring countries like Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan, who have taken a great deal of people and to whom promises have been made in terms of funding from the European Union, but who have yet to receive that money, I think that issue needs much more attention and much deeper focus, because citizens’ concerns on that issue are feeding into negativity around the European Union. On the UK issue, I have already spoken in raising a question. We must not interfere, but we do – and have space, I think, to – give our opinions as a near neighbour in terms of a border with the United Kingdom. I am an Irish Member and we have Northern Ireland on our borders. We will have an interest in the outcome, and clearly our interest is maintaining the UK in the European Union.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in response to the migration crisis, the European Council welcomed NATO's decision to provide assistance in the reconnaissance, control and surveillance of illegal crossings in the Aegean Sea. Frontex must cooperate directly and closely with NATO. The full implementation of the EU-Turkey action plan is indeed a global strategic priority in order to stem migratory flows. We must sustainablely reduce the number of illegal entry into the European Union from Turkey through further and decisive efforts to ensure the effective implementation of the action plan. Further efforts are therefore needed to ensure this effectiveness, and the summit on 7 March will be decisive. On Brexit, I think that a possible exit from the European Union could be fatal for the stability of the European Union, but also for the UK economy itself. And even if the agreement reached is not what we wanted, it is therefore a good thing what the European Council has decided. We must make every effort to keep Britain in Europe, to change Europe. More Europe, to save Europe.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, Turkish slave traders continue to send thousands of refugees to Greece, Skopje, assisted by Austria, closes the border and Greece is in danger of becoming a vast refugee Dachau, while France, Germany, Denmark, Austria, Sweden and now Belgium have suspended Schengen.  The hypocrisy surrounding relocation continues, since of the sixty-six thousand four hundred refugees the European Union has pledged to take from Greece, not even four hundred have been relocated. As long as Greece remains in Schengen, it is a magnet for the thousands of refugees, since it grants them Schengen-style travel documents that allow them to travel to Germany. That's why refugees risk drowning in the Aegean Instead of going from Bulgaria to Germany.  The only solution is for Greece to withdraw from Schengen, close its borders and entrust the guarding of its maritime borders to the Greek navy and the Coast Guard. In addition, Greece should take advantage of the derogation clause in Article 72 of the Treaty and stop applying Dublin 3 for reasons of public policy and internal security.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, my party has been betting since the 1930s on the European project. That is why we must today express our concern about the content of an agreement that slows the consolidation of federal Europe, weakens the concept of European citizenship and insists on an opaque way of doing and negotiating. Fortunately, Parliament retains some capacity to improve a document which began to be written more to solve Mr Cameron's internal problems in Britain than those in Europe and Europeans.  Once again, Brussels has been used in a national debate as a scapegoat for problems that arise on its own soil. And from this European conviction, shared by other European nations without a state, I also note that it may be more correct to talk about Englandexit than Brexit, because there are British kingdoms that warn that they will fight to remain part of our Union if things get twisted. So we are going to open another debate on the right to decide of the stateless nations that we want to add up to in Europe, and I think we will soon agree that adding to the Europeanism of Scots, Welsh, Basques, Catalans or Flemish is a matter of democracy and fundamental and fully European rights.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we woke up this weekend with an agreement with the United Kingdom which says a lot about the Europe we are building. That two-speed Europe discussed at the beginning of the crisis is already a reality. The scope for action denied to southern countries is given to others under threats, with unequal treatment that is contrary to the principle of fairness that underlying this common project which is Europe. The conditions accepted by the Council advance in the worsening of inequality, and no longer only of income, but of citizenship status. In the United Kingdom, a hundred and eighty thousand Spanish citizens now reside who will become second-class European citizens who are people who work and contribute to the support of the state. We can only denounce the arbitrary nature of this agreement, which goes against Articles 45 and 46 of the Treaty on European Union. This agreement is a differential grievance for countries that receive austerity impositions without any possibility of negotiating.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – I quote from the document adopted at the summit: the relationship between the United Kingdom and the Union, sovereignty of the Member States. Member States acknowledge that the United Kingdom is not committed to greater political integration with the European Union. It will be incorporated into the Treaties when they are amended next, so that it is clear that the references to the closer possible unity between the peoples of Europe do not apply to the United Kingdom. This is a very important point and not just symbolic. In future legislation, all legislation that is moving towards closer integration does not apply to the UK. However, this raises the issue of discrimination, which is a European value. The treaties should give the same opportunity to other countries interested in looser cooperation. I trust that the Hungarian Government will make use of this opportunity as soon as possible.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, it is evident that far from being the far-sighted reform of the working of the EU that it was intended to be, or a diplomatic victory, the agreement reached at the European Council last weekend on the avoidance of Brexit is rather a deal to satisfy – and, I would add, exaggerate – the concerns of  a single Member State. Of course the concessions that proportionately affect the new Member States were worth making, and both the European Union and Britain are better off with the latter in the Union than outside. It is not European nation states by themselves that are able to address the economic, financial and security challenges of the globalised world, but a stronger, more united and more efficient Union. However, we should be extremely cautious that this settlement does not open the back door for special requests from other countries for their short-term or long-term existing or perceived problems.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, the Council's conclusions face a consummate fact, one of those occasions which shows that bad agreement may be better than a disagreement involving the uk's departure. But in this debate we are not here to prosecute Prime Minister Cameron's irresponsibility, because that is what the House of Commons is for, that is what his own divided party - the British Conservative Party - is for, of course, the British people in the referendum on 23 June.  But we are here to ensure that the Commission respects European law, in the decision-making procedure, in the implementation of those conclusions, if it succeeds. And, of course, to ensure that they do not violate the fundamental principle of free movement of persons – which is enshrined in European law – and that they do not make European citizens themselves immigrants in the United Kingdom, lower in rights than other citizens. And above all, to ensure that the Council's own conclusions on the refugee crisis are met, they are still clamorously violated by the non-compliance with these figures of a resettlement that never takes place.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. President, it was read from the statements that followed the meeting that both sides in the negotiations between the United Kingdom and the European Union were satisfied with the agreement. However, according to the reactions of most of the British public, it can be concluded that there are many dissatisfied, which means that even if the UK remains part of the European family, we must not give up further reforms of this community. The federal model that some European leaders and many members of this house are striving for is outdated and as such is completely unadjusted by modern times where there is a need for increasing decentralization of political power – both on European and national soil. Make no mistake, the UK's stay in the European Union will not silence the millions of Britons who seriously criticise the current state of this community, just as leaving out will not silence all the rest of us who seek and expect serious reforms.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, the fact that the Commission's policy was and is hypocritical on the refugee issue we knew. Now, with the last decision, with your own statements, you want to tell us that you are weak or even unable to implement a European solution to the refugee crisis. Where are the powerful, weak institutions of the European Union, which have imposed memoranda, which have imposed blackmailing austerity policies? Now it's other people's fault, or now you can't do it.  Your responsibilities: sixty-eight thousand refugees came to Greece in January, six thousand have been stranded at the border and it is envisaged that one million people will be trapped in this policy.  And what are you doing provocatively? You want to bring the Dublin Regulation back into operation. What else did you do? Unfortunately, with the agreement of the Greek Government, NATO has also been involved in militarizing the Aegean Sea, exacerbating the de facto refugee problem and putting Europe and my country in geopolitical upheavals. So say clearly that with what you do you want to load all the weight in Greece...  The President interrupts the speaker

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). Madam President, we make it clear that it is the implementation of the Council's dangerous decisions and not their violation that has led to the mass entrapment of thousands of desperate refugees in Greece. The Council adopted the recommendations of 12 February implementing Schengen providing for border controls, giving a green light to everything: closed borders, fences, refugee shelters, unseleging those with cheap labour standards for monopolies, confiscating any of their existing ones and deporting the rest. This is the capitalist barbarity that brings the imperialist war, the cause of the refugee crisis. And above all, with the agreement of the Greek government, the NATO "wolf" in the Aegean is questioning Greece's sovereign rights, encouraging Turkey's provocation. These are the European Union and NATO. In their bonds, the peoples are in constant danger. Therefore, a sustained popular fight against imperialist wars is needed, support for those uprooted in opposition to racist fascist forces and demand measures to directly transfer refugees to their final destination states.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE). Madam President, Vice-President Dombrovskis, joint action must be our guide. But what happens only in joint action does not highlight. What about compulsory relocation to the refugee camp? Is the Commission ready to activate a sanctions mechanism, i.e. cutting funds from agricultural subsidies and the Structural Funds for Member States that refuse to take refugees on their territory, or create obstacles, such as the referendum in Hungary? What about border guarding? Can NATO take action on the basis of what has been agreed, overcoming the objections raised by Turkey outside international law?  One must be our message: there are no regressions from what was originally agreed in NATO, nor are there any setbacks from the Member States.

name: Paul BRANNEN
text: – Madam President, I am sure I am not alone in being worried about the position that the Democratic Unionist Party have taken in Northern Ireland. They are apparently opposed to the United Kingdom staying in the European Union, but – as their name suggests – they are a Unionist party. However, if the United Kingdom leaves, this will trigger a further referendum in Scotland and, if Scotland leaves the United Kingdom, there will be no Union. There will be no Union Jack. There can be no Union Jack without the flag of St Andrew. So I would ask the Democratic Unionist Party to reconsider their position. How can they be a Unionist party and be working to destroy the Union? Please change your position.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Madam President, on a point of order, I signed up for catch-the-eye at the very beginning of this afternoon, and I wonder what the principle of selection was. The other thing is, what would happen in this Chamber if once, more than, say, 50 people out of the 750-something showed up, if those couple of dozen of us who appear have no chance at all of speaking?

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mrs Morvai, I would like to thank Mrs Morvai for her With the catch-the-eye procedures, we are trying to take as many as possible, but also have a certain relationship between larger and smaller groups. I have taken three speakers from the larger groups, two of them, including those who do not belong to any group – that is to say your colleagues – including those from Hungary, someone from your party, and someone else from the non-attached Members. I think that is understandable in this context. You were the third to speak for catch-the-eye from the non-attached Members. I took two others. I think I have evenly distributed this in this Chamber.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, on the subject of the UK negotiations, Heads of State and Governments agreed on a deal last week to accommodate the concerns of Prime Minister Cameron, and the decision is now in the hands of the British people. As President Juncker said, should the outcome of the referendum be positive, the Commission would immediately put legislative proposals on the table to the European Parliament and the Council to implement the deal. On the refugee crisis, the Commission is working day and night to handle the crisis and the flow of refugees. We believe that the solution can only be a European solution. Member States need to cooperate among themselves and implement agreements already reached so we can see the first positive signs with the better management of our external borders, hotspots, relocations and return policy, and the Commission is working to present further measures and bring further improvements to the situation in the very short term. Concerted action with our external partners is also of utmost importance, and the meeting with Turkey and EU leaders on 7 March will be key in this regard. We need to provide a coordinated response to the refugee crisis.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – We are in favour of the uk's stay in the Union, but we will be vigilant to ensure that this agreement respects European law and does not violate the fundamental principle of the free movement of persons. We are also concerned about the continuing crises of the Union. By force of successive crises of refugees, security, Brexit, we have forgotten that we have been living in a permanent crisis for a few years now of growth, employment, social rights and low wages. The OECD has published its weak growth prospects. Why is this happening in an exceptional monetary policy environment, in a favourable exchange rate environment, in a low-priced commodity environment? Because there is no expansive fiscal policy. That is why the OECD, not a conspiracy of Keynesians or a group of socialists, calls for more ambitious fiscal policies, greater investment in the short term and on the basis of the long term. Common sense and evidence require the Juncker plan to be implemented more determinedly and taking on greater risks. I do not conclude without referring to the issue of immigration: the solution is to implement the agreed commitments and ensure respect for European values.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This European Council was just another meeting of Europeanists who are trying by all means to save what can be saved from the EU. No solutions have been found regarding the problems in Syria or Libya except statements of good intentions.  The migrant crisis will continue and escalate even as EUROPEAN leaders refuse to face reality and the need to stop all eu-pending immigration, get out of Schengen and finally allow states to control their national borders. Finally, the conclusions welcome the agreement reached on the United Kingdom and its membership of the EU. Let us hope that British citizens will choose the path of "Brexit" and will not be fooled further by the great promises and negotiations of back-shops in Europe.  They have the opportunity to blow the wind of change and their vote could pave the way for the liberation of many European peoples from the Brussels diktat. We must put an end to this technocratic EU which imposes its treaties and laws on us, decided by unelected people, without democratic debate and whose consequences are more than terrible for the citizens.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. – This was yet another summit in which the lack of coordinated European action became apparent, and for the 10th time the problems persist and that action is urgently needed. I of course share the concerns, but I reiterate that all this is due to the lack of action by Member States, including frontline countries. Everyone insists on not realising that single and unilateral measures, which fuel national selfishness, make european solidarity increasingly difficult. Moreover, the lack of solidarity was also evident in the compromise reached with the United Kingdom. Without prejudice to recognising the importance of the United Kingdom as a member of the Union, it is not a good principle to deepen exception regimes which weaken the fundamental pillars of the Union. The European Union is an unfinished project with problems that we have to solve. However, we must do so together, and not just so that a Member State can say that the problems persist, but no longer affect it. Beyond the impact of the concrete solutions – or lack thereof – that resulted from this Council, it is the culture of commitment and trust between States, the pillar of the European project, which is most affected.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. – Investing in people, starting with the first school cycles, can and must contribute to reducing inequalities and strengthening social inclusion from an early age. I believe that it is beneficial for the EU to have forms of cooperation between governments, companies, including social enterprises, educational institutions, individualised services, civil society and social partners in order to adapt Member States' education and training systems to meet the needs of the labour market. Education can and must provide the most appropriate tools for citizens to access the labour market for all in Europe, which is why Europe needs a broader investment strategy covering the entire education and training cycle, covering all areas of lifelong learning, training and formal and non-formal learning in the workplace.  On the other hand, there is a need to expand forms of labour training, including adult and vocational training opportunities, with a focus on training people who have retired for a period of their professional activity to raise children, with the aim of better aligning education systems with the needs of the labour market.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. The conclusions of the European Council of 18 and 19 February specify the terms of the agreement between the European Union and the United Kingdom. An agreement reached after lengthy negotiations which has the merit of clarifying the "special status" of the United Kingdom and which forms the starting point for removing the possibility of its exit, in view of the referendum on 23 June. I am confident that this agreement, however painful it may be, such as the extension of the temporary freeze on unemployment benefits to migrants from other EU countries, will be the starting point for a decisive relaunch of the Union's integration process, on the basis of different speeds and prospects. Never before has the Union needed new and more effective governance that would allow shared and rapid decisions to be taken. I believe that we need a Union that is more supportive and, if necessary, even more 'close' if we are to break the political and identity deadlock that is driving citizens away from the European institutions every day. I hope that this agreement will help to improve the participation of one of its most important members in the European decision-making process: the United Kingdom.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. The EU's response to the migration crisis for the containment of flows, the protection of the external borders and the safeguarding of the integrity of the Schengen area has failed. The huge and unmanageable wave of people fleeing war continues to be a problem for the frontline countries, and especially Greece and Italy. The whole of the European Union and its declarations of intent have had little international impact on the real causes of the migration problem. Since its entry into the European Parliament, the M5S has insisted on proposals based not certainly on the interest and selfishness of a few, but on common sense and the interests of all, including the stop to arms sales, the political and financial isolation of terrorist organisations, the amendment of the Dublin Regulation, the compulsory and permanent relocation mechanism, legal access routes and the , returns for those who do not have the right to remain in Europe with full respect for fundamental rights. It is time, on the other hand, to passively suffer the negative consequences of a phenomenon that has persisted for years, that emerges what is still lacking: a clear, unified and unambiguous political will on the part of the Member States to really change things.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – The Conclusions of the European Council are well demonstrated by the scale of the crisis, the degree of disaggregation, the lack of values and lack of legitimacy that mark the process of European capitalist integration. The negotiations on the so-called 'Brexit' and the 'solution' found show that, in the face of the worsening crisis and the contradictions between powers that develop in this framework, EU leaders have no other answer than, on the one hand, to try to 'accommodate' in a bureaucratic encased the elements of disaggregation of the EU and, on the other hand, to deepen the reactionary character of their policies. The decisions now announced berest the eu's much-proposed and endeably 'freedoms'. "Freedom of movement and movement" is, after all, as we have always said, the freedom of great capital to develop its predatory and exploitative action. When it comes to meeting the interests of large financial capital, re-establishing contradictions between powers and saving their supranational mechanisms of political and economic dominance, EU treaties and legislation are likely to be amended and even subverted. This 'flexibility' now demonstrated in the 'Brexit' case contrasts with unacceptable rigidity and immobility in the face of the very serious social crisis and the pressures and blackmails that continue to be directed against countries such as Portugal.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – The last European Council focused its attention on negotiating the agreement to prevent exit from the United Kingdom. I think we have been right to invest time and effort to try to prevent Brexit. However, the lack of a similar commitment to prevent the refugee crisis from aggravating the humanitarian tragedy of millions of human beings and leading to the destruction of Schengen is unacceptable. How many summits of Heads of State and Government are needed for Member States to implement at national level the commitments made at European level? The Union must be based on the principle of solidarity when it comes not only to financial benefits but also to political responsibilities. In this regard, decisions agreed and voted on in the Council of Ministers of the Union should not become an 'a la carte menu' where only what benefits and the rest is ignored. As a result, I call on national ministers to urgently implement the proposals adopted in the field of the European institutions. Violation of commitments will only bring more death and destruction of the principles and values we claim to uphold.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. – We are in favour of the UNITED Kingdom's stay in the Union, but we will be vigilant to ensure that this agreement respects European law and does not violate the fundamental principle of the free movement of persons. We are concerned that the EU is living in a permanent crisis, for a few years now, of growth, employment, social rights and low wages. The OECD has published its weak growth prospects. Why is this happening in an exceptional monetary policy environment, in a favourable exchange rate environment, in a low-priced commodity environment? Because there is no expansive fiscal policy. That is why the OECD calls for more ambitious fiscal policies, greater investment in the short term and in the long run. Common sense and evidence require the Juncker plan to be implemented more determinedly and taking on greater risks. I do not conclude without mentioning the refugee crisis: the solution is to implement the agreed commitments and ensure respect for European human rights and values.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – On 18 and 19 February 2016, the European Council adopted a strategic programme setting out the long-term priorities for EU action and work. The main themes were the UK's status in the EU and the migration and refugee crisis. After hours of negotiations, EU leaders have reached an agreement that strengthens the UK's special status in the EU. The decision taken by the 28 heads of state is legally binding and irrevocable, as David Cameron has pointed out. Under the new arrangements, the UK will be permanently excluded from the process of progressive EU integration and immigrants from other Member States will be subject to restrictions on access to the social care system. Furthermore, the UK will never join the euro area and will remain outside the Schengen Agreement. In the context of the migration crisis, the European Council decided to protect the EU's external borders, reduce irregular migration and guarantee the integrity of the Schengen area. Nato's decision to assist in reconnaissance, monitoring and control of illegal border crossings in the Aegean Sea was also welcomed. Nevertheless, the full and rapid implementation of the EU-Turkey Action Plan remains a priority in halting migration flows and combating networks of traffickers and smugglers.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. The British have an incredible opportunity to be consulted by referendum on their country's membership of the European Union. Mr Cameron is also fortunate to have found people with his European counterparts and the Commission who are willing to help him try to curb the Euroscepticism of the right wing of his party and UKIP.  But what did Mr Cameron really get? Very little except the reaffirmation of the exceptions already enjoyed by the United Kingdom on migration policy or the single currency, which no one, for that matter, was thinking of questioning. And vague promises of some legislative changes, which will ultimately depend on the good will of the European Parliament. He will present himself before the voters with a lie, that of his alleged victory over the Brussels bureaucracy, and I hope with all my heart that they will not be fooled.  I would not allow myself to interfere in the campaign of the British referendum, but I believe that a vote in favour of Brexit would be a great opportunity to radically change this bureaucratic and disconnected Europe which the European peoples no longer want, and which has demonstrated in the face of all the crises, financial, debt, migration, agriculture... impotence, inefficiency and even its capacity for nuisance.

text: in writing. – We are in favour of the uk's stay in the Union, but we will be vigilant to ensure that this agreement respects European law and does not violate the fundamental principle of the free movement of persons. name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Writing. – An important element of the so-called 'new agreement with Britain' contained in the Council conclusions is the significant narrowing of access to British welfare systems for eastern European workers, despite all available studies and surveys confirming that those affected, who are younger and working at a higher rate than the UK average, contribute significantly more to british welfare systems than they take out of it. So there is no welfare parasite, in fact they are net contributors to the system. I think it is unacceptable that, in the direction of the least resistance, The British people are being paid to stay in, even if the Hungarian Government has assisted in this. But there's something else wrong. The majority of European decision-makers, including a significant number of MEPs, seem to believe that accepting the British demand for special treatment and exceptions is the price that we now have to pay to keep the EU together. It is much more likely that this is a major step towards disintegration and the disintegration of the Union. What's the message? The Member States can blackmail you, they will get what they have asked for, because the EU has neither the strength nor the will to resist.  And the Member States understand.  A deal with the British is a huge nail in the coffin of integration. The agreement is not part of the solution, but part of the problem.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. – External borders must be secured and defended. Member States must meet the requirements of the Schengen Code. Those who encounter problems must be supported, willingly or unwillingly, by European entities: Frontex, for example and, I hope very soon, the European Border Guard Corps. The Schengen area must be defended at all costs. Avoiding loss of life and reducing the flow of refugees cannot be achieved without stopping conflicts in the countries of origin and stopping people in the areas of departure. Turkey and the states of northern Africa need support. The amounts decided must bring concrete results. The resettlement procedure for the 160,000 refugees is very difficult to apply as it is based on the refugee option principle with regard to the host Member State. The European Agenda on Migration will not have the expected results, as long as the procedure does not provide for appropriate measures to ensure that Member States that initially took on refugees hold refugees in their responsibility. The review of the system for granting the right to asylum must be carried out in such a way that applicability in the territory is possible and immediate.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Writing. – The decisions taken by the European Council in difficult negotiations on Britain's concerns pave the way for the referendum there on 23 June to be held in favour of Europe. The compromises agreed were not easy. They are, however, justifiable. Because keeping the UK in the EU is extremely important. It is gratifying that the negotiation process in Brussels was characterised by the apparent will of the agreement. The conclusions of the European Council take into account the UK's reform concerns, such as the new arrangements for the UK within the EU, as well as specific provisions on the banking union and the further integration of the euro area. The new rules on child benefit to protect social systems, agreements to increase competitiveness, the strengthening of the role of national parliaments and the principle of subsidiarity have produced results that should benefit Europe in the future. It is now up to the UK to decide whether the country remains part of the European Union. We can all contribute by avoiding talking badly about Europe in the coming months. For the decisive factor in the vote will also be the image of Europe that the British public will have in the coming months when they look across the English Channel.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. National sovereignty is the ideal of the 19th century, an outdated concept in the 21st century. The Union's development trajectory of more than half a century is on its way to a federal state formation, the thresing of which, and the transfer of EU competences back to national level, is detrimental to Europe and hungary in it. If we do not want to sink into mediocrity, the only way forward for Europe is towards deeper political and economic integration. Separately, no Member State of the Union can compete with China or the USA. Let us not forget that Germany, europe's largest Member State, is only the fifth largest Chinese province by population. I believe that the European Union is not only an economic community, but also a community of values and destiny. I therefore reject initiatives that would dethrone European integration into a trade alliance. A decent worker who ases to national and EU legislation should not be discriminated against in respect of social benefits. I remain convinced that the ability of tens of millions of Hungary to averachn their interests is enhanced not by the strengthening of nation states, but, on the contrary, by the creation of a federal Europe of 500 million, the creation of a United States of Europe.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – The UK is one of the most relaxed countries in the EU. He is not in the Schengen system or in the euro zone, but terrorism and economic concerns have not gone past him. The recent UK-EU agreements formalised in the Council will ultimately give Prime Minister Cameron the reason for remaining in the EU in the referendum, but the impact of the EU-UK deal on British public opinion is rather limited. More importantly, the UK's explicit support for the UK remaining in the EU, as well as the general uncertainty about the future, will be more important. Because there can be no answers to how the UK can deal with security concerns, opportunities for growth and many other important things outside the EU. In addition, if supporters of leaving the EU remain, the uk itself could be threatened with disintegration if Scotland makes a new independence referendum quickly, and in this part of the UK, supporters of EU membership are outnumbered.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. – The Council's decisions explicitly and shamelessly clarify the essence of the EU's migration policy - the expulsion of refugees and migrants and the closure of external borders. For a humanitarian problem, a militaristic and militarized vision and solution advances. It is unacceptable for NATO to intervene closely with FRONTEX, the establishment of the so-called European Coast Guard and the demand that Turkey take further measures to prevent the crossing and stem the flow of migrants. Decisions that are deeply contrary to international law, which protects and confers rights on refugees and asylum seekers, and provides for a criminal maritime action from which thousands of victims could result. This is the eu's policy of 'solidarity' to respond to the so-called migration crisis, a humanitarian drama for hundreds of thousands of people fleeing hunger, misery, persecution, war. A storm that stems directly from eu interventionist action, in conjunction with the US and NATO, with their policies of military interference and aggression in various conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa. Neocolonial political criminals aimed at destabilizing the Arab world and geostrategic and economic control of those regions.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. – Last Friday was a sad day for Europe, for European construction, for those who dedicated their lives to the creation of the Union and believed in a strong Europe. On Friday, the heads of state and government decided to give in to British blackmail, accepted more sovereignty and less Europe. Although the Council says that the signed agreement is legally binding, there are many unknowns in the equation. An agreement signed by the Heads of State and Government cannot be binding and can only be applied by treaty amendments or secondary legislation. I'm afraid a dangerous precedent has been set. I will never accept that a worker from my country working in the UK should be treated as a second-class citizen. I will get involved when the Commission's proposals reach Parliament's table to ensure that fundamental rights are respected. I believe that this two-speed Europe that we continue to promote is not the Europe that Robert Schuman and Jaques Delors dreamed of, and if some have forgotten the main purpose for which the Union was created, it is worth reminding them that peace is more expensive than anything and that we are united.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: Writing. – The UK's withdrawal from the EU would not only be of use to either side, but also a sinister event in the context of crises that are devastating to the whole Community today. I am therefore pleased that a compromise agreement was reached at the European Council last week. EU leaders have shown that a common understanding of threats exists and that compromises are not feared in response. This European unity and the ability to communicate today is more necessary than ever, because the EU, as a global player, bears responsibility not only for the development of its members, but also for the development of the whole world. However, we must ensure that this agreement does not pave the course of a two-speed Europe. The UK's membership ensures a balanced "brake and counterbalance" system within the EU when it comes to the deep debate from the very beginning of European integration: the direction in which the EU must move in, in terms of deepening or enlargement. London brings enthusiasts of unconditional integration to reality, raising fundamental questions. Britain also plays the role of the transatlantic cooperation bridge, which is particularly important in today's threatened international environment. I would like to point out that the agreement reached and that mutually satisfactory agreement obliges the British leaders to convince eurosceptic sections of society that the alternative to secession from the EU will bring dangerous uncertainty not only to the Community but also to Britain itself.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. – The European Council Declaration on Competitiveness underlines the importance of a strong multilateral trading system based on respect for rules and the need to conclude ambitious bilateral trade and investment agreements with third countries in a spirit of mutual reprocessing and benefit. They also talk about trade for all, that Europe must boost its international competitiveness and that trade must benefit everyone without exception, consumers, workers and economic operators. This last consideration is totally hypocritical. You know that being competitive is about liberalizing policies. In agriculture they have already done so and we already see how Commissioner Hogan himself has just recognised the serious crisis in many sectors in the last Agriculture Council. In this same line of deregulation to boost competitiveness, you are trying to establish the Competitiveness Authority to intervene in the world of work and to accommodate wages to the demands of companies to regularize the current social dumping strategies already practiced today by many companies, including large textile chains. Within a few months of COP 21, they seem to have forgotten the impact these proposals will have on climate change.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. – Since its accession, Britain has been an important member of the EU. This country's further stay in the EU will benefit not only the EU, but also the UK itself. Since it is economically closely linked to the EU, I believe that maintaining the possibility of shaping European legislation and other benefits of membership outweigh counter-argument. So that the EU remains united and strong. In the context of the migration crisis, it is important that EU Member States ensure the functioning of the Schengen area, but at the same time that all actions are in line with international obligations in the area of refugee law. The stability of both Syria and Libya remains an EU security concern.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: in writing. – As a whole, the agreement negotiated with the United Kingdom can be a good agreement that gives it a chance to remain a Member State of the European Union. For Romania and other less economically developed Member States, this agreement contains some deeply unfair provisions. It is difficult to accept that, in the European Union, a Romanian citizen who will go to work in the United Kingdom should not enjoy the same financial rights for children remaining in Romania as a British citizen. In the case of Romanian citizens already working in the UK, this unfair decision will apply later. That is why I will vote for the agreement with the United Kingdom, but not for the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 883/2004, which would allow the United Kingdom to treat Romanian citizens working in the United Kingdom as second-tier citizens in matters of children's financial rights, no matter where they are located.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. – I understand the relief from the reports of the Presidents of the Commission and the EIT when it comes to decisions on the British question, but I do not share the satisfaction, especially the joy. This enforced set of decisions could curb, stop and destroy the entire European construction in important areas. Moreover, this demotivates pro-EU political and civic forces, and the (Orban's) destructives get bloodshot; this effect could also be had if the exceptions were not put in place because of the possible – unwanted – negative result of the British referendum. In contrast to the exceptions that ensure Britons are left out of an "ever closer" Union, there is a lack of community decision-making and influence.
