Even in the light of the communication issued, there is no indication of how the separation of The British people will be applied in the most important areas of deepening political union, such as the Eurogroup and Schengen, such as the E.P.A., as well as in social and labour matters. Failure to do so would seriously harm the interests of other Member States and the fundamental principles of how the EU works. As a socialist, I am particularly sorry that a right-wing British government, largely self-generated, is trying to solve its domestic problems at the expense of workers in other countries by bracketing social justice, solidarity and other European core values.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – At a recent summit, EU leaders reached an agreement on concessions to the UK to prevent the country from leaving the Community. Commenting on this situation, the European media paid the most attention to the issue of reducing social assistance for Europeans residing in the UK, but also in other Member States. It must be said that this is undoubtedly an important but not crucial issue for the future of the Union. A more serious problem is the risk of a 'three-speed' Union. There is a risk of dividing the Community into countries: (1) the euro area, 2) the United Kingdom and 3) the other Member States. These three "zones" will be m.in other integration rules and other member rights and obligations. This threatens to weaken and perhaps disintegrate the Union. Such risks may also be reinforced in the future by the fact that other Member States, especially those with high popularity with Eurosceptic parties, can now make their own demands, similar to those raised by the United Kingdom. I am therefore afraid that the European Union has weakened, not strengthened, in recent decisions, threatening its good future.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – The decisions of the last European Council represent further real proof of the deep crisis in which the EU finds itself. Both decisions on refugees and decisions in the face of the UK's demands demonstrate the political exhaustion that has been reached and the consequent lack of solutions to the existing problems. In the face of the plight of refugees fleeing war caused and fuelled by western powers and the European Union, the response continues to excel in repressive measures, treating refugees as criminals of common crime. The expressions of rejoicing, in the face of NATO's participation in patrolling operations off the Turkish coast, say everything about the point we have reached. As far as the united kingdom is in the case of compromises, it is yet another precedent which shows that, in this Europe, there is no equality between sovereign states. There are rich countries that want to protect their financial sector to whom everything is given away, while mercilessly falling on less-rich countries to zero tolerance.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. – Mr President, the agreement negotiated with great Britain is a balanced whole and provides solutions to the issues that the UNITED Kingdom has found problematic. On the other hand, it is important for the future and unity of the EU that you cannot obtain any privileges by threatening to leave the EU. However, all the other Member States would have national demands and promises to the electorate. In the interests of fairness, it is therefore important that other Member States should also be given the same opportunities for the new flexibilities that were promised to Great Britain. Britain must also accept that the agreement now negotiated will not be reopened – whatever the outcome of the British referendum. It is important for Europe that Britain continues to be a member of the EU. Britain is both economically, securityly and mentally important to the European Union. After all, it is one of the largest, most stable and prosperous Member States of the Union and, moreover, an important link between Europe and the United States. I believe that Great Britain will also benefit from membership and will continue to be able to take decisions on its own that will affect it anyway. The acute immigration crisis, for example, is also the issue that is best resolved together. So the EU needs the UK and the UK needs the EU.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on – the report by Maria Joo Rodrigues on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the European Semester for the Coordination of Economic Policy: Annual Growth Survey 2016 (2015/2285(INI)) (A8-0030/2016), – the report by Sofia Ribeiro on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: Employment and social aspects in the Annual Growth Survey 2016 (2015/2330(INI)) (A8-0031/2016) and – the report by Catherine Stihler on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection on Internal Market Governance in the context of the European Semester 2016 (2015/2256(INI)) (A8-0017/2016).

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, the report on the social and employment aspects of the European Semester aims to transform the European Union into a modern social Europe, given the potential and current challenges, and stresses the concrete measures that need to be implemented to balance the economic and social dimensions and to boost sustainable social development. It focuses on the fact that economic and financial systems are aimed at improving citizens' living conditions, and that is the main reason why we need to continue with the consolidation of these systems.  Presenting as an objective social development, which must be presented across all Union policies, it proposes monitoring of these policies and stresses that Member States and the European institutions need to ensure, in a responsible manner, the long-term stability of their political and budgetary choices in order to be able to continue towards sustainable growth. In this sense, this report focuses on the need to consolidate public finances and tax systems, given the fragile economic situation of many Member States, and reinforces the importance of this consolidation in order to ensure social stability, not only in the present day, but preparing the future of younger generations. As we have seen in recent years, Member States' resilience to the financial crisis is linked to the empowerment of their public finances, and the ones with the worst results are those with the most marketable economies and larger deficits. This financial consolidation must be accompanied by growth policies, which are translated into a set of structural reforms aimed at competitiveness and defending the social role of states in the face of the problems – also structural – that we are currently facing. The sustainability of social security and social security systems and pension schemes is perhaps the most paradigmatic example of this challenge, given the ageing trend of the European population predicted in the coming years. Education is also a fundamental pillar for development, and we are competing to ensure that education systems give young people the necessary skills, especially in new work areas, of which the digital, green and blue economy is an example. It is also an essential area to meet the needs of companies, which are the first engine of development. We believe that European policies should still enhance public and private investment at European level, but that investment must be targeted at projects that ensure economic and/or social return and should boost growth and can never be a mechanism for the mere use of public funds. Finally, I would like to highlight the entirely new approach proposed in this process, which is the unprecedented introduction of social indicators, including the activity rate, youth employment and long-term employment, in the analysis of the overall development of the Member States. If this report is adopted, Parliament will be giving the Commission and the Council a strong message that, alongside other existing indicators, such as those in the economic and financial field, we must have mechanisms to assess the extent to which our policies are having an impact on the daily lives of our fellow citizens. This will be a way of ensuring that internal imbalances in the Member States are further assessed so that we can redesign their economic and social reforms where necessary. This is a great step that allows us to strengthen the social pillar. In conclusion, Madam President, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs of the other political groups, who have been very committed to us in a joint effort to reach a common position.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, we are at an important moment for the European Semester because Parliament can deliver today three important reports which deal with a situation that is quite unique in the European Union. We are dealing with overlapping crises and, if you want to cope with these overlapping crises, it is certain that we need to strengthen the internal cohesion of the European Union. This will depend a lot on delivering a much stronger and more balanced recovery. I have the pleasure to present today the report adopted by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. I am very grateful to my colleagues, because I believe that it was possible to reach a very useful compromise with real added value for the situation in the European Union. The starting point of our report is to say that the European Semester should be used to pursue the rebalancing of our budgets and relevant reforms, but also to implement the Europe 2020 strategy for growth and jobs, because we believe that, in the end, the future of Europe will depend on this kind of competitiveness geared to the future, based on energy transition , digital solutions and bringing about more and better jobs. But if this is the case, the policy mix should be fully supported for this ambition. This means that in the policy mix to be implemented in the coming year, pushing for investment should be a top priority. This means making the best of the available tools, starting with the European investment plan, but also completing the banking union to make access to credit much easier for small and medium-sized enterprises. We do, of course, also need reforms, but we believe that we need a second generation of reforms pushing for education, innovation and good public administration and ensuring sustainable welfare systems. And, of course, we need to pursue the fiscal rebalancing of our budgets, but in such a way that we do not undermine this pro-growth move and the strategic investment we need to address. We should also take into account the fact that Europe is confronted with new challenges, security issues and, in particular, the refugee crisis. I believe that the most important value in our report is the way to manage the euro area, because we recognise that the euro area is an economic entity deserving an appropriate policy mix. That is why we recommend that the investment gap which is there in the euro area should be addressed by sharing the contributions from different countries, particularly those with more fiscal space. The same should happen when it comes to reducing macroeconomic imbalances because, on the one hand, we need more-competitive countries to expand internal demand and, on the other, we need less-competitive countries to increase their competitiveness – not by reducing wages and social conditions but rather by investing in the future. These are important conclusions. We believe that it is crucial to organise upward convergence in the eurozone, assuming that economic and social objectives should be treated in the same way. This can only be delivered if we complete economic and monetary union with a fiscal capacity and the banking union.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Council – in the person of our former colleague from Parliament – for being here with us on this important debate. The single market is a precious resource which the European Union’s current and future economic prosperity depends upon. The untapped potential of the single market, estimated at EUR 1 trillion in value, is both an opportunity and a wake-up call to ensuring the single market works to benefit us all. I think it is a great pity that we have continued to miss out on these advances for over 20 years, especially in the light of the ever-growing internationalisation and global competition that we face. The single market has great potential to boost jobs and growth, and this prospect has been widely acknowledged at an EU level. However, despite repeated calls to strengthen the single market in the Council and in annual growth surveys and country-specific recommendations, not enough progress has been achieved so far. In order to effectively deliver on jobs and growth and competitiveness, the progress of integration of the single market and Member States must be accompanied with better governance and greater transparency of the process. Including the single market under the European Semester could help us achieve this goal. Regular, structured compliance dialogue with Member States, proper involvement of the European Parliament, inclusive and non-discriminatory approaches to all EU Member States, euro and non-eurozone, Member States’ national parliaments and all stakeholders, is crucial for transparency, governance and ownership, and ultimately for the success of the process. I also believe it is the enforcement and implementation of already existing EU legislation by all 28 Member States that is key to unlocking the full potential of the single market: overcoming unnecessary non-tariff obstacles, proper implementation of the Services Directive, proper and timely transposition and implementation of public procurement and concessions legislation, modernising public administrations, providing more and better accessible digital services for citizens and businesses – and these are just a few examples where already-existing EU legislation is not yet properly implemented. They are stalling the development of the single market across the European Union. Change cannot and should not only come from the top. All players need to embrace a single market compliance culture and work in a cooperative partnership. Such multi-level ownership needs to be supported by adequate training, assistance and dedicated resources and accessible information at all levels. I have tried to address these features in my report, and overall I am pleased with the final text. I would like to thank the shadows for their contributions; although we did not always agree on everything, I think we managed to reach an agreement in the end. I would also note that it is my firm belief – and hopefully that of many of my colleagues – that one of the reasons we are here as Members of the European Parliament is to ensure that we pass and adopt transparent, appropriate and fair laws. Since the Treaty of Lisbon entered into force, Parliament has more say over what and how legislation is adopted at EU level, and we need to use this influence as the only democratically-elected EU institution to ensure we adopt better regulations and better regulatory principles. That is why on behalf of my Group, I am asking for a slight change of wording in paragraph 46, via an amendment. This is to ensure that the better regulation principle is duly referred to in this report, as better governance and greater transparency of the process equates to an enhanced functioning of the single market for consumers and businesses alike. I hope I can count on your support, colleagues, to support the amendment and the text as a whole, and I thank you for your cooperation.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Madam President, I welcome the Presidency of the Council and the Commissioner. I would like to stress the somewhat formal nature of our exercise, deplore the small parliamentary dimension of the European Semester and regret the lack of ambition of the report of the five presidents in this regard. Having said that, and I repeat Mrs Rodrigues' words, the European Union does not have an economic policy. Economic policy is an addition of national policies and coordination too often remains somewhat incantatory. That is why we believe it is necessary to strengthen the euro area, which can only expand when the countries that are not yet members will show the will. The euro area needs a budget that would allow us to combat asymmetric shocks and reward the reforms that are being made by the Member States.  I want to stress that the European Financial Stability Mechanism is in a way a mutualisation of the over-indebtedness of certain Euro area Member States and that what we want, thanks to this budget, is the policy mix: a synergy of fiscal and monetary policy.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, first of all, many thanks for the opportunity to discuss the European Semester. In times of crisis, when pressing issues abound, I am grateful to Parliament for dedicating time to the subject. Yes, it is a complex issue but one that deserves our full attention, for if we are to make Europe relevant to people’s daily lives, we need to achieve concrete results on growth and jobs. We need to create opportunities for young people, for the long-term unemployed, for small businesses. Yes, it is a long journey, for sure, but things are looking up. Europe is experiencing a recovery. Slowly but surely we are emerging from the crisis. So which priority should guide our actions at this juncture? Reading your reports on the European Semester, I was pleased to see that we share a common assessment of the challenges before us. Obviously, relaunching investments remains a vital condition to strengthen the still fragile recovery and, as stated by rapporteur Rodrigues, investments are crucial. So yes, the Commission’s investment plan is central to our efforts in this respect. The European Fund for Strategic Investment, on which the European Parliament and the Council have worked hand in hand, is in place, but more needs to be done. So let us continue to work together with the same sense of urgency to lift the remaining barriers and to foster a truly favourable investment climate. Clearly, sound responsible public finances are another essential part of our growth strategy, for the recovery can only be sustained if it is based on solid ground. This means making our tax systems more growth-friendly as well as developing modern social protection systems. We also need to embrace structural reforms to strengthen our economies, to ensure that our economies are resilient and fit for the future. Member States, especially those hardest hit by the crisis, have over the past few years undertaken ambitious reform agendas which are starting to bear fruit. However, as the pressure eases, the temptation to go back to ‘business as usual’ emerges. This is, obviously, understandable, but standing still in a fast-changing world is not an option. We have to move from rebalancing our economies and reforming our pension systems to ensuring that the younger generation have the skills they need for the future challenges. In other words, the reforms we carry out today will shape the competitive Europe of tomorrow. In our endeavours to promote long-term growth, we can rely on the EU’s most valuable asset: tapping the potential of the single market. This was also stated by Ms Stihler. You have underlined in your report a single market dimension of the European Semester, and I very much welcome this. As you know, deepening the single market is an issue dear to the Netherlands Presidency, and we have planned to report on the issue ahead of the European Council meeting in March. At the core of our approach lies the conviction that, in the midst of global uncertainty and the crisis that Europe is facing today, we need to lay the ground for tomorrow. It is about designing and implementing future-proof policies. How do we make sure that our policies withstand the test of time? First, we need to constantly review our work, for good recommendations are by no means a guarantee of success unless they are fully implemented. This is perhaps the single most important challenge of the European Semester: making sure that we actually deliver on reform. Member States’ responsibility is central here. The European Parliament has been active in pushing us to do better, and rightly so. As the Presidency, we believe that much can be done in the Council to provide the right peer pressure to undertake the necessary but sometimes painful reforms. More political discussions on the implementation of reforms and sharing best practices between ministers will help keep the momentum for reform ongoing. This is why, in the coming two weeks, in addition to the usual discussions on the Annual Growth Survey, we have scheduled specific debates in the Council on the implementation of country-specific recommendations in the run-up to the March European Council. But let me be clear at the same time: there is no quick fix to address the implementation gap, and deeper discussions within the Council will not be sufficient. We need to involve all stakeholders, national parliaments, social partners and, of course, the European Parliament. This is not just about democratic oversight; it is vital for the process to be effective, as ownership is the foundation of meaningful reforms, and today’s debate is important for that very reason. Progress has been made. Shorter, more focused recommendations do make it easier to concentrate our efforts on the key issues. The new timing of the Semester gives more time for work at expert level to exert a truly multilateral surveillance, and the early adoption of the euro area recommendation means that our discussions on national recommendations from now on will take into account euro area challenges. More attention is also being given to the social dimension of the Semester, and taken together these are meaningful changes, obviously. We will continue to strengthen our cooperation in order to reap the full benefits of the European Semester with just one goal in mind: delivering on a stronger Europe for all citizens.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, this morning the College of Commissioners held an orientation debate on the European semester, including country reports and developments in the macroeconomic imbalances procedure. We will publish the country reports on Friday, and decisions in the context of the Macroeconomic Imbalances Procedure will be taken in the next few weeks. The country reports follow the policy guidance provided by the 2016 Annual Growth Survey and the recommendation on the euro area last November. The 2016 European Semester is more streamlined than in the past: it integrates the euro area and national dimension and puts stronger emphasis on employment and social performance, convergence and support from the European structural investment funds and technical assistance to the implementation of reforms. This year we decided to streamline the Macroeconomic Imbalances Procedure, moving from six to four categories, namely: no imbalances; imbalances; excessive imbalances; and excessive imbalances within the corrective arm of the Macroeconomic Imbalances Procedure. To put country reports in a broader economic context: the EU economic recovery is still ongoing but risks have visibly increased over the past few months, with negative external developments starting to feed into European financial markets and confidence indicators. Unemployment has been falling, but it remains high in a number of countries, particularly unemployment among young people and long-term unemployment. The adjustment of macroeconomic imbalances has advanced but is far from complete. In particular, high levels of private and public debt still act as a drag on growth in many Member States. This situation must be seen as an incentive to redouble the efforts to implement policies that support growth and stability. In this respect we have many good examples of reforms in our Member States but also see that progress is uneven across Member States and different sectors. Further progress can be made with the close involvement of national parliaments, social partners and other stakeholders in the design and implementation of reforms. It is necessary to strengthen the effectiveness and ownership of reform efforts in the Member States. Publication of the country reports earlier than in the past serves this goal. It provides more time to engage in an in-depth dialogue with Member States and key stakeholders before the Commission publishes country-specific recommendations. The role of the European Parliament in the European Semester has evolved over time. Ways to strengthen it further are being explored in line with the Five Presidents’ Report on completing economic and monetary union and the communication of October 2015 on steps towards completing the EMU. I am convinced that it is of the utmost importance to have an exchange of governance milestones like the country reports, and I am very much looking forward to discussing these with you. The findings of the country reports, the outcome of the Commission’s analysis of our exchanges as well as the stability and convergence programmes and national reform programmes will pave the way for the 2016 country-specific recommendations, which the Commission will issue in May. Now to come specifically to the three reports we are discussing today, to start with the Stihler report. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Stihler, and welcome the contribution of the European Parliament on single market governance as part of 2016 European Semester. Structural reforms are needed to facilitate the reallocation of resources across companies, sectors and regions in order to increase productivity and competitiveness. It is necessary to go further in the process of reform, setting the foundations for a more competitive and resilient European economy. This can be achieved through reforms such as opening the product and services markets that would boost the EU internal market, and through structural reforms to eliminate barriers to the free circulation of goods and services. The Commission is working to reduce the high number of restrictions in product and services markets in many EU Member States. Improving the functioning of these markets is essential to renew the economic fabric of the EU and to ensure that EU companies adopt and successfully integrate into the increasingly global value chains. Now to move the Rodrigues report. I would like to thank Ms Rodrigues for this report and it concurs with the views of the Commission on a wide range of issues. The Commission welcomes the support for the 2016 Annual Growth Survey and for the priorities it identifies, as well as for the advanced timing and content of the recommendation of the euro area. The Commission shares the importance of making more effort at national level to implement structural reforms effectively. It also shares the need for close coordination to achieve more robust economic recovery, to support sound public finances and address macroeconomic imbalances. The emphasis on promoting convergence towards the best performers in the euro area is also at the core of the Commission’s work. Finally to the Ribeiro report: once again, thank you to the rapporteur. The European labour market is showing some positive signs. Unemployment is still high in many Member States, but it is gradually decreasing. Employment is growing in most sectors and for all age groups. More young people are back in jobs or taking part in education and training. Our efforts to fight against youth unemployment are beginning to bear fruit. We are also seeing the first signs of divergences among the Member States starting to decrease. Because of the crisis, more people have fallen into poverty, but also we see some first signs of progress. The promotion of better social standards and upward social convergence within the EU is a priority. The European Pillar of Social Rights will be an important vehicle to restore social convergence. The Commission is paying more attention to employment and social developments in the European Semester. First, the 2016 Annual Growth Survey package puts social fairness at the heart of economic recovery. Second, in line with a new start for a social dialogue, the involvement of social partners in the European Semester is strengthened throughout the consultations at EU and national level, and in addition, the new employment guidelines call on Member States to involve social partners in the design and implementation of the reforms. Third, the analysis of new employment indicators in the Macroeconomic Imbalances Procedure allows for a better understanding of the employment and social consequences of imbalances in some Member States. Several Member States have pursued reforms in the labour market and there are visibly positive effects, not least through increasing employment rates. However, these reforms should be continued, to stimulate growth and to create a positive environment for the creation of quality jobs. Once again Madam President, Madam Minister, honourable Members, thank you and I am looking forward to a productive debate.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. – In recent years, two objectives have consistently been on the agenda of this Parliament – economic growth and employment. None of these objectives would be achievable if we did not have healthy European citizens. We all know that the primary responsibility in this area rests with the Member States, but the European Semester can and should be used as a tool to achieve modern health systems that meet the expectations and needs of citizens. I therefore consider it essential that there be an assessment of the functioning of health systems within its framework. I call on the Commission to develop tools to monitor health outcomes and measure access to high-quality health services in order to reduce inequalities in this area. The European Union must reaffirm its commitment to the implementation of the 2020 Strategy. We must demonstrate to European citizens that we have a plan for the future of our continent. I therefore believe that the revision of the 2020 Strategy needs to be integrated very strongly into the European Semester. In the field of environment and health, there are great prospects for growth, investment and job preservation. The European Semester plays a key role in promoting the necessary structural reforms.

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. – In its opinion on the Annual Growth Survey, the Committee on Regional Development calls on the European Commission to better take into account the europe 2020 objectives by improving its implementation and carrying out further review, as well as by proposing measures and methodology to better monitor the expenditure of European Union funds related to the Europe 2020 objectives. In this context, the forthcoming revision of the multiannual financial framework makes it possible to analyse and increase the added value of European Union funding.  The REGI Commission points to the existing links between the objectives of the European Semester process and the programming of the ESI Funds and considers that cohesion policy investments can play a very important role in supporting structural reforms and the implementation of the European Union's strategic objectives by following up on relevant specific recommendations by Member State.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The Commission's Annual Growth Survey identifies three priorities: boosting investment, implementing structural reforms and responsible fiscal policies. From the point of view of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, this is a very clever, sensible triad, that is reasonable. I believe that we are doing ourselves no favours by abusing the European Semester – and I will make it clear – to invent new indicators every year that have little to do with competitiveness, little to do with good budgetary policy or structural reforms, but which have only one objective: to calculate bad figures. The economic environment is not improved by inventing new indicators. That is why we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats have been very reluctant to do so. Our aim is not to weaken the strong, but to strengthen the weak. In concrete terms, this means that if there are countries that have an export surplus, for example, then other Member States in the European Union will benefit in the same way, because we also have very intensive trade relations internally. It is not by trying to reduce this, but by enabling others to produce similarly good figures. The third thing that particularly moves us as the GROUP is that we are concentrating more on a few requirements for country-specific recommendations for the Member States, which will then actually be implemented. I would like to thank the rapporteur briefly for having addressed many of the points that we have dealt with, so that we can now vote on a balanced report.

name: Elisa FERREIRA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group- Madam President, Commissioner Dombrovskis, Council, welcome. I begin by thanking the whole team of colleagues who were rapporteurs and, in particular, Maria João Rodrigues, for ECON, this excellent report. The message that the report brings is very clear: it says that it is time to change Europe's economic agenda. Today, in the United States, the 2008 crisis belongs to the history manuals. In the European Union, however, we continue to 'skate' (excuse the plebeians) in an overly weak recovery and unemployment. Expectations today for German industry are unfortunately at the level of 2008-2009. Banking and insurance have started to show signs of tension again, because there are no good deals if there are no good profitable companies, and there are no profitable companies without domestic demand and without investment, no reason how low the interest rate. In the economy, you cannot just see supply, there has to be demand, and the economic policy that we have followed has extinguished that demand through excessive austerity. Today, any swing in the economy of the United States or China disturbs the Union.  Fiscal policy needs to be readjusted and symmetry introduced in the adjustment between deficit and surplus countries. We need to protect strategic investment – and it seems that there is consensus on that. And we must complete the banking union, or the European Union will lose control over its own destiny. Portugal is, in this respect, a good example that european rules can be complied with and a more stimulating policy of economic growth and employment can be taken on. But the Union and the Commission in particular, as well as the Council, need to be available to support alternatives such as these and also to change the dominant one that has existed so far in the general policy of monetary union itself. With so many problems threatening the Union, let us have the intelligence to solve the economic component, because it is in our hands. I hope that will happen.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The EU's economic situation remains marked by major imbalances, mass unemployment in southern Europe is persistent, and without low oil prices, the current growth figures would be hard to imagine. Entire countries and regions remain decoupled from the recovery. The European Semester aims to make country-specific recommendations on economic reforms on the one hand and to address macroeconomic imbalances on the other. The effort involved is considerable. The success – i.e. the transposition by the Member States into concrete policies – is rather low, at around 25% in 2014. Implementation is voluntary and should remain so in the spirit of subsidiarity. This is not a problem in the non-euro countries. With their own prosperity and their future prospects, they must be liable for the quality of their own politicians. In the euro area, on the other hand, the costs of inadequate reforms are passed on, for example, via target balances, artificially low interest rates or, right through the printing press. Inequality in the EU is growing, and the dream of economic convergence – once an objective of the introduction of the euro – is further away than ever. Since there can be no devaluation of one's own currency, it is still necessary to devalue internally. As a consequence, an economic government is to be established in order to be able to control the economic policy of the euro area. That is the wrong way to go, because people are fed up with both the transfers and the eu's paternalism. Europe's strength lies in its innovative strength with ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the ALDE Group is of the opinion that this report could be improved. That is why we are presenting some amendments for tomorrow. If they receive the votes of the big coalition, we could reconsider our final negative vote on this dossier. In our opinion, the current version of this report calls for increasing flexibility in public deficit spending, forcing the legal framework. The text also has the wrong view and implications on current account surpluses, which are more critical than current account deficit countries. The dossier does not recommend EFSI projects to be economically viable and falls short, introducing bureaucracy, modernising economies and removing barriers to entry to the labour market. Our amendments tried to make the report more balanced. Fiscal expansion is not the panacea for the current economic situation. We point out the importance of structural reforms. Only if the business environment improves will private investment be mobilised. China is slowing, and even the Federal Reserve in America is afraid that another crisis is around the corner. So it is time for Member States to do their reform homework.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to focus on the social and employment aspect, and I would like to point out that, although it is quite positive that we are now talking about social infrastructure investment, there are still really no concrete criteria for this. What does this actually mean? It still seems to me that, through the European Semester, there is really no growth in employment – on the basis of good work – and also in social security. From my point of view, the cat bites its tail here. If, for example, the aspect of flexicurity is brought up from the dungeon or from the grave and it is claimed that there has only been some overdrafts in the past, then I have to say: no, flexicurity has been precisely the approach why we have more precarious employment today. So there is a lot to discuss, enlighten, change together. If a social pillar is to be created, it must be clarified: what will be the content? Will it be ensured that these minimum standards, which are to be at issue there, will not become a standard for lowering social standards?

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur for the good cooperation in this report and also to thank my shadow rapporteur. Mr Tremosa i Balcells, I am a bit surprised: you say that you are voting against this report because we are using the flexibilities for more investment. Have you been listening to the chief economist of the OECD, who this year joined the ranks saying that Europe needs more investments? It seems that more and more economic institutions in Central Europe, and even outside Europe, are saying that more investments are needed, but ALDE, the Liberals, are keeping up their old strategy of saying ‘no, we should not invest’. This is a very strange attitude, and I am happy that this report gives more room for investment and also more room for investment in human capital, and that we are saying that the euro area’s aggregate fiscal stance is a good thing to look at and that the structural reforms should be more geared to resource efficiency. All these aspects are good aspects in this report, and that is why we as a Group can vote in favour and give once more consideration to the Liberals to really change their strategy, because the world is moving on. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: blue-card question. – This is an irony in itself, because in the Juncker plan, the D66 – our liberals – voted against, and the Greens from the Netherlands voted in favour, and now it seems that the same is happening. But we think that one of the main reasons we are voting against this report is that we wanted to have the word ‘investment’ – the investment that we all agree that we need to be economically viable. Because we have to ensure that no more investment will go to airports without planes, trains without passengers and highways without traffic. We want to ensure this, and we do not want to let Member States [...] (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr Tremosa i Balcells, that was not a question. I let you speak a bit longer but I will nevertheless give the floor to Mr Eickhout.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: blue-card answer. – [...] like a question, because I have to get back to your first contribution, when you said ‘I’m voting against because there is more flexibility and stability growth backed in the report, and there’s also negative language about surplus countries like the Netherlands and Germany’. That is a good thing indeed, and I think we should do so. And on investments: only if really viable; if that is the reason why you would vote against, then just look at the fact that on structural reform and investment we say that the sustainable transition of Member States’ economies towards greater resource efficiency is crucial. That has your point in it, so if that is really your key vote, you can still change and make it a plus.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission's economic recipe is the result for yet another year of three wrong principles: austerity, with the words discipline, rigour and stability put everywhere; reckless reforms, without adequate impact assessments; and famous private investment, but without public stimulus they remain inconsistent. A failed economic recipe, meaningless Community, which still strongly imposes the German will. To oppose this recipe, it is not enough to say 'no' to austerity, but we must be intellectually honest and question the monetary instrument through which states are obliged to apply these wrong policies, continually trampling underfoot national constitutions. The transfer of monetary sovereignty is the original sin and taking it back is the only concrete way to fight against austerity head on and put the Union back on its founding principles and save Europe. To date, we have two clear examples of bargaining power: the strong example of those who do not have the euro, such as the United Kingdom, which can determine itself economically, comes to Brussels to play a leading role, setting the conditions, and the weak one of those who have given up economic policies by adopting the euro and are therefore obliged to do what Brussels and Frankfurt say, begging for flexibility and suffering slaps and injustices in the application of the rules. Greece and Italy are the two most concrete and glaring examples. I am talking about injustice because for almost twenty years we have had a currency that is an expression not of a real currency area, but of a fixed exchange rate bond between 19 states with deep and deep-rooted economic and social differences. We say this in every report on economic issues since we entered this Parliament: every day, for too many years, germans and Dutch have been exploiting the undervalued fixed exchange rate for their economies and enriching themselves by recording current account surpluses in the balance of payments. The Commission is slowing down and doing nothing concrete, applying the MIP too softly, slowly and gradually. Over the years, the Commission has only moved to beat the Mediterranean countries, which are already in difficulty, which are forced to devalue internally, trapped in the impossibility of floating exchange rates in order to close the gap. The Italian Finance Minister, Mr Padoan, also had to admit this a few weeks ago. Plus there are decades of economic studies that say what I'm saying right now. Unfortunately, once again, the issue of the German surplus will not be clearly dealt with head-on in the text on which we are going to vote. There is hope of our amendment to nail Germany, the Netherlands and the Commission; we will see who will vote or who will continue to support a watered-down compromise with the PPE and hide the obvious irrationality and unequal treatment of this monetary union.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, Commissioner, once again we are seeing the total inefficiency of the European Semester. This programme, which consists of putting national economies in step to better build economic and monetary union, does not work. The OECD is lowering its forecasts for growth rates and inflation in the euro area. However, the conditions are very buoyant: the ECB's rates are low, the price of oil is low, the euro-dollar has depreciated by 20% in the last two years, but the European economy is not taking off again. In 1992, your European advertising slogans touted full employment and European prosperity, but twenty-five years later, your socio-economic record is dismal. The euro and your Europe are massive unemployment, stagnation, a mountain of debt, austerity and, above all, financial and banking totalitarianism. Your European utopia is not working and, moreover, the United Kingdom has understood it well and wants to leave this mess. With the same causes having the same effects, none of the Reforms of the European Semester will work. Unfortunately, in a year's time, the situation will be even worse than it is today. That is why we will not vote for this report.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The evaluation of the European Semester must involve an assessment of the state of governance of the Single Market. Unfortunately, it must be said that there is still a great deal of work to be done in this regard.  Dear! We live in the 21st century, and today's times are characterised by, among other things, rapid digital and technological progress, widespread globalisation and international competition, changes in social mentality and consumer patterns, as well as the emergence of completely new, previously unknown forms of economic activity. Thus, in order to maintain existing competition in the common market, the European market, but more importantly, in order to maintain and develop European market competition on the global market, we need deregulation of business conditions, empowering small and medium-sized enterprises, including start-ups, developing innovation, including technological and technological progress, disseminating e-government, reducing the bureaucratic and financial costs of economic activities, fully implementing European law in all Member States , removing non-tariff barriers and protectionism in the Member States.  In fact, we absolutely need to improve the governance of the Single Market. And this is the punchline for today's work.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: – Madam President, we have presented from the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs a good report, a very good report which contrasts, Commissioner, Ladies and gentlemen of the Council, with the reality you describe, with a reality very accommodating to what citizens live in the vast majority of the countries of the European Union. The truth is that we have been recovering for two years, but it is true that it is a slow recovery, it is a weak recovery and, above all, it is a deeply uneven recovery. All international reports tell us. For example, the OECD, I can't help but say it, is stating to us that the differences between the poorest 10% and the 10% it has the most since the start of the crisis have multiplied, in some countries like mine, to seven. And you draw us, as I say, an overly accommodating picture, even with the reality we are seeing, with the new economic and social uncertainties that are scouring us. For this purpose, from the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, from the Socialist Group, we ask you mainly three things. First, encourage investment. Secondly, they correct the excesses of the policy of excessive austerity that have been carried out in both labour reforms and structural reforms, and above all, which have attacked the European social model. And third, to build and strengthen the euro area, the social dimension of our common currency. We have to strengthen investment. If we do not invest, if we fail to create a countercyclical policy in this new climate of economic uncertainty, we will not have learned from the mistakes of the past. We have the Juncker plan, but the Juncker plan is not producing the effect of increasing investment in the euro area. Do you know that with regard, for example, to the United Kingdom or, for example, to the United States, which has increased investment in the last two years, last year in the euro area we continue to decrease global investments compared, for example, to the period 2013-2014? We can't allow it. We need more investment to boost economic growth and we cannot allow what little we know about the Juncker plan today to be as a result of a substitute effect on all Member States on already scheduled and unensured investments. We need to correct the excesses of labour reforms, because employment is being created, but precarious employment, underemployment, working hours of very few hours. We're on totally involuntary partial contracts. We are seeing indefinite contracts replaced by precarious contracts, sometimes by hours. And we are generalizing and not combating a phenomenon of labour poverty which today is, throughout the European Union, to work for less than it allows us to fill the shopping basket or pay the receipt of light, that is, ultimately, to live with dignity. And we have to recover the social model, because it is the fairest policy, but above all it is the most efficient economic policy. With decent pensions, with sufficient unemployment benefits, with scholarships we are not only creating a fairer society, but we are creating automatic stabilizers that protect us against the economic shocks that come from outside. If we don't get back to social models, we won't be learning from the mistakes of the past.  And finally, we have to build a better euro area, with a social dimension. We cannot afford, as I say, that in the next economic crisis wage devaluations ... (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Firstly, I would like to ask you to clarify the availability of the reports being debated today in the mother tongues of Members of the European Parliament. For example, Mr Rodriguez's report on the European Semester was still available today only in English. As far as the European Semester is concerned, fortunately, I can say that this is not a new topic. From my point of view, I have a few comments; two characteristics I would like to present. Firstly, structural reforms in the Member States. We regularly debate how binding the country-specific recommendations are. Let us be clear – the recommendations are, after all, binding, because they are approved by the Heads of Government themselves and very often strike at the very heart of the problem in individual countries. Another point, which is somewhat inter linking to the previous one, is that I cannot imagine how and why to increase economic coordination at European Union level if we are not able to coordinate the ESMS accordingly at the moment. Many countries are not implementing the reforms they are recommended, so I personally believe that we should rather focus on what to do to encourage governments to carry out reforms at national level, especially now that the spectre of another financial and economic crisis is really threatening us.

name: Ulla TØRNÆS
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur from the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, Ms Ribeiro, for a very good and a very constructive process and work on this report. I understand that finding compromises in this matter is not easy, and I understand that many concerns have been taken into consideration. I also have to say, however, that in my opinion the Employment Committee’s position on the annual growth survey could have a more forward-looking approach, recognising the achievements made and pointing to reforms needed in the European labour market to size up the full potential and contribute to strengthening the growth that is now slowly returning to Europe. The economic situation is improving. Unemployment continued to fall in December 2015 by 0.1% compared to November 2015. Unemployment is still too high, standing at 10.4%, but the situation is, however, improving. The number and proportion of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion stabilised in 2013 and 2014. We should not neglect the fact that the social situation is still severe for many and that more efforts need to be made to create growth and new jobs and thereby a way out of poverty and social exclusion, but we should… (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Madam President, the growth prospects for 2016 represent the starting point of a process to which we firmly oppose it. The European Semester and economic governance are at the heart of a neoliberal strategy for national states' fiscal policies. The guidelines contained in the report, which should be followed by governments, insist on the same revenues that have sown poverty and unemployment across Europe, in practice preventing any alternative strategy to tackle the crisis with policies to stimulate growth based on public investment and increased aggregate demand. There are no cosmetic manoeuvres, whether from a social point of view or through the greater involvement of this Parliament, which erase the deeply undemocratic character of economic and monetary union, which imposes, in the interests of the people and workers, its neoliberal policies of concentration of wealth. We remain convinced that only the end of economic and monetary union and the euro can pave the way for alternative development policies.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: – Madam President, like others, I would like to thank the rapporteur of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs for her openness. Within this process many of us have been arguing for quite some time that the social dimension –social fairness – has to be fully recognised. We really hope that what we are seeing here is a genuine shift in the Commission – but I think many of us wait to be convinced. We welcome the additional social indicators, but we think they have got to have a real meaning and a real impact on policy and that social fairness means that we have to tackle the inequalities, both within and between our countries. We recognise that it is not a by-product of economic activity but requires considered action. So we welcome the report’s call for investment in services such as healthcare, child care and housing. Social fairness will be helped by decent wages, and it really is time that we closed the gender pay gap and tackled in—work poverty. We really hope that social dialogue is seriously back on the agenda, having been so badly damaged.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: – Madam President, so we reach this point every year, the moment when supporters of the eurozone predict that happier days are just around the corner – strong growth, major job creation, all the things that never actually come to pass. Euro supporters talk about the potential of further structural reforms, and almost everyone agrees with Mr Draghi about the euro being a success. That is, of course, a complete load of rubbish. The euro area has barely grown at all in the relatively benign conditions of the past year. Take things back to the euro’s inception: an index placing economies at 100 back in the first quarter of 1999 would have just crawled to 123 for the eurozone 17 years later. Even in the UK, where we have had our share of stops and starts, we have reached 137 in the same timeframe. Your politically-inspired currency does not work and as a result many of your young people do not work either. That is not going to change until you put the euro out of its misery. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: blue-card question. – I have been listening to you and I would just like to understand – maybe you can explain to me – why the pound sterling has gone down in the last few days.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: blue-card answer. – Well, as you know, currencies tend to go down and they go up as well. In fact, after the 2008 crash, the pound sterling went down and we saved something like a million jobs in our country, while you were losing millions of jobs in the eurozone because the individual nation states could not run their own currencies. It is actually quite benign that sterling has gone down at the moment because investors across the world have finally woken up to the eurozone weaknesses. So, if we can get a temporary corrective out of a temporary decline in sterling, I do not mind that at all.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: Madam President, Europe is suffering. All indicators are in the red: mass unemployment, lack of competitiveness, recession and austerity.  Colleagues, you are asking for more integration of the single market, but do you really believe it? This process responds to a powerful political agenda whose goal is the disappearance of the nation-state. You continue to present the single market as a remedy for mass unemployment, while every day brings its share of bad results: business closures, relocations, precariousness of whole sectors of the real economy. The stubborn complacency on the integration of the single market is astonishing, given this meagre record, which must be analysed with pragmatism. In the IMCO committee, some colleagues made staggering statements. To say that migrants arriving in the millions must be integrated into the single market and that they are an opportunity for Europe is irresponsible. However, it is simple to anticipate the consequences of the integration of these populations on the labour market and on average wages. Who benefits from crime, one might wonder.  Ladies and gentlemen, European economies need oxygen, they are stifling because of the centralising rules imposed by the Commission and its experts. Market governance is an old-fashioned concept that my group will oppose tomorrow.

name: David CASA
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank our rapporteur, Ms Sofia Ribeiro, for her excellent work on this dossier. It has to be acknowledged that the European Semester has clearly shown that it provided the necessary tools that helped Member States get out of the financial crisis, but the crisis has left its scars on the European social model. The challenge lies in strengthening the social dimension of the EU. It is encouraging to note that three new employment indicators have been added to the main scoreboard. In order to strengthen the recovery and foster upward economic and social convergence across Member States, it is necessary to reform our economies and invest in human capital to create more jobs at all levels. Europe has a number of tools at its disposal to achieve this: essentially the Europe 2020 strategy and the implementation of the Investment Plan for Europe. On both counts, we need to look carefully at improving its implementation and monitoring in order to ensure smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. Finally, I believe that Member States need to take a holistic approach to implementing effective labour market policies, targeting both jobseekers and employers. It is important to facilitate job-seeking in the European Union through education, training and reskilling.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I am very pleased, Mr Casa, to listen to you. The internal market is one of the cornerstones of the European Union. This is said time and time again, and I am absolutely convinced of that. However, I am always amazed at the old-fashioned ideas that still remain in many minds, which say: yes, it is only about the economy, it is only about business, preferably the very big companies, and then everything will be settled. No! We need a holistic approach – as you have just said – in which not only the economy, not only businesses, but high-quality jobs, innovation and consumer protection are designed at the best possible level. Only if we bring this together as a whole will we be able to advance the economy of the European Union and ensure that not only jobs are created, but also economic growth, which is what we need in our economies. We must ensure that this is the first time that we are doing so. That is why I am pleased that the internal market has finally been brought to the centre of the European Semester in order to be able to take these aspects forward. And I am pleased that if we succeed in solving a small problem with paragraph 46 in the Stihler report, we in our group will really be able to vote in favour of all the reports.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The European Semester is, after all, part of the attempt at economic governance in the European Union. Economic governance can be made if we have a clear objective in mind, as was originally the case in the context of economic governance: an objective of the stability of public finances, the soundness of public financing. However, we have never achieved this objective. This goal has suffered catastrophic shipwreck in the sovereign debt crisis of 2010 and 2011. That is why the new philosophy seems to be that we are expanding the catalogue of objectives a little, that we are adding a lot of other indicators to our scoreboards, and Mrs Gebhardt has just, so to speak, expanded this into a holistic approach. If we only have enough objectives, ladies and gentlemen, then we will probably happen to achieve a goal somehow. But in the end, the control becomes completely useless. If we look at what is happening in the euro area today, we see that the objectives are being ignored: Portugal should therefore save, say. But the Portuguese are adopting a budget that is not an austerity budget. The Italians should also save money. But they say they need more fiscal space and ask whether they should simply raise the deficit again than is actually necessary. The French pass laws that require them to run the deficit again for the third year in a row. Greece is dancing around on everyone's nose and not adopting the necessary reforms. Ladies and gentlemen, let us give up control and simply let the countries themselves implement their economic policies!

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: – Madam President, the single market is actually the biggest and most successful achievement that we have in the European Union, and we should be proud of it. In the last 50 years it has generated opportunities, created jobs and offered greater choice at lower prices for consumers. But the work is far from finished and a lot of challenges are still ahead. Single market governance is a top priority, and the European Semester is a wonderful tool for that. I strongly believe that the EU should use the momentum of the collaborative economy. The Commission and Member States should encourage the development of new business models by ensuring the best possible conditions for them to develop and thrive. The Commission and Member States should work better to enforce the mutual recognition principle as this is crucial for the better functioning of the single market. Furthermore, the single market needs new market surveillance and product safety legislation at European level. I strongly encourage the Commission to take the lead there.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Madam President, we are dealing with a number of documents that continue to deepen the European Semester and economic governance policies, in a posture of making up and laundering its objectives and consequences. The lie of these instruments is sold as the path to development, economic growth and convergence when, on the contrary, they are instruments that compromise the sovereignty of states, which promote development asymmetries, capital concentration, social inequalities, the attack on workers' rights and the precariousization of work. We reject the European Semester and economic governance policies, contrary to any attempt to launder or legitimise impoverishment and austerity policies. We affirm the need to break with these policies and, as opposed, to strengthen the sovereignty of states and to support economic and sustainable development and growth through public control of strategic sectors, in working with decent rights and wages. (The speaker refuses to answer a "blue card" question from Mr Nuno Melo)

name: Pascal DURAND
text: Madam President, the European Semester is the EU's scoreboard to ensure consistency in European public policy. Beyond the mantra of "competitiveness, growth, administrative burden", this control should integrate the real social and economic tools of sustainability. Unfortunately, in the report, no mention is made of either the issue of the circular economy or the question of the management and efficient use of resources, which was specifically requested by the European Parliament in July 2015. On the other hand, how can we understand, in a report aimed at the governance of the single market, the absence, after the Volkswagen and Dieselgate scandal, of market surveillance tools? How can we also understand, after the LuxLeaks, the absence of fiscal and social convergence to balance public policy? Therefore, Mrs Stihler, and I regret it, in view of the work you have done, because of these absences, we will unfortunately be forced to vote against this report.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which In fact, every year in this debate, we discuss a great deal about budget figures, alleged imbalances and reproaches among ourselves, but unfortunately lose sight of the fact that, of course, the 28 Member States of the European Union, the euro area Member States, also have a personal responsibility to ensure that responsibility for the growth forces that the European Union can actually provide, namely a single internal market with uniform standards and uniformly applied implementing laws. , often falls out of focus. This is a pity, because only if all the Member States actually take the trouble to see the internal market as the heart of the European Semester can we succeed in actually narrowing the wealth gap and the internal market having the economic impact it needs. I say this every year at this point and I know that, unfortunately, it is not sufficiently heard in the European Semester. Nevertheless, I thought it would make sense to repeat it.

name: Joachim SCHUSTER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In the new European Semester there is a lot of light and a lot of shadow. It is positive to note that more investment calls for new impetus for growth. This is important, because unemployment in Europe is still unbearably high and the central problem. It is to be deplored, however, that, in the end, there is no turning away from the harmful austerity policy. Fiscal consolidation is still higher in many Member States than the fight against unemployment. Those who really want to promote employment need to change course more clearly. We need a consistent growth policy through the massive expansion of public investment. We finally need a European tax policy that finances all things by combating tax avoidance and tax evasion. We need to strengthen domestic demand, including through an expansionary wage policy in the surplus countries, and we need more social indicators to be taken into account in policy recommendations. Initial course corrections will be hinted at in the European Semester. It is important to develop them.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: – Let's start with the good news in these reports. I do think it is wise to reduce the rules and interference for companies and, in particular, SMEs. But when it comes to the socio-economic aspects, you miss out! In order for our economy to grow again, the government does not have to spend more money, but rather shrink. You are pointing the finger at countries that are putting their budgets in order, but it is those who do not respect the budgetary rules that we should be tapping into. Flexible labour markets should not be dismissed as antisocial, but are like a cure for unemployment. My recommendation is to read less Paul Krugman and Paul De Grauwe this European semester.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: Madam President, Mr Drombovskis, I am addressing you directly. The European institutions were responsible for the failure resulting from austerity and went into a state of denial.  There is persistence in the economic and social disaster, they masked it and called it compliance or non-compliance with the rules. But when we look at the Commission's behaviour, we find everything but rules and criteria. Different countries deserve different treatment, depending on their size, whether they react or not to structural reforms, but above all, depending on what the European Commission's ideological agenda is, which has to do with the easing of the labour market, privatisation and the dismantling of the social state. We look at the Deliberations of the European Commission, for example, on Portugal, Spain, Italy, France and Austria: criterion, none; equality, none; arbitrariness.  And so I want to ask you, Commissioner, if you really want to continue on this path, because those who have fulfilled the most – the so-called good pupils – have had the worst results.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the coordination of economic and budgetary policies within the euro area are the keys to the European Semester. We must ensure that we contribute to ensuring the convergence and stability of the euro area. We must also ensure that we contribute to ensuring healthy public finances. And we must also ensure that we promote economic growth and job creation. Because the way to consolidate economic recovery is undoubtedly reforms at the national level and also progress in the long-awaited and necessary economic union and, ultimately, political union. Because, ladies and gentlemen, reforms mean growth, and Spain, despite what Mrs Matias says, is an example of this. It is one of the countries that has made the most reforms and is the country that grows three times more than the euro area average and also created six hundred thousand new jobs last year.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: " The benefits of growth and jobs must be felt first and foremost by our people. Yes, the recovery is palpable, which has to be acknowledged: employment is increasing slightly, unemployment is falling. But, dear colleagues, first of all, I want to draw your attention to the huge problem in our European Union countries, namely child poverty. As many as 27% of children in the European Community are in poverty. I therefore call on the Commission and the Member States to create a guarantee for children, a measure with a certain special budget, whereby our children can receive free healthcare, education, decent accommodation, proper nutrition. Secondly, I would also like to draw attention to women's poverty. However, I would like to call on the Commission and the Member States to make specific recommendations and measures to reduce the gender pay and pension gap.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, go east in Europe, go west. Ask north, ask south, you always get the same answer. Everyone wants economic growth. There is no disagreement on this in this House. Whether the keys to economic growth can be found in Brussels or in the Member States. There's a difference of opinion on this. As we know, the European Union is now recovering from the worst economic crisis in its history. The journey back to growth has begun, in some Member States better, in others worse.  I believe that the growth report presented by Mrs Rodrigues provides good ideas for strengthening European economic growth. Increasing public investment and strengthening domestic demand play a key role in getting the wheels of the economy back on track. However, these matters should not be decided in Brussels. The best way to support growth is to make the right decisions in the Member States' own parliaments.

name: Nuno MELO
text: – Madam President, we agree on the drawbacks of austerity policies. But, starting with it, some of those who appeal to the solidarity of those who comply with rules do not make austerity inevitable, as has happened in Portugal, poorly ruling the Socialists until 2009.  A country that spends more than it can afford condemns itself intolerably and indebted to future generations. That is why the absurd spending options until 2009 meant – necessary condition – deficit, debt, unemployment, recession, inability to finance markets and the troika. Now, in 2016, the same ruling socialists, having lost the elections, insist again on fanciful budgets, where they predict growth above – see there – the European Union's own average. We've seen that movie. I'm afraid you know how this is going to end. (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the "blue card" procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: Rapporteur, question "blue card". – Dear Mr Melo, we are witnessing an intervention by Mrs Rodrigues in this debate with a Europeanist speech, which called for the strengthening of the euro zone, and on the other hand we are watching a speech by our communist colleagues with a totally Eurosceptic speech. Now, we have found that there is a gap between the speeches here and I wanted to know if Mr Melo is accompanying me in the misunderstanding of this coalition which, in Portugal, has a speech and, here in Europe, is having another completely different one.

name: Nuno MELO
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – It could not be more agreement and, not coincidentally, the Communist MP who wanted to question with the blue card did not answer and fled – he is not even in the room anymore. But that's the way it is. In fact, in Portugal, we have a party that governs, having lost the elections, which has learned nothing from the mistakes of the past and that persists in the budgetary illusion of those who want to make faith a science. Faith in growth forecasts, which those who do accounts do not conceive, unfortunately do not have a translation in reality, and so I am very much in agreement with the honourable Member, thank you very much for your question. (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the "blue card" procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: rapporteur, asks "blue card". – Mr Nuno Melo, it is indeed fantastic how you and other colleagues insist on making this Parliament an amphitheatre to discuss Portuguese politics – that is not really the case. However, what is at stake here is whether or not it is possible to combine budgetary responsibility with recovery of growth, job creation and reducing social inequalities. The party government you are a part of has failed to do that in recent years, and what it comes to is whether the government that is now in office will be able to do it, and I think it will.

name: Nuno MELO
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – Madam President, the step in your speech referred to the advantage of solidarity of countries in better budgetary conditions compared to countries in difficulty, particularly in the euro area. What I would like to say to you is that it also gives a wrong signal, because it has not had a say in relation to the need for structural reforms of those who, by governing badly, by mistake, to some extent condemn, in the future, their own development – that is, we cannot appeal to the help of others when we have our own responsibilities and we do nothing to overcome them either. And what I think is that, in his speech, he should have a speech between solidarity of others and internal responsibility – and, in relation to that responsibility, the Socialist Portuguese Party has a lot to say, unfortunately.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Madam President, the real problem with the current economic performance in Europe is investment. There is not enough of it, so growth is limited. The improvement – indeed the preservation – of social conditions for workers in employment, young people looking for a job, working families and pensioners is not in sight. These people claim that Europe is failing them. The social compact on which it was established is no longer there. It is not populist to agree with those who make such claims, as they are right. The problem is not about agreeing or disagreeing with them. The problem is how to get economic growth back on track so that full—time, secure jobs are generated for young people and the old do not fear for their pensions. We do not need complex technocratic tools to solve this problem. We just need the political will to think outside the box into which we have squared ourselves, supposedly in order to satisfy the Stability and Growth Pact.
