We need simple, decisive action that goes to the root of the problem: public and private investment. The record shows that private investment follows from public investment, not the other way round. Public investment has been lagging. The Juncker fund, worthwhile though it is, cannot cover the problem. Moreover, public investment is more effective when deployed at national level when it does not have to depend on the delays of bureaucracy. If we can find ways and means of promoting national public investment that will in turn stimulate national and Europe-wide private investment, would this breach the current rules of the Stability and Growth Pact? Possibly, yes. Should we care much? In my view, no, so long as we make sure that added public spending on a national basis is really being dedicated to investment, not recurrent outlays.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Madam President! There is something paradoxical about having this debate just hours after we discussed the agreement that David Cameron has reached in the European Council, precisely because that agreement separates the eurozone from non-euro zone countries. This is a fact which is not reflected in this report at all. You could say that this report, even now that we are discussing it in this House, is old-fashioned. It does not reflect the new reality that we have in the European Union, namely that the countries that are in the euro zone must, of course, have more sovereignty deposited in the Community in Brussels, more central control in order to allow this currency to survive, while we, fortunately outside, should not be part of that centralisation. This is a completely central premise – not least when you look at what the economic development of the world is like in these years, when you have to say it is not flashy what is going on in the euro zone. I recall the debate over the last fifteen years on whether the euro should be what saved the EU economy. So far, only the opposite has happened. And nothing will change in the European Semester. (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question, see Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. I myself believe that any economic growth or budgetary balance should not be worth causing a serious decline in social rights. I ask you, do you think this deal was worth it that Europe had given up a lot of social rights to keep Britain in?

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Blue-card response. – I do not see Britain "sacrificing social rights" as it was translated for me. On the contrary, I believe that, with the agreement that has been reached, Britain actually secures support for a community that I believe both you and my country have a common interest in surviving. Because if we do not ensure fairness in, for example, access to social benefits, then public support for eu work will not increase, no, it will fall further. Some people may think it can't get any further down, but it can. I can assure you all of that. What David Cameron is doing is the greatest gift to cooperation in Europe, because if you do not listen to criticism in member states like mine, or in Britain, then support will fall ever more. This means that even the entities and areas that we agree are good – freedom of movement, that one can create growth together – will also disappear. Reflect on it, Mr President.

name: Lara COMI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would also like to thank the Commissioner for all the help he is giving us at the moment. I apologise for not talking about maximum systems, but I think it is time for the Council to take its responsibilities for the implementation of the product surveillance package, including with regard to safety, with regard to this. We need a secure market, we need people to really know what they are wearing, how they dress, what they are eating. This is called traceability for us, and we regret that this package is once again blocked. We need a "made in": yes, I defend "made in Italy", but I also defend "made in Europe", and for this reason I believe that we need a breakthrough on the part of the Council, precisely to move forward, otherwise we are not competitive.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the single market is undoubtedly the best result of the process of European integration. Its value is borne out by the debate on Brexit these days: it is in fact the real argument of those in London who claim that an exit from the European Union is inappropriate. The many studies on the costs of 'non-Europe' show that the single market is still incomplete today and with a wide untapped potential. But today there are also other clouds on the horizon: national interests and selfishness and the questioning of the principle of free movement in the Schengen area can not only further curb its completion, but also undermine the achievements achieved so far. At this difficult time for European unity, however, we must once again see the single market as a driver of growth and innovation for a new competitive Europe.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I agree that the principles of social policy must be taken into account in the management of the European Union's economic policy. But how far can the Union's coordination of social policy go? The European Union is supposed to help to point the way, not to abuse its role by falling within the powers of the Member States of the Union. Member States should carry out their own social policies, so it is difficult to agree with some of the provisions in Mrs Ribeiro's report, for example, that the European Social Fund should allocate 20% of its funds to the fight against poverty and social exclusion.  Nor can the proposal that the European Commission be empowered to monitor and control employment contracts concluded in individual Member States be accepted. Such regulations are too much entry into the powers of the Member States of the Union. It is up to the governments of the Member States to know best how to solve the social problems of their countries, and it is up to the voters of the country, the people, to decide which government, what position on social issues they want to choose.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. The European Semester was introduced in response to the severe economic and financial crisis. Economic imbalances should thus be identified in good time to prevent new crises. Two points are particularly important to me in the discussion: on the one hand, the European Semester must improve, it has not always achieved the desired results. There have been too many and too often superficial recommendations, and the Member States have not always followed the recommendations. Secondly, we are currently discussing a great deal about how to make Europe more social. Social indicators are often used to determine the economic situation. In the report we find three social indicators: youth and long-term unemployment and the employment rate. These three indicators, in my view, are part of the European Semester process. However, I also call for all other macroeconomic indicators to remain in the same number and weight. Here, too, we must maintain a balance between the various groups of indicators.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, I would like to start by thanking the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs and all the colleagues who have made amendments to these reports. They are not perfect, but I believe that here are very well formulated things that can indeed lead to the governance of the single market and which ultimately achieve their goal. The quality of this governance is very important – and really to reach an attractive European Union, and we will obviously also have concrete results on job growth, social cohesion and improving the quality of life. Cross-border development is needed and this is included in the report, the development of jobs in poor areas. There is a need for common competitiveness policies and, lo and behold, there is an amendment on the network of national competitiveness councils. It needs to increase its role in common competitiveness policies.  Public procurement and the public sector are important vectors but, Commissioner, honourable members of the Council, there must be more transparency and more ethical competition. SMEs need to be in the attention of governance and I believe that the report is worth voting on.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. I am a great supporter of using this tool flexibly with respect for states and for their responsibility, without centralism – that is what Mr Krasnodębski has just said, but I would like to draw attention to something that cannot formally belong to our debate, but has a great impact on European solidarity, on economic and budgetary balance in individual countries and on making efforts for Europe. These are defence spending. Only five European countries (Poland, France, the United Kingdom, Estonia and Greece) account for 2% of GDP in defence spending. The rest of the countries do not. The scale of these burdens must be taken into account by the European Commission, because it has a powerful impact on the budgetary commitments of these countries, and these are expenditures for the security of all Europeans. I strongly encourage you to take this into account.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: – Madam President, I share the priority objectives and specific recommendations for the euro area, but I would like to stress the section on the need to invest in people. European citizens have faced great difficulties. Therefore, the consolidation of economic recovery has to be extrapolated to society as a whole, and its greatest exponent must be employment.  The problem of youth unemployment has been linked to long-term unemployment, increasing the risk of poverty and social exclusion and making it difficult to return to the labour market, especially among older workers. Lifelong learning education systems must be adapted to the current and future needs of the labour market with greater cooperation of the education system with the business world, as it is inconceivable that these unemployment rates coexist with nearly two million vacant jobs throughout the European Union, or that 39% of companies seeking qualified staff in the digital sphere have difficulty finding it.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, the single market is not only the cornerstone of the European Union, but also represents the only real and measurable benefit for Member States. Today, only the biggest extremists on the left and right are slowing the value of the single market for our states and this is an indication that its establishment in all areas is something we need to work on seriously.  It is clear that this market is not and cannot be isolated from member states' economic and social policies. Often, in this context, there is talk of tax oases and their harmful effects. Whereas on the other hand, I think a little bit, actually too little, we're talking about bad policies that create what I like to say and call the twilight zone.  The Twilight Zone is created by unreasonable taxes and unnecessary regulations and procedures that directly affect entrepreneurs and limit their growth and further employment, which impoverishes our societies. The single market does not make excessive sense if it is over-regulated and participation in it weighs too much on European companies.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! Today's debate on economic policy coordination in the European Union is very important because I have the impression that we are all not entirely satisfied with the effects of this economic policy. Over the last ten years, between 2005 and 2014, gross domestic product across the European Union has increased by only 7.5% and in the euro area only 5%. These are not results that satisfy our societies. Public disillusionment is so great that all those who seek the guilty also point the finger at Brussels, even though it is the Member States that have the greatest share and responsibility for the economic performance of each country.  I would like to call on the European Commission to increase the activity, firmness and effectiveness of the impact on the Member States so that the potential growth rate in the European Union is significantly increased. We have talked a lot about investment, but it is not just about investment. Employment and technological progress are also important. I therefore call for, as part of the country-specific recommendations to be prepared, to pay even more attention to issues relating to labour market reform and increasing the labour force of the population, as well as to improving innovation and accelerating technological progress, because without this, Europe will lose its distance to the rest of the world.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – Madam President, I welcome the Vice-President and the Representatives of the Council. The success of the European Semester requires a great deal of coordination: coordination between local, regional, national objectives and needs with objectives at EU level; coordination between cohesion policy and recommendations to Member States; coordination of different sources of funding and synergies; coordination of different European policies, such as environmental protection, transport policy, energy, digital policy, urban, rural, innovation, research and development policy and of course cohesion and economic and focus on their implementation. Quality and efficient coordination is one of the biggest challenges, especially given the number of Member States and the number of different institutions responsible for different policies, but also different organisations within the Member States. That is why it is very important for us to work on coordination, because without it we will not even achieve implementation.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, again in the same play viewers as the Commission proposes the same well-known failed recipe: merkelic austerity, violent fiscal adjustment and implementation of the anti-social Stability Pact. However, this will not reduce poverty, unemployment and underdevelopment affecting the peoples of the European South as well as the Greek people. Through the European Semester, European bureaucracy and banking intervene in the conduct of the economic policy of the Member States of the Union, abolish the will of the European peoples and annihilate the sovereign rights of Parliaments, to freely shape national budgets.  Madam President, Greece continues to groan under the boot of the troika that dissolves insurance, hammers the homes of Greeks, makes a tax resalto in the pockets of the Greek people, reduces the pensions of the people of life and dissolves Greek farmers.  But this cannot go on for long, Mr Dombrovskis, as the Greek people step up their fight to finally throw the troika out of Greece.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, unemployment and insufficient economic growth definitely remain the main problems in many Member States. Are we ready to face this challenge, and especially with the challenge to come, as many hint at new years of new crises. The European Union wants to combine a number of policies with the European Semester, and of course this is absolutely not easy.  Especially if we want to combine the education system, if we want to combine an environmental protection system, if we want to combine the social system with our economic growth. That is why I accept many of the thesis in this report, but I invite Mrs. Rodrigues to accept the ALDE amendments as well, so that we can all vote for your report together.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, the European Semester is the institutionalisation of neoliberalism. And this year in the reports on the European Semester I read how this helps the single market and competitiveness and how this promotes employment and growth. Ladies and gentlemen, employment and growth are not the historically high unemployment figures and the sharp decline in the labour force in the countries with memoranda, nor is it the poverty of the population, nor is it the deregulation of the labour market and the dissolution of the social state. In the reports on the European Semester we read about the advantages of coordinating the Union's economic policies. What coordination? Do we recognise that the European Semester is only aimed at promoting the interests of large multinational companies and reducing wages and social rights downwards? We, on the left, reject the European Semester, so we will also vote against the reports, but also the logic of neoliberalism, austerity of memoranda and budgetary discipline at the expense of the people. The President interrupts the speaker

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – Dear colleagues, mr. I would like to make one comment in addition to the praise words for Rodriguez's report. This is a review by the Commission and, in my opinion, a fundamentally wrong idea that member states must be punished for errors or shortcomings in cohesion management by restricting cohesion aid to them or by creating pre-ex ante conditions. I do not see a positive link between economic governance and cohesion policy. Both issues are very important, but we cannot come down to a roughly instrumental approach, as the Commission proposes. These issues need to be dealt with separately, not by making each other a condition. I also regret the fact that the rapporteurs have failed to make such a provision in the report. In the area of cohesion policy, sanctions against Member States will not only make the European Union more difficult to achieve good governance, but will also complicate economic growth.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Madam President, according to the Commission, the over-influx of migrants, whether smuggled or not, will have short-term adverse economic consequences, while in the medium and long term it will help the economy due to an increased supply of cheap labour. You're making a mistake. If not, you're a criminal! So far about a million cheap labour, as you call them, are waiting in Greece to find work in the European Union. You are deceived if you think that by taking Greece out of the Schengen zone, imposing unbearable memoranda and condemning it to death, you will also stop the huge influx of illegal immigrants, jihadists and criminal Islamic extremists who exploit the refugee influxes to enter Europe. All of them, sooner or later, will end up in your countries. How are you going to find out and stop the criminal evidence in time? How will you educate, maintain, care for and integrate millions of immigrants into local communities? Already, many of them wish to impose the law of Islam by force.  The problem is not economic, but social, religious, ethnic, and much more European.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Member States continue to record high youth unemployment: it is clear from the available data that the level of implementation of the Youth Guarantee programme is clearly unsatisfactory. We should place greater emphasis on creating opportunities for young people to work largely by teaching entrepreneurship. We will not need any guarantees. We are also concerned about the increase in the number of people in the category of working poor. In addition, non-standard forms of employment are abused in many countries. I would like to stress that ensuring flexibility in employment is necessary for the proper functioning of both European companies and workers. This does not change the fact that every worker, regardless of the form of employment, should be covered by the social security system. In this situation, it seems a good step to introduce three new employment indicators in the Annual Growth Index and to place greater emphasis on labour and social policy. It is important that we do not find ourself in a situation where, despite improvements in macroeconomic indicators, the lives of ordinary people will deteriorate. I congratulate Sofia Ribeiro on her very good work on the report.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Madam President, the priorities of the Semester report address vital aspects relating to social and labour rights. This is a misleading text that presents as new the same recipes of austerity that have caused so much damage to southern Europe. The rigidity with which austerity policies are maintained, fiscal consolidation and the strangulation of public investment make this framework unfair and inefficient for improving the European situation. In this regard, the European Central Bank needs to renegotiate the Stability Pact and to see new, more flexible instruments within the deadlines. We must remove this drag that hinders the growth of southern economies. A country like Spain, which has more than 20% unemployment, where 12.3% of workers are poor and where one-third of the population lives at risk of social exclusion, needs a plan that does not continue to increase these numbers. The Commission continues to propose patches rather than solutions, thinking that changing words eliminates problems. Problems need to be addressed knowing who we put first, and in this sense for us it will always be citizenship.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank you for this very stimulating and productive debate today. The European Parliament has an important role to play in progress on European economic policies, and I have carefully taken note of the remarks made today by Members of Parliament. The European economy has come out of the recession, but still it remains on a path of very modest recovery, and unfortunately today there are more reasons for concern than a few months ago. The external environment has deteriorated and we have seen a marked increase in financial market volatility and risk aversion. In order to nurture this recovery we need to ensure that this is supported by the measures and policies needed to unlock further growth. While different views and opinions were expressed today during the debate, I am pleased to see that many of you largely share our integrated strategy based on investment, structural reforms and responsible fiscal policy. We are committed to bringing economic and social levels across Europe closer and closer to the best performers. The Commission welcomes the European Parliament’s contribution to the European Semester by way of its regular and timely reports such as the ones we are discussing today. We also welcome the strengthened cooperation between the European Parliament and the national parliaments such as in the European Parliamentary Week in which I took part last week. I believe we share the same goals – to promote economic growth and job creation in Europe – and I look forward to continued good cooperation with Parliament and those involved with this topic also in the future.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me start by saying that the internal market is a key asset of the EU through which the EU can deliver directly to its citizens – growth, jobs, prosperity – and therefore the work towards the further deepening of the internal market is a main priority for our Presidency. I would like to underline the importance both of new proposals in fields where the internal market is not completed yet and of the full implementation of existing legislation. Many of you also stressed the importance of strengthening the social dimension in the Semester, and I understand. But as you know, Member States have different opinions on strengthening the European Semester on the social dimension and employment. A number of Member States made it very clear that social policy matters fall within the competence of Member States. They do not wish to give in on national sovereignty through the Semester process. However, all Member States – and this is the good news – stress that a revamped European Semester should continue to ensure that necessary structural reforms are implemented to address social and employment challenges and continually improve social and employment outcomes, taking into account the targets set in the Europe 2020 Strategy with regard to increasing employment, fighting poverty and social inclusion. Many of you also emphasised the importance of the implementation of the country-specific recommendations (CSRs), and I could not agree more. CSRs are the key to structural reforms in Member States. Sometimes it is not easy – sometimes it is even painful – as I said it at the beginning, and let’s face it, reforming Europe’s pension system or labour market is difficult. But it is the best way to kick-start growth and jobs, so yes, I agree with you, implementation is therefore crucial. Many important points were raised today. I will need to keep them in mind in the coming months. Soon the Commission will adopt country reports analysing Member States’ economic situations, their reform agendas and possible imbalances, and this will mark the beginning of the groundwork by experts and should lead to the adoption of the upcoming country-specific recommendations in the summer. In other words, and in closing, this is an important phase of the European Semester where we can take stock of how much has been achieved in each Member State and set out the main challenges ahead. Many are long—standing issues, from reforming our social protection systems to ensuring well-functioning housing markets. Others are new, such as setting up the right policies to deal, for example, with the recent influx of refugees and migrants. All require our full attention in the year to come. In order to face up to all these challenges, our continued cooperation will be of the greatest importance.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, it is now my pleasure to intervene in the conclusion of this debate. I also found the debate extremely useful. I would also like to thank the Commission and the Presidency for the statements they made. With these three good reports, we can see a new compromise emerging for a stronger recovery – to implement the Europe 2020 strategy with the right combination of investments and reforms, but also to tackle imbalances and social inequalities. We need to do so. You can be sure that Parliament stands ready to go on working, together with the Commission and the Presidency, to deliver on the next phases of the European Semester. That is why I would like to use my last minutes to propose that, by building precisely on our very positive experience over the last months, we can open negotiations on the interinstitutional agreement in order to improve the European Semester. In practice, we could already get some of these improvements, because we could have a good discussion with the Commission before the adoption of the Annual Growth Survey and immediately afterwards. A second important improvement was the euro area discussion in plenary, which was also an opportunity to interact with the President of the Eurogroup. Finally, as we can see now, we in Parliament can deliver three reports well in advance, to be taken into account for the preparation of the upcoming spring European Council, thus improving the interface we have between Parliament and the Council. We can build on this progress and consider the possibility of an interinstitutional agreement to have a European Semester with more democratic legitimacy, but also with more relevance and impact on the ground regarding our citizens.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank colleagues, the Commission and the Presidency of the Council for the richness of the debate we had this afternoon. There is a common line here, according to which we must invest in the European Union. The question is what kind of investments we want and under what conditions do we launch that investment. This is the responsibility of all of us as the European Union, but it is a responsibility which in many cases is also exclusive to the Member States, and the Member States cannot afford that responsibility. We need stability in our public policies and we need to gain the trust of our investors. And since we are talking about confidence – and we have just talked about the Portuguese situation, in which we have set an example by colleagues of the Socialist Party on the Portuguese issue, in which a vote of confidence has been asked for the Portuguese Government, which was given by the European institutions – let me just say that we cannot have uncertainties. Mrs Rodrigues said she thinks we can grow. We cannot think, we cannot continue to use demagoguery and we cannot afford to do more experiments in Europe, we must be sure, we must have responsible policies and we must have properly targeted policies. In the last two years, we have witnessed, both at the level of my country and at European Union level, an economic and social recovery, which is true that has been timid, but which has pointed us to a path that we must continue. If it is true – and it has been recognised – that there are numerous factors that can be reviewed and that must be reviewed – and we have that responsibility – we cannot lose everything and we cannot make change just by change.  It is in this sense that I am prepared to continue to cooperate with the Commission so that we can, in fact, in conjunction with national parliaments and the social partners, understand how, in a global and local way, we can actually build the Europe of citizens.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, thank you to colleagues, the shadows, the Council and the Commission. The importance of the single market has been heard today and we know that we have the beauty of the single market, but balancing that with social rights is some strength that we have within this European Union. Many colleagues have spoken about the issue of digital, and I would like to touch on the importance of the digital single market in my final remarks. We are experiencing this Fourth Industrial Revolution. You just need to look across at colleagues while this debate has been going on, with everyone on their smartphones. In fact, by 2021, 70% of all handsets will be smartphones. By 2020 there will be 14 billion network devices and 3.2 billion people using the internet. Mobile traffic alone has grown by 65% from Quarter 4 in 2014 to Quarter 4 in 2015. We are truly experiencing this revolution, and this links into the Semester and the single market. There are three points I want to make: accessibility when it comes to the digital single market strategy; accessibility to superfast broadband and infrastructure; and accessibility to ensure that those who have the least also have access to this revolution. We do not want the digital divide to become a digital chasm. On skills, we look at the range from just switching on a computer right through to becoming a software developer. In fact, while we have been speaking in this Chamber, one of the great initiatives called CodeClan has been happening in Scotland. This allows people who want to be software engineers to be able to do that within a three- to four-month period. This is about lifelong learning and about mindset – a mindset that, no matter if you are a small business or a multinational, we all have to get real about digital. Therefore I think we have an opportunity through the Semester, and through the single market, to make the European Union one of the most digitally-savvy spaces in the planet, and this is the opportunity we have now.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The joint discussion is over. The vote will take place on Thursday, February 25, 2016, at 11:30 a.m. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Since the economic crisis of 2008, the European right has imposed drastic austerity measures on us. These measures have been in place for almost 8 years now and nothing is moving! State debt continues to rise, the unemployment rate remains at a historically high ceiling and the gap between rich and poor is growing by the day.  However, since the beginning of this year, we have seen encouraging signs of change and this report is once again proof of this. Indeed, for the first time, the report on the European semester, which sets out policy guidelines for the year, calls for more investment and a balanced tax policy in parallel with austerity measures. It also takes social problems into account and provides solutions to them.  A new lease of life, then, on economic policy. Investment is beginning to be a priority and we can only be satisfied with that. I can only welcome this change of course in Europe and I hope that it will help to revive the European economy and with it growth and jobs.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. This report supports the strategy, which I believe to be unsuccessful, proposed by the European Commission, insisting on the need to continue with fiscal consolidation, structural reforms, private investment, full application of the Stability and Growth Pact. While presenting some points that we in the 5-Star Movement supported, such as the importance of stimulating domestic demand and increasing public investment and paying greater attention to environmental issues, the problem of unemployment and growing inequalities, these are references which, if not accompanied by proposals for alternative policies and revision of the rules and mechanisms of economic governance , are empty and insufficient. What I really do not think is in the report is a critical reflection on the need for a real change of course in the policies adopted so far. I regret that I did not find in the text an adequate analysis of the role of the euro, macroeconomic imbalances, budgetary constraints and the impact of the Commission's recipes on the economy. In general, I do not believe that what is expressed in this report is what Europe needs.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. – We believe that employment and social inclusion issues should be high on the European Union's agenda and effective actions should be taken in coordination and cooperation between the European Parliament, the European Commission and the European Council, with a single objective: to increase jobs and reduce the unemployed and the socially excluded. This must be the EU's top priority and it must focus and respond in practice with policies, projects and strong funding towards the fight against unemployment and social exclusion.  In recent years the EU has been being tested hard by the social and relentless nightmare of unemployment that irreparably affects almost all European countries and societies. The thousands of European unemployed, especially young people, must not leave us alone for a moment. The vision of a united Europe and a social Europe does not fit unemployed, socially excluded, people below the poverty line. The effects of unemployment, especially for young people, have enormous social and economic consequences.  I mention, characteristically, that the loss of human capital due to unemployment is enormous and that the total cost of unemployment has been estimated at EUR 153 billion per year.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. – The European Commission's current survey of annual growth in the European Union in 2016, subtitled to boost recovery and promote the convergence of the economies of its Member States, sounds at least paradoxical. The reality is that instead of convergence we have a constant divergence, with the Member States of the Mediterranean south trapped in a vicious cycle of austerity-recession-new austerity.  Moreover, the whole Union, and in particular the euro area, is showing anemic growth in relation to the USA and China, while real household incomes are falling, through the ever-worse squeeze on labour wages, in the name of supposedly boosting competitiveness. We need demand-boosting policies at pan-European level and greater solidarity between Member States. And we also need an authentic pan-European deposit guarantee scheme in order to strengthen depositors' confidence in the banking systems of the euro-region countries and to finance their economy with sound new resources. When the cost of borrowing in Greece exceeds 10% and in Germany it is close to 1%, competition becomes unfair and the divergence of economies is constantly increasing. Hypocrisy must end and there must be a change in economic policy before it is too late.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. – This report concerns the European Parliament’s contribution to the definition of economic policy priorities for the 2016 European Semester process of policy coordination, responding to the Commission’s Annual Growth Survey and related documents, including a draft recommendation for the economic policy of the euro area. In parallel, reports on the employment and social aspects and the single market aspects of the European Semester are also being drawn up. These reports are discussed with the Commission and the Council in preparation for the Spring European Council meeting. The present report aims to stimulate debate at European level, also with the involvement of national parliamentarians, social partners and civil society. It is my view that in the current economic circumstances the ‘virtuous triangle’ of fiscal responsibility and structural reform, promoted by the European Commission, should be enlarged into a ‘solid square’, with domestic demand as the fourth component. There is also a clear need for higher investment. Furthermore, there is an excess of savings not channelled towards the real economy.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. – The 2016 Annual Growth Survey, which is under discussion and which launches the annual cycle of economic governance, has significant weaknesses this year, much to the disappointment of all concerned. Based on the data from the Commission's winter forecast, on which the programme is based, the priorities of the 2016 Annual Growth Survey are the promotion of investment, the implementation of structural reforms and sustainable fiscal consolidation. It is clear that Europe is still in a difficult economic situation, a fact that has a negative impact on the development of the budgets of the individual Member States. For example, average public debt relative to gross domestic product is still far too high in many Member States. The same applies to the average unemployment rate, which is higher at 9.2 and 10.6 percent, respectively, than in the United States, for example, at just under five percent. There are negative outliers, especially in Greece, Spain, Cyprus and Croatia. Despite billions of investments by the ECB and a large number of coordinating and regulatory measures by the Commission, Europe's economy is not really picking up. Many Member States remain a long way from the requirements of the Stability and Growth Pact.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. – The EU presents economic governance as the appropriate framework in which to set economic policy priorities. If it does not deliver the expected results, it is because governance should be "complemented" with social elements that would enable the improvement of the living conditions of the European people's classes. This is a perverse wording that seeks to deny the fundamental opposition between liberalisation, commodulation and deregulation of the European economy through technocratic mandates and the possibility of maintaining a strong state and collective bargaining on which to base the defence of social rights. A strategy of legitimacy that excuses the effects of neoliberal policies while developing a future (and unconcrete) social pillar for the single market, while continuing to institutionalize European governance outside of any democratic control. The basis for a European social policy is elsewhere: in the obligation to join the European Charter of Human Rights, references to the European Social Charter, European social dialogue or the establishment of European rules against social dumping, all areas in which the EU maintains its immobility.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – The European Semester should be a moment of reflexion on what does not work in the European Union and what we have to pursue in the coming period to resolve it. We see a Europe that is having difficulties recovering from the crisis. The slow economic growth is still affecting employment, and the lack of investment is affecting the entrepreneurial potential in a lot of European countries. Europe is even more unequal than ever before, the future of young Europeans is affected for ever, and no solutions seem to be found. The promised leverage mechanism of the European Fund for Strategic Investment is not there. With only a five-point multiplication effect we are far from the target. Europe needs a new hope, a new dynamism. We are acting as fixers, not as solution makers, we are not doing prevention at all and we are incapable of delivering quality results. Our solution, as social democrats, is to start reconnecting with our citizens, with our SMEs, with our town/villages, to find there the resources that can make Europe great again. We have the strength, we simply need the will.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – A strong and stable EU economy has at its heart active citizens with access to opportunities for employing their professional and creative potential. I therefore welcome the inclusion of employment indicators in this year’s Annual Growth Survey. Activity rate, long-term unemployment and youth unemployment are very much needed as integral elements of the scoreboard, as they would allow us to track progress on key elements of employment. We are currently observing a positive trend of increasing employment and activity, whereby the overall EU employment rate has even reached its pre-crisis level. However, regional disparities remain and much more progress is needed to reach the employment target of 75% that the EU set itself for 2020. The means for achieving this goal are also anchored in the AGS, which underlined the importance of the use of funds under Horizon 2020 and the newly-created EFSI. Unfortunately, these instruments are not sufficiently understandable and applicable for the European citizens. If we are to fulfil our ambitions for a growing and thriving Europe, we must really enable people with professional drive to engage in employment and self-employment. EFSI and Horizon 2020 must therefore really serve the interests of the economy and be made more accessible to citizens. This is how we will start creating employment.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. – Although unemployment in Europe is gradually decreasing, up to 23 million active people remain unemployed. There is one number that I find even scarier, and that is 123 million Europeans at risk or affected by poverty and social exclusion. It is therefore necessary that The Member States do not overlook this problem. There must no longer be a headless drawdown of every euro from the UNION budget. On the contrary, we must, above all, ensure that investments go to the areas that require them most and where they bring the greatest added value. The Youth Employment Initiative can serve as an example in this respect. I do not want to tolerate any further widening the gap between the populations of the poorest and richest regions, because this will only bring further instability to the European continent in the long term. But the problem of European unemployment is far deeper than choosing the right investments from European or national budgets. It is necessary to coordinate policy correctly not only in the context of national negotiations, but also at the highest European level. I would therefore like to push for joint meetings of the Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Protection Council with the Economic and Financial Affairs Council. Tearing down the wall between the two formations can help create quality jobs and distribute wealth more equitablely.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: in writing. – Europe has not yet emerged from the economic crisis, and the disastrous situation today is due both to the crisis and to past decisions at EU level. They did not provide a sufficient degree of economic protection for the common market. The key to economic return is the internal market, and the demand in this market exists and is high enough, only it is not us, the Europeans, who meet this demand. Products are imported into the European area from all continents of the world and, at the same time, all European states are diminishing their own monetary reserves by paying for these purchases, of course, to the detriment of Community production. Let us not forget those industries in European countries that no longer exist and which have disappeared as a result of a hostile economic environment in Europe. The key to intra-Community economic growth is protection, namely European Economic Protection. This protection must first ensure the preservation of the resources and values that the Union still has and, as a secondary object, ensure those mixes of economic and social policies that give Member States sufficient sovereignty to defend themselves against threats of an economic or social nature.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I invite you to vote in favour of this report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination, which focuses on employment and social aspects in the context of the 2016 Annual Growth Review.  While the economic forecasts for 2016 are encouraging, it is clear that unemployment levels are still very high in the European Union, especially among young people. If I am in favour of coordinating economic policies in Europe, I support the idea that the social objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy are better integrated into the European Semester. It is on this basis that we must coordinate economic policies in Europe.  In particular, I call on you to call through this report for "a strengthening of the role of the Europe 2020 strategy" and by calling for "social objectives to be reflected equally in all the instruments of the Semester, including the country-specific recommendations". More than ever, we must coordinate our economic policies in order to improve the social conditions of all European citizens.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Writing. Every year, when it comes to the European Semester, there is the same discussion here. We Social Democrats want the direction to be changed. We want to move away from a one-sided policy of cuts towards a balanced economic and financial policy. It is one-sided to say that Europe has a competition problem and that increased competitiveness automatically leads to more growth. Flexibility yes, but not one-sided ones, which is only at the expense of the workers. Even more so-called zero-hours contracts or other precarious forms of employment do not solve the problem. It only leads to rising poverty despite work. It leads people to turn away from Europe. The European Semester lacks social indicators, for example to combat poverty and social exclusion. In short, we need a change of direction now. Unless it is gradually shown that social triple A is serious for Europe, we will lose to Eurosceptics, anti-Europeans and fascists. That is why we have repeated the mantra that we Social Democrats have been repeating for years: social and employment policy must be just as binding as economic and financial policy.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. – I support the report's emphasis that the need to invest in social development is not only a means of ensuring sustainable and inclusive economic development and convergence, but must also constitute a specific objective in itself.  We need investment in housing support, healthcare, childcare and rehabilitation services. As the report rightly covers, quality and inclusive jobs are an essential pillar of social justice that promotes human dignity for all.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. – The European Union is currently in its third year of economic recovery, with a decrease in the unemployment rate, but not significant enough to limit poverty and unemployment, given that 23 million Europeans, representing 9.9% of active citizens, still do not have a job. The growth forecast in the European Union for 2016 is 2% but it remains uneven between Member States. In this respect, a strategy is needed to ensure sustainable growth, particularly in the context of economic and financial turbulence in some emerging economies, leading to new strategic challenges to the European Union.  Moreover, a large proportion of Member States face structural problems. It is therefore necessary to continue to attach importance to public and private investment, as well as to socially and economically balanced reforms. In addition, Member States need to increase the coverage and effectiveness of active policies in the area of labour market stimulus.  I would also like to stress the need for greater attention to the EU's peripheral regions, especially the least developed ones, in order to bridge the gap and strengthen cohesion at European level.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The EP Report on the annual growth survey and the European Semester 2016 marks a turning point in the prevailing thinking at the European forum for the representation of European citizens. The report rejects the austerity model and is committed to economic and social policy coordination which refers to the Europe 2020 Strategy for Growth and Jobs. It advocates strengthening investment and domestic demand. It advocates 'second generation' structural reforms to strengthen growth potential by focusing on education and innovation, the sustainability of the social model, the modernisation of public administration and a fair and equitable tax system. It also supports a new eurozone management model that brings it closer to an optimal monetary area, easing it with its own instruments in the framework of economic and monetary union. It is a historical report whose recommendations need to be made.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on Heinz K. Becker's report, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the European Employment Services Network, workers' access to mobility services and further integration of labour markets (A8-0224/2015).

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, representative of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. With the EURES report on the European Network of Labour Market Administrations and Labour Market Mediators, we have before us an EU regulation for the vote, which, after eleven intensive trilogue rounds, has succeeded in a highly constructive spirit on the part of all the groups in this House and, at the same time, the Commission under the Luxembourg Presidency, which will have a lasting effect on European labour markets for a longer period of time. While many regions in Europe are characterised by high unemployment, two million jobs remain vacant elsewhere because of a lack of skilled labour on the ground. The EURES Internet platform can ensure very easy access to hundreds of thousands of vacant jobs across Europe from the very first stage of development. As a result, many more jobs will be offered, with up to 1.4 million jobs available. EURES is thus a massive promotion of labour mobility, which is currently only 3% in Europe. More people should work in another country. We have worked very intensively in Parliament on the Commission's initiative to reform the EURES regulation through a new EURES platform and optimise it with efficiency and innovation, and we have wrapped Up Parliament's priorities in almost 700 amendments and over 40 compromises, which were then negotiated in the trialogue for the joint result. In this context, I would like to express my thanks to the competent round of shadow rapporteurs and their assistants, as well as to the professional EMPL secretariat, as well as to our active advisers to my own and to the other groups, not least To Mrs Ulvskog as sovereign chairman. I would therefore also like to mention the soft values, which are not unimportant when a result is achieved. A spirit of cooperation has emerged, together with the Commission's leader and the Council team. Without lazy compromises, the quality of the new EURES regulation, a strong instrument for promoting worker mobility and thus also to reduce unemployment in the EU, could finally be made clear. We were able to enshrine the following key points of the regulation by common accord: in addition to the public labour market administrations, private employment intermediaries are also on board. Together, they feed the hundreds of thousands and, later, even more vacant, vacant jobs in all the Member States. And there has never been so much support for people, especially young people, with THE easy-to-use and accessible Internet platform of EURES if they want to find work in another country in Europe because they are not able to do so in their home country. And every job seeker has been able to post their application documents online with ease, and their CV can be viewed by all worker-seeking companies from anywhere. With EURES, job seekers receive support not only on the internet platform, but also personally, through 850 best-trained EURES consultants in all EU countries. The path of every job seeker to his new job will be completely free. Most importantly, we have also succeeded in convincing the Commission and the Council that the active role of the social partners in the EURES construction is not only safeguarded, but even strengthened. Why, in fact? There is a clear answer to this: in a modern European labour market, the interests of workers and employers must be fully guaranteed. And another success of our negotiations: as part of the redesign, the cross-border models, which have already been recognised as successful, were explicitly and comprehensively anchored and given access to EaSI. As Members of this House, you can therefore vote in favour of the new EURES regulation with complete conviction, including as an achievement of this European Parliament.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank Parliament for its support and the rapporteur, Mr Becker, and also the chair of the trilogue, for working so competently. I would also like to thank the entire negotiating team for their efforts and constructive approach. The new EURES Regulation is part of our broader policy to help people into a job and to facilitate the exercise of the freedom of movement of workers within the European Union. EURES is much more than a mobility portal. It is essentially a human network that provides support to jobseekers and employers across Europe, and it is key to addressing high unemployment rates and skills mismatches. Of course, while discussing labour mobility, it is important to ensure that this does not become a one—way street and does not result in a brain drain in some countries, especially new Member States. There are more than 22 million people unemployed in the European Union today, and yet there are 2 million unfilled vacancies advertised. It is clear that we can, and must, do more to help people into jobs and to help employers to find the workers they need, within the Member States but also across borders. This is precisely what the EURES Regulation is about. Therefore, the Commission welcomes the timely agreement of the co-legislators. Already today, the pan-European job search network, with its 34 European public employment services, is working successfully. For more than 20 years EURES has helped people to find jobs in another Member State through its web portal and its network of 1 000 advisers across the Union. The new regulation builds on this work and strengthens EURES further for the future. So what are the main improvements? More jobs will be advertised and there will be more effective automated online matching between the specific qualifications of job searchers and the skill requirements of specific vacancies, a broader network open to more members and partners and an agreed minimum package of services to jobseekers and to employers in all Member States. It is good that the EURES network will open up further to more members and partners, also including private employment services. We need to work together across silos and exploit synergies to be most effective. At the same time, those who join must be serious, reliable labour market actors and must be committed to building a responsible partnership within the network. With the new member organisation, EURES should also become better known, since today too many job seekers and employers are simply not aware of its potential. Members may want to promote its existence within their constituencies, in particular in regions with high unemployment or high skills shortages, or in border regions where the EURES network can, for example, provide information on concrete social security or labour law questions that potential border workers are often confronted with. EURES is indeed more than a pan—European job search tool. Through its network across the Union it can advise and assist in finding a job or a worker and give guidance on the many practical questions that still arise in the context of labour mobility. Whereas today the services offered vary a lot among the Member States, the regulation ensures that a minimum package of support services will be available everywhere. The Council is expected to adopt the new regulation on 15 March. In the meantime, preparations with representatives of the Member States of the EURES network have started to ensure successful application of these rules as from the day of entry into force. Within two years we will report on the state of play to Parliament and the Council, as well as to the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: Rapporteur for REGI opinion. – Madam President, every day more than 1.1 million European citizens living in a Union country cross borders to go to work in a neighbouring country. In this context, the Eures Labour Mobility Portal is a unique opportunity for jobseekers. The European Parliament supports an update on the functioning of Eures and its harmonisation with the evolution of society at European level. I believe that there is a need for national and cross-border structures to have sufficient staff and resources to carry out their work, including staff training programmes.  At the same time, this reform must enable public employment services to lay the foundations for closer cooperation with educational and training bodies, in particular with regard to continuous training, including for people over 40 years of age, in order to enable the development of skills and for the use of information and communication technologies intelligently.

name: David CASA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I would like to start by thanking Mr Heinz Becker for his excellent work on this dossier. Freedom of movement is one of the four basic freedoms on which the EU is founded and creates opportunities for both workers and companies and increases employment rates. However, we are still facing endemic mass unemployment, which places upon us the responsibility to improve labour mobility within the EU, not only by creating new opportunities but also by filling vacancies effectively to develop the European labour market, as the EU 28 mobility rate currently stands at a low of 0.29%. One method of encouraging employment and creating human capital is by not only reinforcing every EU citizen’s fundamental right of free movement but also removing possible obstacles which may obstruct intra-EU labour mobility throughout the Union. This is where EURES will aid in filling these vacancies. The EURES database will help promote mobility and make the process of obtaining jobs in other Member States much simpler. I believe that regulating and enhancing the EURES network with the European classification tool will present more opportunities to fill job vacancies across EU borders.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I hope it will not seem grandiose if I suggest that this quite long technical piece of legislation might be a microcosm of the European Union as a whole. In the first case, the process by which we arrived at this piece of work was collaborative, it was sensible, it was admirably led by the rapporteur, Mr Becker, and I learned a lot as a British socialist about where the centre of gravity in this Union lies. It lies in a very liberal, sensible, social place. Social partnership was easily woven throughout this piece of legislation as it could never have been in the UK. It is free to workers throughout, there was no controversy with other political partners, and cherry-picking by the private sector was as abhorrent to our PPE colleagues in this process as it was to us, which it would never have been back in the UK. I think the whole of our proceedings very often mirror this experience. It was also long, dull, dry, technical and difficult to explain to other people, but actually rather important and meaningful, and in that sense too it mirrors the work that we do as a whole in this place and in these institutions. Finally, in what is only ever two minutes, this is an instrument which did not use to work at all, but which thanks to this legislation has been fundamentally revised and in future will, I think, work very well and will improve access to jobs and work for hundreds of millions of people across the Union in a very productive and beneficial way.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: for the ECR Group. – Let me thank the rapporteur, Mr Becker, thanks to which we have today a very balanced proposal that has the ambition to improve the services that Eures provides, while also giving Member States the space to keep undisclosed posts, which are, for example, part of an active labour market policy agenda. However, I must say at the outset that my wish – and I think that the wishes of many of us – are that the citizens of the European Union find application, especially in their Member States, as this is often a sign that the situation on the labour market is working, that the country is doing well, that they are not forced to leave their families for long periods of time by going abroad to work. On the other hand, however, there will always be a proportion of citizens who live close to the borders, for example, or simply people who desire and need foreign experience for their work. Such an experience helps, improves language skills, helps the transfer of skills, but also personal development, and thus ultimately enriches us all. It is therefore desirable that we can support these workers, make it easier for them to find vacancies and help them to navigate the labour market. It is also important to me personally that we have found broad agreement during the negotiations, and the proposal does not forget the principles of non-discrimination, and the EURES portal will also be available to people with disabilities. I believe that the improved EURES will be an instrument of very concrete and practical assistance, both for jobseekers and employers, and that we will be able to bring it to the attention of the widest possible public. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. I agree with you that it is not necessarily necessary to merely facilitate movement between countries, but it would also make sense to achieve something at regional level in relation to EURES. At the same time, we run into the problem of not having information in all 24 languages at the same time. So if you are at home, in many cases you may be at a disadvantage compared to a foreign worker. How would you think to deal with this problem?

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – I think that, even during our negotiations, which we also conducted in the trilogue, but also in the debate between the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs, we have tried precisely to remove all barriers that could prevent people from applying for jobs in another Member State of the European Union. So I believe that the portal itself, but also the accompanying services that should accompany these jobseekers, will allow even those who may not know the language of the country to access the information they need to find the job.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: on the alde group. – I would like to thank the rapporteur, Heinz Becker, and all the shadow rapporteurs for their really excellent cooperation. The negotiations on the final form of the report took quite a long time, and I myself have tabled more than 100 amendments. We must also thank the Luxembourg Presidency, which has a great deal to do in finding a final agreement. We now have the EURES portal, which meets the current requirements of the labour market and can be an effective tool to promote employment and mobility. A great success is the extension of the portal to the positions for trainees and apprentices or the involvement of offers from private employers and private recruitment agencies. For many of us, the opportunity to dream of working abroad, to choose a job abroad, moreover from the comfort of our own home, for many years was completely unaffordable and unimaginable. Today, free movement of labour is one of the greatest advantages of the European Union, and yet labour mobility in the EU is still ten times lower than in the United States. I believe that the new EURES will be the right impetus to kick-start a new approach by Europeans to work abroad, especially among young people. I believe that the modernised EURES portal is one of the right ways to remove barriers and solve labour market problems across Europe. We owe it to our young people.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, first of all, thank Mr Becker for his work. It's been very interesting working with him. It is more than a year since we started talking in this Parliament about recasting the European Employment Services Network. The Commission proposed to us to set up a tailored network of private employment services to promote forced migration of unemploymenty Europeans.  Fortunately, what we have built among all has been something very different: a network that will have to support the fair mobility of workers, with the full participation of social actors and a central role for public employment services. But we know there's a lot to do. Mobility will not be fair if neoliberal policies are implemented that push millions of Europeans into forced migration, further denying them recognition of social rights and expelling European workers residing in another country.  Commissioner, mobility cannot be defended and at the same time, together with the Governments of the European Union, the UNITED Kingdom's attack on the fundamental right to the free movement of workers and the strengthening of fierce competition in the single market cannot be endorsed at the same time. That, of course, is not the way.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, first of all I would also like to thank our rapporteur, Mr Becker, my colleagues, our shadows, and obviously the representatives of the Luxembourg Presidency. We need to thank all of them because basically, as my colleague Mr Simon has already mentioned, their constructive attitude and benevolent flexibility meant that we were able to first work out the compromises in Parliament and then come to the reasonably early reading agreement which is in front of us. Believe me, I come from a Member State called Hungary. I can value flexibility and willingness to compromise in politics. I do not want to claim any specific merit for the Greens, but I would like to highlight two things that I think we have been slightly instrumental in putting into the legislation. We believe that EURES advisers should play an important role, providing personalised support to jobseekers, in order to ensure that they can make informed decisions when looking for, or taking up, a job abroad. We also have to modify and improve the original text to ensure that all users have equal access to the services without discrimination, and that data protection provisions are observed. Thank you very much for your attention and for the flexibility which I mentioned before.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, many people in the UK will not have heard of EURES, but they might remember the story that hit the headlines about a website that advertises UK jobs across the entire EU. As an MEP I am regularly contacted by people who are desperate for work and desperate to support their families, but who – even after years of searching – have failed. I do not believe this is because every single unemployed Brit is lazy or unqualified, as some politicians say. So why does the British Government support a strengthened and expanded policy which allows every man and his dog to apply for jobs in the UK? It means that job centres in the UK are now legally obliged to advertise any vacancies they have to half a billion people. Let me get one thing straight: this legislation has not been written for the benefit of the working person; it has been written for the benefit of big business. Open-door immigration is a policy which has driven down wages in the UK, and this is backed up by the GMB Union. The minimum wage has become the maximum wage, and British taxpayers are now subsidising low salaries which employers can get away with thanks to the over-supply in the labour market. The government’s support for this expansion of EURES and the obligation for all Member States to post jobs on the website was just a cynical attempt to make it look like the proportion of UK jobs advertised was smaller in comparison to other countries, but figures show that one third of the vacancies advertised on ‘Your first EURES job’ were placements in Britain. 1 178 unemployed people from across the EU took jobs or training in Britain, yet only 25 Britons under 30 found jobs. I do not believe we should be exporting jobs to other EU Member States, and we certainly should not be paying GBP 55 million a day into an organisation that tells us we must. I hope British voters realise what this government and the EU are doing ahead of the referendum in June, when I believe we can get our country back and put British people first. (The speaker declined to take a blue-card question from Mr Siôn Simon)

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the issue of the EURES platform, the European employment services network, continues on its way. In doing so, the negatives appear more clearly behind the apparently positive motives of the proposal, namely the transparency of the labour market, the technological leap of networks - with automatic matching of offers and CVs - associated with new services, or the increased coordination of exchanges between Member States. But, de facto, this allows, through what you humorously call "areas of shortage or over-labour", to reveal a hidden major danger: that of clearly indicating to potential economic competitors the areas of strength or weakness of Europe. Because the holding of categorical targeted listings by private and public law bodies can be understood at the level of the Member States, but at European level it is a major economic weapon in addition to being a pervasive surveillance tool.  It is therefore at the state level and through targeted international partnerships that trade can be made in favour of workers chosen for their skills and who move freely.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – In the European Union, there are 8 million workers who do not work in their own country and 25 million are unemployed. The EURES employment and mobility portal, which we will now decide to reform, can also help in their search for a job, but let us ask the question: what is the single EU market in this area? We could only talk about a fair labour market and mobility if the huge income gap between the peripheral and centre countries were reduced. For example, in Hungary, the monthly income of a shop assistant is EUR 350, the same in neighbouring Austria is EUR 1200, in the same network of shops. The large number of people in Central and Eastern Europe go to western Europe to work not because they live with this freedom as self-conscious EU citizens, but because they are driven from their home countries by economic constraints.

name: Anne SANDER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, tomorrow we are voting on a new regulation to strengthen and develop the European job search network EURES. Finally, we offer this instrument the means of its ambitions.  EURES is no longer an empty shell. Thanks to a revitalized web portal that is accessible to all, EURES will make life easier for our European workers and employers. EURES is also committed to apprentices by relaying apprenticeship offers. And in the border areas, I am pleased that EURES is encouraging the creation of partnerships capable of providing information and support to border workers.  Now I would say that the ball is in the Member States' court. It is up to them to encourage public employment services to improve the website and it is up to them to promote this tool on the ground.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the EURES benefits all Europeans, including the British. I am glad that border partnerships have been strengthened. That was not always the aim of the Council and the Commission. In my EaSI report, there were plans to weaken the Commission. However, it is precisely the consultation work of genuine border partnerships with the social partners that is extremely important – in employment services, but also in cross-border employment relationships, employees and employers need advice. We have such different tax and social security directives, which makes working across borders very difficult. Fortunately, it has also been achieved that any cross-border structure cannot use this work for profit, then be able to make it available for remuneration, so that European funds cannot be called up for such purposes. This is also important to us that basic services continue to be provided free of charge. It has finally been possible for all job advertisements within the network to be advertised, and to do so in a binding manner.

name: Laura AGEA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank Mr Becker: you have demonstrated with the availability of this year's work the precise will to put content inside a container, because EURES was a container devoid of content and, above all, lacking the need for use, for immediate information, which is fundamental to tackling the problem of unemployment and the problem of employment. So I was really happy to be able to work with her. You have shown that this Parliament, when it is necessary to give concrete answers, can work at 360 degrees and aim for results, content and truly effective results. So thank you and you will have our support tomorrow in the vote.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The reform of the EURES network sends a positive signal and offers hope to improve the process of exchanging information between countries on the needs of local markets and available job vacancies and job seekers. I find it particularly positive to see changes aimed at providing more personalised career and recruitment advice, providing practical assistance in finding work and hiring workers, and providing workers and employers with information on social security, taxes and relevant legislation in the various Member States.  The obligation to effectively promote and promote networks to employers and workers, imposed on the Commission as well as on the Member States, is also important. The EURES network will never work effectively unless the public and private employment services are fully involved. Let us hope that initiatives such as EURES will, albeit in part, offset the negative effects of recent actions leading to the creation of new barriers to the free movement of European Union workers. Heinz, thank you and the counter-rapporteurs for their excellent work.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: – Thank you to the rapporteur, Mr President. For Becker, for good work, because in fact, with this regulation, we are seeking to strengthen the EURES platform and make it a truly effective tool for those interested in the movement of labour within the European Union. And one of the most important improvements is to increase transparency by allowing more job vacancies to be reviewed in one place at European level. And it is very important that this network also aims to include apprenticeships and traineeships, but certainly provided that they are subject to a normal employment relationship. All jobseekers must therefore be able to obtain detailed information on working conditions at that place of work. I am pleased that the negotiations on this regulation have succeeded in strengthening the role of the social partners in the network, so that we have made it easier for both workers and employers to obtain the information needed for recruitment. It is also essential that the basic services of the EURES network are free of charge for the jobseeker and therefore more accessible to them.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – First of all, of course, all congratulations to becker's colleagues for their very good work. We have a very good proposal in front of us, which we will easily support.  The European Employment Services Network will make a significant contribution to speeding up the coordination of job supply and demand throughout the European Union. Vacancies will be open and accessible to all. That's very good. It is also of paramount importance for jobseekers that private agencies and NGOs can be included in the new network in addition to public employment services. I think that this will also help us reduce unemployment among the most vulnerable groups.  In any case, I, too, support all my colleagues who say that special attention should be paid to apprenticeships and traineeships. I am convinced, of course, that EURES will also have a positive impact on increasing intra-EU mobility.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – First of all, I would like to thank my colleague Becker for his work on the EURES report.  The resulting text, which was supported by a large majority in the EMPL vote, clearly shows that it is a solid text and deserved this support.
