I am also glad that amendments have been adopted, including an amendment that I have tabled in the sense of applicants who meet the requirements and criteria for granting authorisation so that a Member State issues this authorisation. So that there is no doubt as to whether the authorization can be issued. I am therefore very pleased with this clear definition in the report.  I also welcome the fact that this labour market policy remains fully within the competence of the Member States, so subsidiarity is respected and, of course, the lowest bureaucratic burden and good implementation must be sought. I therefore welcome the statement by the Commissioner, who has promised to monitor implementation and report on this. Thank you all for your good work.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: – Facilitating the mobility of workers in the European Union can certainly be seen as a positive step by which they can effectively and flexibly tackle inequalities in the labour market.  But it also has its flip side. Unfortunately, with huge differences in wage levels between countries, there is an outflow of skilled workers from poorer European countries to richer ones. This causes huge problems in some sectors. I will mention, for example, health care, where there is an acute shortage of health professionals in countries where there are better conditions and thus the availability of health care is directly threatened.  Public universities will provide education here, but their graduates will soon leave the country. Is the solution for these countries to import health professionals from even poorer parts of the world? Is this a sustainable model of the European labour market? I don't think so. However, this is not a EURES problem.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, there is more hypocrisy and bilingualism in the European Union. While we are discussing the EURES programme, which aims to contribute to the mobility of workers within the European Union and to help the citizens of the Member States to look for work in another Member State of the Union, at the same time as the Brexit arrangements, the Heads of State or Government of the Union have decided to drastically restrict the rights of all migrant workers.  Rights a source of their employment relations relating to tax exemptions, housing, marriage, children and so on. This means discrimination against the union's migrant citizens vis-à-vis the citizens of the host Countries.  Thus, with the signature of Tsipras, more than four hundred thousand Greeks, young scientists and other workers who emigrated to work in Britain, Germany, France and other countries of the Union, will suffer a new social racism. They left Greece because of a troika and a memorandum, and now Merkel and the Merkelists, with the consent of the SYRIZA/ANEL co-government, are imposing a new memorandum that reduces their salaries and makes them second-class citizens.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Dear President, we need greater mobility within the European Union, only 3% of Europeans work in another EU country.  We have 2 million jobs that can be filled, and we have huge unemployment in a number of soot countries. That is why I strongly support the EURES platform: I am convinced that in this way, in the way of new technologies, we can solve our problems very well in many countries and enable many citizens to reach their jobs. Today we have a situation that the European Union, on the one hand, needs work, on the other hand, people are looking for work. Public employment services, private agencies through this compound can really provide better happiness for many individuals and many families.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – I would also like to point out that 1.1 million EU citizens currently apply a cross-border form of work. Also, that 7 million EU citizens are employed in other EU Member States. That's, I think, very important.  I think it shows precisely the values that need to be mentioned at this time, and that is therefore the freedom of establishment and the freedom of work guaranteed by the EU's fundamental four freedoms. This also implies a number of stimulating criteria that can be valued, and that is GDP growth. On the other hand, what my colleague Sehnalová said is really true, and that is the outflow of skilled forces. This, too, must be dealt with by the Member States, which must then, to some extent, combat this value in their legal systems.  For me, it is important that EURES has been reformed and reformed in a way that further applies greater involvement of skilled labour in the labour market.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, a strengthened and better—known EURES network with a broader scope, a wider range of support services and a modern IT platform that allows for better, automated matching of profiles will be a powerful instrument. It will make it easier for job seekers to expand their job search in other Member States and it will give employers access to a wider pool of talent. It will facilitate, on the ground, the exercising of free movement by workers. The strength of any network always depends first and foremost on its members. This is no different in the case of EURES. The Commission is committed to continuing to support the network, to helping it develop and to making best use of the tools that the new regulation puts at its disposal. I hope that we can count on Parliament’s continued support in our doing so.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to revisit those aspects which have perhaps proved to be clear in the speeches. In particular, I would like to point out that the EURES regulation has explicitly taken up the current discussion on two different points. Firstly, the free movement of workers in Europe is emphasised, confirmed and called for, including in the EURES report. The second is that it calls for all discrimination – and this is the first priority – to be not permitted on the grounds of citizenship and all other criteria. I believe that among the contributions of our colleagues, it was very important to learn that there is also a significant contribution for disabled people and that traineeships and traineeships have also been given a strong priority. We paid extra attention to this. Let me conclude by making two requests, these are not demands, but we will repeat them very explicitly: one request goes to the Council to motivate the EU Member States not to wait until the last moment of the two-year period for EURES to be implemented. The citizens of each country deserve to be perfectly familiarised with EURES by their government. The second request goes to the Commission to also encourage the Council to develop targeted communication work for EURES. EURES already existed, but EURES was not so well known, it must now be announced! I am pleased that prominent representatives of the Commission from the negotiations are represented here. To a common success.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday, 25 February 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. – The free choice of jobs within the Union is one of the four fundamental freedoms of the European Union. Every day, around 1.1 million EU citizens cross the border because they work in a neighbouring country. In addition, some 7 million European citizens lived and worked in other Member States in 2013. High unemployment in some regions of Europe has led to the recognition of the need to strengthen labour mobility within the Union. This will contribute to the development of a European labour market with a high level of employment, as the 0.29% rate of labour mobility in the EU is relatively low in relation to the size of the labour market and the active population of the EU. The purpose of this Regulation is to transform the EURES network into an effective tool for jobseekers/employers by creating the largest database of job vacancies and job seeker profiles. I support the need to including practical training and traineeship places in a Europe-wide network. I propose to introduce an appropriate exchange of general information on intra-Union mobility in the field of apprenticeships and traineeships, which should be recognised in the same way as diplomas issued by the ordinary education system of the Member States. The reform should enable public employment services to laid the foundations for closer cooperation with educational and vocational training institutions, in particular in the field of further training, extending this to the over-40s, enabling the use of information and communication technologies.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. – The European economy needs to constantly strengthen the foundations of its economy, such as the labour economy, which has been under strain in recent years, so much so that, far from being an asset for growth, it shows a flank vulnerable to economic crises. One of the prerequisites for its return to development is the degree of effectiveness attributable to the freedom of movement of workers themselves, which, it is sad to note, is still low at present. In my question of February 2015, I denounced the lack of knowledge of the EURES platform by workers, employers and the Member States themselves, to the extent that this critical issue, combined with the lack of good practice of having exchange of information on labour shortages and surpluses, undermines what should be termed 'the European Employment Service' which I consider to be a duty of the European institutions. In response to my call for greater accuracy of forecasting models and greater interoperability of data between national portals, the Commission stated in response in June 2015 that the cooperation of national systems is necessary. Indeed, overcoming regulatory barriers and legal obstacles is the greatest challenge, in order to make the freedom of movement of workers effective and real.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – The importance of the EURES network and employment mobility portal, which has more than two decades of history, has grown even further in the light of the crisis, as mobility within the EU opens the door to new employment opportunities, thereby helping to reduce unemployment. The problem of mass unemployment in certain areas of the Union can be tackled by the mobility of workers. EURES supports workers and employers in exploiting the opportunities offered by the principle of the free movement of persons. EURES and public employment services in the Member States consider it their mission to contribute to the balance between supply and demand in the labour market and to ensure easy access for employers, workers and recruitment firms to the local, national and European labour market. The report mentions a number of points aimed at increasing the effectiveness of EURES, while stressing that employment policies fall within the competence of the Member States. Most of the proposals mentioned in the proposal (e.g. to include TRAINEESHIPS in EURES, to provide all jobseekers with full information on employment conditions in the country where the job in question is located, the EURES platform should be as user-friendly as possible) express valuable ideas that can make an effective contribution to reducing unemployment in the Union.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I am pleased that an interinstitutional agreement on the EURES instrument has been reached in the trilogue process. I am of the opinion that a new directive re-establishing this instrument, if implemented swiftly in the Member States, will allow for a new dynamic of interregional cooperation in the field of recruitment. The European Union has been facing not only unemployment for several years, but also, on the other hand, vacancies in some areas of the economy. The European Network of Employment Services in a new, strengthened form has the potential to facilitate the recruitment of staff from different Member States. The network will be set up by both public employment services and the social partners, which will have the same minimum criteria. I believe that this is a good basis for cooperation. Furthermore, I am pleased that the issues of labour mobility in cross-border areas have been identified and clarified. In fact, it is a group of workers who face slightly different problems, which requires special attention and often separate solutions. I therefore consider the creation of separate cross-border partnerships within EURES to be a good solution.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – I see the free choice of jobs within the Union as an integral part of the right to free movement under the four fundamental freedoms of the European Union, which is an important element of EU citizenship, which is otherwise in danger of being put at risk by the current migrant crisis. Today, there are 23 million unemployed people in the EU and one in five young people have no job. Despite rumours to the contrary, EU labour mobility in the EU is low compared to the size of the labour market and the EU's active population, but also compared to larger competitors (USA, Japan) – the MOBILITY rate of the EU-27 is only 0.29%. The regulation aims to transform the EURES network into an effective tool for jobseekers and employers, respecting member states' competences with regard to labour market regulation, which remained a national competence. My position is that employment problems should be reduced not by more non-EU and explicitly unsklined immigrants, but by strengthening the free employment of EU citizens. In this context, I believe that, with regard to filling vacancies, the Member States and the Commission should ensure that citizens of EU Member States take precedence when filling them, so that the principle of EU preference is also implemented.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – The free movement of workers is a fundamental principle of the Treaty enshrined in Article 45 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. In order to help workers to effectively exercise that right – to look for a job and to work in another EU country, enjoying the same treatment as the country´s nationals in terms of access to employment, working conditions and social benefits – we need to reinvigorate and adjust EURES. This cooperation network for labour mobility clearly showed some shortcomings such as limited support services and information exchange, as well as not sufficient cooperation and lack of transparency in labour markets. In this regard, I find essential the incorporation into the network of effective public and private employment services. It is important to widen to scope of information which is available on the portal, ensuring that all jobseekers can obtain comprehensive information about the existing vacancies and all related employment conditions. On the other hand the portal should facilitate the automated matching of job vacancies and CVs, which will allow employers to quickly find and recruit workers who have the right skills and qualifications. Reinvigorating EURES will be highly beneficial for the reduction of the unemployment rates and will contribute to a more integrated Union labour market.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: in writing. – Although the free movement of workers is a right reflected in the EU Treaties and that there are Member States with very high unemployment rates and others with a large number of vacancies, labour mobility is very low within the EU. Only 3% of the working population is economically active in another Member State and less than 25% of workers wishing to move to work in another country do so. This Regulation, in addition to ensuring a level playing field for persons with disabilities, will enable the main problems to be solved by facilitating the free movement of workers. We need to promote the European labour market and the possibilities it offers, such as those two million vacant jobs in the EU, as the EU integration process requires greater movement of workers between Member States. If we can get the EURES network to function as a true job search portal at European level, ensuring equal treatment of workers and employers regardless of where they are in the Union, we will be closer to achieving this.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I have repeatedly asked and called for the creation of a European information bank on traineeships and traineeships. I therefore strongly support the inclusion of apprenticeships and traineeships in the EURES network. In this context, I stress the need to provide comprehensive information for jobseekers or traineeships on the terms and conditions of employment and benefits related to potential work. In order for EURES to be a useful and effective tool for seeking a job or traineeship, it must be accessible to as wide an audience as possible. Therefore, it is necessary to ensure that it is user-friendly and properly promoted in the media.  It is also important to monitor the functioning of this tool so that any shortcomings can be corrected on an ongoing basis. I also propose the implementation of new initiatives aimed at creating a comprehensive information point on employment and the development of professional competences from the EURES portal. Information on language courses, conditions for m.in recognition of academic and professional qualifications or accommodation opportunities in a given country should be available on the EURES portal.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. In the name of the sacrosanct 'free movement', the EU wants to set up a structured cooperation network allowing all citizens to access all job offers. Parliament's proposal mentions, in bulk, the strengthening of cooperation between the Public Employment Services (SPE), the integration of non-public bodies, an improvement of EURES, the creation of a European coordination office...  Obvious problems are emerging: at the logistical level (linking offers and demands at a European level poses obvious problems, especially in times of crisis), at the financial level (linking offers and demands will be expensive) and especially at the human level because EURES, this "European employment hub", promotes blackmail to mobility , according to which an unemployed person would not want to work if he was not ready to take an offer in Europe, wherever it was.  Rather than institutionalising job inecarisation and uprooting, we should support SMEs, which account for 90% of jobs in Europe, and set the conditions for job creation in the Member States. An individual, not to the displeasure of the Commission, will always prefer to work close to home!

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: in writing. – If we measure our economies in GDP growth rates, then employment, especially among young people, is a matter for specific people and their future, not numbers and graphs. And specific young people value only concrete measures and results, and that is why I propose two concrete steps.  First: public-private employment services. In some countries, there are employment sites and services that do better than public employment services. About 80% of employment service funding is public. Employment is most effective with private investment. Business employs our young people and companies need to have a stronger voice and participation in the management of employment services.  Second: Erasmus for young entrepreneurs is the new employment for the young. But we need to change two things: global Erasmus in the US, China, Japan and elsewhere – young Europeans learning from the best entrepreneurs, then starting a business and employing more young people; budget corresponding to demand. The programme's funds by 2020 are only €55.3. 90% of the participating entrepreneurs are under the age of 40, and over 1/3 of them start their own business after participation.  In view of the above two proposals, I know that there is no law, regulation, directive or institution to serve as an excuse and justification.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – There is a fundamental difference between the basic principle of freedom to work anywhere in the EU and the reality in which this principle works. The European Union is increasingly fragmented, a union threatened both from the inside and from the outside by factors that lead to consistent obstacles to genuine mobility from the outset. The figures show that, out of 4 million monthly hits, the main labour mobility portal, EURES, generates about 50,000 hires a year. We must recognise that the main flow of labour mobility in the EU is from east to west. From 2005 to today, the number of Europeans working in a country other than their home country has increased by 60%, mainly against the background of EU enlargement.  I support the renovation of the EURES portal, I support the efficiency of mobility, but I want to draw attention to the clear need to report realistically to the phenomenon of internal migration in the EU. Most migrants do not use official channels to get to and work in another country, they may not have access to the internet, they may not have even heard of EURES. These people most need the support and protection of the EU.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. There is a need to improve workers' access to labour mobility support services in the European Union and to relaunch the European Employment Services Network (EURES).  Several shortcomings in my opinion: incomplete pool of job offers and resumes on the PORTAL EURES; Unequal access to service within the European Union; Limited capacity of the portal to reconcile job offers with resumes filed; Inadequate availability of support services; lack of exchange of information between Member States on labour shortages and surpluses.  The strengthening of EURES would make it easier to implement the instruments that the Commission is putting in place for employment, such as the Youth Guarantee Mechanism. It therefore does not seem appropriate to raise a reservation under the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. – Today we are talking about a very important topic of work. The conclusions drawn up on the basis of high unemployment in some European regions show that labour mobility in the EU should be strengthened in order to increase employment opportunities for workers and to provide employers with better and faster job vacancies. Member States should therefore establish national coordination centres to provide joint support and assistance to all organisations operating on their territory in support of cooperation with relevant organisations in other Member States, in particular in neighbouring Countries. Such coordination centres should, in particular, be entrusted with examining complaints and problems relating to job vacancies and of checking compliance aspects relating to voluntary and fair labour mobility within the Union. Let us not forget that increasing interdependence between labour markets requires closer cooperation between employment services, especially in border regions, in order to ensure the possibility of free movement for all workers in accordance with the principles of voluntary and fair labour mobility within the Union. This should, of course, be carried out throughout the Union and in accordance with the Treaties, without any discrimination. A common framework for cooperation between member states and the Commission should be established . This should build on the pooling of all job offers from across the EU and the possibility of applying for work through mediation for workers and employers. It is also necessary to define a common approach to the exchange of information and to the provision of personalised advisory services necessary to facilitate such cooperation.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. – The proposal for a regulation on Parliament's table aims to improve workers' access to services supporting labour mobility within the EU, thereby promoting fair mobility and ensuring better access to employment opportunities throughout the Union. The main instrument for this is the European Employment Services Network (EURES), which has around 900 consultants. However, it is clear that this instrument in its current form cannot encourage further equitable mobility patterns, in particular because of the size of the UNION workforce and the nature of the challenges of the current economic situation. This proposal responds, but it must be pointed out that, in addition to encouraging labour mobility, we must also provide support to those who have left their home country under economic duress and are doing work, sometimes underpaid and unfair to their qualifications. If there is AN EU funding to facilitate the mobility of European citizens, we must also find a way to help those who want to prosper again in their homeland.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The right to free movement of workers has already appeared in the Treaty of Rome of 1957. It is also guaranteed in Article 39 of the Consolidated Version of the Treaty establishing the European Community. It is estimated that more than 7 million European citizens lived and worked in another Member State in 2013, 78% of them active and 68% of them in employment. However, due to the financial crisis, the movement of labour within the Union has recently decreased by a third. In addition, there is a trend of a lack of qualified staff. In order to counteract the further effects of the evolving trend, on 2 December 2015 the Permanent Representatives Committee approved the agreement reached with the European Parliament on the re-establishment and reorganisation of the European Network of Employment Services (EURES). The aim in itself is to make the EURES network an effective tool for jobseekers or employers. In addition, overcoming barriers to mobility will increase employment access across the EU, facilitating job creation. Moreover, this employment network will contribute to combating unemployment by helping to better match labour market supply and demand. EURES is also expected to play an important role in providing specific information and services to employers and cross-border workers in European border regions. I am of the opinion that the idea of a unified market without major national borders is based on a high level of mutual trust and on the equivalence of regulatory systems.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the debate on: – the report by Marielle de Sarnez, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the introduction of exceptional autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia (COM(2015)0460-C8-0273// 2015-2015/0218(COD)) (A8-0013/2016) and the Commission statement: Opening negotiations on the EU-Tunisia FtA (2015/2791(RSP)).

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, dear Cecilia Malmstrom, I think this is an important debate that we have this evening. I'll be back in two minutes. First of all, I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs who have been fully involved in the last few weeks on this important issue not only for Tunisia, but also for Europe and for the idea we have of it.  You all know the Tunisian context, you all measure the progress Tunisia has made since the last Arab revolutions. It is basically one of the few countries that has succeeded in its democratic transition and has succeeded in establishing this democracy. He was rightly rewarded with the Nobel Peace Prize for Tunisian dialogue. That was entirely justified. Nevertheless, you all know what challenges this country faces. We all remember the terrorist attacks that hit Tunisia. The terrorists did not hit this country by chance, they hit it because Tunisia is succeeding and, in doing so, they have obviously damaged the economy: there is no more tourism, there is an unprecedented economic crisis, there is extremely high unemployment, especially among young people and young graduates , and there are all the questions obviously posed by the neighbourhood of Libya and perhaps tomorrow of Algeria. So we need Tunisia to succeed, and the European Union must help it succeed. It is the spirit that presides over the two texts that we will be talking about now. The first of these texts is very important. It has been presented by the Commission: these are emergency measures in favour of olive oil. I say it is important because it is about getting it done in practice. It is not just a question of talking, it is not about beautiful speeches, it is about being at the rendezvous of solidarity with Tunisia and Tunisians. What the Commission is proposing is quite timely, namely to increase not Tunisia's olive oil exports, but to increase quotas of zero-duty olive oil by 35,000 tonnes per year over two years, without exporting more olive oil from Tunisia. I give you a figure: we produce more than 1.4 million tonnes of olive oil in Europe. So you see that this proposal is very important for Tunisia, but is not likely to destabilize Europe. We have also obtained amendments that provide for measuring the effects of this mechanism after one year and, if there is a problem , which I do not believe, action will be taken. The second text refers to alecA, the free trade agreement with Tunisia. The first round of negotiations took place. Tomorrow we will adopt a resolution on which we have worked a great deal in our committee. Parliament's message is simple: it is not just a resolution that talks about trade and free trade; it is first of all a political resolution, a resolution that says our solidarity, our support for democracy, growth, the economy and jobs in Tunisia. This resolution sets the conditions for success. We are saying that, first, the agreement must be political; secondly, that this agreement be asymmetrical - first of all for Tunisia - and progressive; thirdly, that there be not only transparency, but also that Tunisians as a whole take ownership of this agreement, let them make it their business. That is why I am very pleased that we have had this dialogue with Tunisian parliamentarians in the European Parliament. It is very important to install it absolutely permanently. This agreement must serve Tunisia, it must serve all Tunisians and, at that time, we will meet our demand, namely to be with Tunisia and Tunisians.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Tunisia and the European Union have been close partners for a long time. Since 2012, the EU has been supporting the young Tunisian democracy via a privileged partnership which is not limited only to trade but encompasses a variety of other issues such as an intensification of a political dialogue and a significant increase in technical and financial assistance to Tunisia. Because it is, as the rapporteur said, very important to support this country where the democracy is fragile and weak and the situation is, as we all know, very difficult for the Tunisian people and the government. Twenty years after the signature of the Association Agreement between us and them, during which our bilateral trade has more than doubled, we are again at the beginning of a new process aiming to deepen our trade relations even further. It is my conviction – and recent citizens’ protests also demonstrate this – that Tunisia’s political success depends on its economic success. They go hand in hand. We have an obligation to support that. An openness to trade and investment can play an important role. So the negotiations for a Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area Agreement (DCFTA) represents one of the ways in which the EU can support the economic recovery of Tunisia. It will go hand in hand also with the reform process undertaken by Tunisia itself, and I was very happy to be in Tunisia earlier last fall to launch the negotiations of this DCFTA. We are aware, given the current fragile economic situation, that these negotiations are a major challenge for Tunisia. We therefore propose, as the rapporteur also said, an asymmetric and gradual approach to market opening in these negotiations. We share with the Tunisian authorities their willingness to move forward in stages. A good negotiation begins in the first place by mutual listening, during which we must integrate the realities, the specificities and expectations of each other. The EU is ready to accompany this negotiation and implementation with a package of different supporting measures. This package will support the reform process and be conducive to the upgrading of certain key sectors such as agriculture and services, and also providing support to the private sector. I am very aware of the importance of Tunisian civil society. They have played, and are playing, a key role in Tunisia’s reform process. They should also play a role, of course, in these negotiations. I was happy to meet many of them when I was in Tunisia, and we had a dialogue on the DCFTA. I have promoted a high level of transparency and dialogue with civil society, both Tunisian and European, all along the process. Civil society should be provided with regular debriefings after each negotiation round. Close and continuous involvement of civil society will play a key role in raising awareness about the negotiations and also the future implementation. As for the draft regulation on olive oil, the purpose of the measure is to send a positive political signal to Tunisia and to bring concrete, tangible short-term benefit to its economy, creating jobs that are so desperately needed in Tunisia. I welcome the way this has been dealt with in the European Parliament under the work of Marielle de Sarnez, the rapporteur, and all the others in the Committee on International Trade (INTA) and joint committees which have worked with this as well. I hope that this House tomorrow will support the proposal by the INTA Committee so that the benefits we offer to Tunisia can enter into force with no further delay. The imports of olive oil from Tunisia will, of course, have to comply with preferential origin and EU sanitary and phytosanitary requirements. The measure is proposed for a limited period of two years, and it will be closely monitored. Let me assure you that the Commission proposal does take into account the general situation of the EU olive oil market. It is expected that this volume of the quota will be absorbed under the current market situation without any significant impact. So thank you very much for the work you have done on this. I hope tomorrow we will send a strong joint signal from the European Union that we are on the side of the Tunisian people. We are ready to help them short term, medium term and also long term, because this is a true partnership.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. – Mr President, Commissioner Malmstrom, I would also like to congratulate Mrs de Sarnez on her report. But I have been rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development and I want to move it here, because I do not think it has been sufficiently recognised. The first thing I want to say in my speech is that the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development supported this political agreement on emergency trade measures to Tunisia. Clearly. There was a vote mostly in favour of rejecting the proposal which absolutely wanted to reject the report proposed by the committee. The committee is therefore in favour of political agreement, but I sincerely believe - and that is why I would like to point it out here - that the interests of the European olive sector, on which many European rural areas, including mine, Andalusia, are not adequately preserved. It is a sector which we cannot therefore forget in the processing of this report. And I ask this House, the people here and you, Commissioner, to be sensitive and to incorporate Amendments Nos 11, 12, 13 and 14. I firmly believe that these amendments do not harm the necessary support for Tunisia at all.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, Tunisia is possibly the only country in the southern Mediterranean basin that is on the road to true democracy. And what we consider to be a good example for the entire Arab world is a bad example for radical Islamists, who are doing everything they can to ensure that Tunisia fails and is destabilised. It is therefore a duty for Europe to help Tunisia in these difficult times, and I fully support the granting of extraordinary import quotas for Tunisian oil. Having said that, it is always our farmers who pay the consequences and in this case I think it is important to strike a balance by taking measures to ensure that European olive oil producers are not harmed by this agreement.  In this regard, we have tabled amendments which clarify this point and which I hope will be voted on in the affirmative tomorrow. As reflected in the text we will vote on tomorrow, this grant of extraordinary measures in no case conditions the motion for a Resolution on the opening of negotiations for a Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and Tunisia, which I fully support, and which I believe is another step in the consolidation of democracy in Tunisia.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Mr President, Commissioner, Madam Rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that, on all the benches of this House, we have the same objective, which is to help Tunisia and the Tunisian people in concrete and lasting form. This has been said, but it must be remembered, because it is important for us Europeans: Tunisia is both the cradle and the symbol of the Arab Spring and it is one of the only countries that is now able to succeed in its democratic transition. But of course - and Mrs de Sarnez was right to point out - Tunisia faces considerable challenges: political challenge with the terrorist threat, economic and social challenge with mass unemployment and collapsing tourism. In short, the question before us is how we can help Tunisians in a concrete and lasting way.  The first thing, and this is recalled in the text, is exceptional financial aid. Many Member States have committed to this. The second thing we can do now, urgently and temporarily, is the extension of zero-right olive oil quotas. On this point, I would like us to have a sincere debate among colleagues. I do not believe, given the small importance of Tunisian olive oil on the European market, that this will have an impact on prices or even on European producers. I think it is a temporary emergency measure, which can give some air to the Tunisian economy. Finally, there is this free trade agreement. I want us to say that this is primarily a partnership that is not only economic, but political. And what does that mean? This implies, of course, that it is symmetrical and progressive, it also implies - and here I am speaking to the Commissioner, because I know she is aware of this - an association of civil society at all times, which sometimes has reason to be concerned, and it must be reassured. In a way, Europe must demonstrate in this agreement that it is not business as usual, but that there is a political imperative that we have taken into account and are trying to implement on this occasion. I think that we must live up to the challenge, but also to live up to the hopes and aspirations of the Tunisian people.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, while the troika is povertying Greek farmers and breaking up the agricultural sector, while lenders impose a harsh tax policy against the rural world and dissolve their insurance system and the OGA, while Greek olive growers have suffered enormous damage from the severe weather events that have affected their production, at the same time comes the decision of the European Union to grant a duty-free import quota of seventy thousand tonnes of Tunisian oil for 2016 and 2017. This action by the Union is a tombstone for poor Greek producers, who are already seeing their oil prices collapse this year.  Why does the legislative proposal apply the duty-free import of Tunisian oil retroactively from 1 January 2006? Who does he want to cover? Who does he want to favor?  Mrs Malmström, the olive growers of Crete, the olive growers of Lesvos, the island that is flooded by thousands of refugees, can't take another blow down the middle.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, as we express our support for closer cooperation between the EU and Tunisia through trade, let me begin by recognising the people in Tunisia. We know these times are very challenging, but we are encouraged and also moved by your ongoing courage and struggle to overcome repression, whether it is authoritarian or Islamist and even the horrors of terrorist attacks. Tunisia is and must be an example of peaceful transition, yet this path of transition to democracy is hard, and the EU must be Tunisia’s first and essential partner. Let us also remember why five years ago Mohamed Bouazizi, in an act of despair, set himself on fire and became a symbol for all those who had a good education but for whom corruption prevented any opportunity, especially for young people. I trust that a good trade agreement along with broader support will contribute to development, stability and the freedom of Tunisians to shape their own future, and in that context I urge colleagues not to prevent a very minimal quota on the import of olive oil without duties. It will have very little impact on the European market but will be a major support for Tunisian development.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, as Mrs De Sarnez said, our responsibility is to stand with the just emancipation of the Tunisian people, which is taking place- many have mentioned - in many torments, including the throes of terrorism that has struck this country three times, with negative consequences on economic activity and employment. Effective cooperation agreements, with preferential exchanges, can be decided taking into account sensitive sectors on both sides of the Mediterranean. This is particularly the case in the fruit and vegetable sector, where production schedules should be put in place to avoid destructive competition. The same is true of the protection of olive oil production.  In contrast to full free trade agreements, which are destructive of activity, or financial aid conditional on the requirements of the International Monetary Fund, we prefer cooperative partnership agreements decided after consultation with Tunisian society and the impact studies necessary to prepare these negotiations.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, we are talking about Tunisia again, and this time with very concrete measures. It seems that this is taking shape that Tunisia is our only possible democratic ally in North Africa and that it has to be a preferred country, which we must help seamlessly. We're talking about two different issues. On the one hand, these emergency trade measures reflected in being able to import more olive oil with zero tariffs. And we are totally in favour, and I say this coming from a country that produces a lot and very good olive oil, because we have to be supportive and we must help Tunisia, which is suffering a lot on its way to democracy: terrorism, the crisis of all the immigrants who have come to it from Libya and all the problems it has. But when it comes to helping you more specifically, this European Union comes up with few things, has little imagination and speaks again of a free trade agreement. A free trade agreement with a very significant imbalance, in the face of the great potential of the European Union and the small economy and the structural deficiencies that Tunisia has. For starters, Tunisian citizens can come to Europe only if they have a visa, while we can move there without a problem. This start of the free trade agreement negotiations has not been supported by Tunisia's civilian organizations. There are many ways to help the Tunisian people different from this one. We want to impose our dogmas of neoliberalism and our ways of creating an economy on a country that is currently not prepared for it. Political support and economic support need not involve such imbalance treaties.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, do not make this great mistake. The Tunisian people are not being helped by the import of olive oil duty-free; This only damages agriculture in southern Europe. Ladies and gentlemen, do not be deaf, moreover, to the appeal of citizens and producers who fear the collapse in the price of oil. Listen to the words and assessments of the European Parliament's Committee on Agriculture. And be ware: there is a risk of counterfeiting of "made in Italy" and fraud to the detriment of consumers. The Italian agricultural sector, for example, would be forced to take yet another decision without taking into account the economic, employment and environmental impact. Do you not have the doubt that, after arriving in Italian ports, some cunning can turn the Tunisian oil passport into "made in Italy"? I ask this because today the imported oil is not easily identifiable and I strongly suspect it after the recent maxi-seizure in Puglia of as many as 7 000 tonnes of North African extra virgin olive oil sold for Italian. The risk is that this oil will not benefit Tunisians, but rather be used by some company that makes money by mixing oils. With this proposal, only agriculture in southern Europe bears the burden of strengthening democracy in the countries of North Africa. Instead, it is the whole of Europe that must help Tunisia. It must help it to combat poverty and Islamic fundamentalism, of course, but we need a Euro-Mediterranean agricultural strategy that values our agriculture and not false forms of one-off support that penalise it. Ladies and gentlemen, I am addressing those of the PD in particular, with your vote in favour of importing Tunisian oil, you are fuelling a war between the poor. (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, you have just mentioned the possible negative effects on the Italian olive oil industry. Do you agree with me that the market for olive oil in Europe currently accounts for around 200 million tonnes a year, that we are talking about 35 tonnes of additional olive oil from Tunisia and that two years ago Italy alone exported more than 500 000 tonnes of olive oil a year from other countries? So if you want to help Italian agriculture – as I can understand – then make sure that your producers import less olive oil than you are now smashing a small straw of hope for the Tunisians.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: answer to a "blue card" question. What I have said is quite different. I have spoken of a Euro-Mediterranean agricultural policy, which means including the countries of North Africa, which means all producers. Let us remember that we do it in Europe, and so we have an equal way of doing agriculture, the products are the same. That is why I was talking about war between peoples. Let us remember that, in addition to these 35 by 2 tonnes, we also have another 56 000 tonnes which have been pardoned, shall we say, by this European policy. What I am saying is that everyone must help Tunisia, and not just Europe. I am not saying that we are not helping you, but rather that it is an outpost of democracy, that of Tunisia, and we must certainly help it, but not in this way.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, I have two points to make on this proposal. First of all, once again, the European Parliament, under the guise of aid to the democratic process, is pursuing a policy of interference that all too often characterizes it. We know the result of the action of some European countries in the process of democratisation of other countries in North Africa or the Near East. What real impact can an increase in olive oil imports have on the Tunisian political crisis? I would like to ask you about the impact of this initiative on European olive oil producers. This sector has experienced serious crises and does not need the European Union to worsen its situation for political reasons. The bacterium Xylella fastidiosa has already put it in great difficulty so I think it is totally useless to add more. As is often the case, the European Parliament organises unfair competition, since there is no import tax. The small producers will again be the turkeys of the farce. The rapporteur believes that the Union must show solidarity at the expense of agriculture in southern Europe. The logical consequence of this common-sense opinion would be to abandon this proposal, because it is impossible that these imports will not harm the European agricultural sector.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to make it clear that I personally am in favour of a cohesion policy that supports the democratisation process from Tunisia and that supports the Tunisian system. On the other hand, I am strongly opposed to the adoption of this type of measure in relation to the destination of oil intake, but I am against it not for oil in specific terms: I am opposed to a policy that once chooses oil, once it chooses tomato, once it chooses wine, once it chooses everything that is produced only in certain territorial areas. Why don't we start choosing milk? Why don't we start choosing meat? Why do we not begin, that is, to realize the condition of diversifying the burden that weighs only on our southern territory (I am talking about Sicily, I am talking about Puglia, I am talking about Sardinia, that is, I am talking about situations that today are dramatically on their knees)? Because it is not a question here of going to consider what we produce, this is about considering what damage small producers suffer through this type of policy. I would add that Europe's credibility is being lost, and it is becoming even more damaged in its ability to transfer a strong and positive message of cohesion and strength precisely because of the existence of this type of measure. I therefore proposed an amendment for the total rejection of this Commission proposal.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Monsieur le Président, Madame la commissaire, Madame la reporture, i vourais tout d'approach remerciver Madame la reporture pour son excellent report, that I share and sutiens entière. The advance of Tunisia towards pluralism and democracy is a source of inspiration, hope and respect for all of us. Tunisia, however, today faces enormous economic, social and security challenges. That is why it is fundamental and urgent to help this country beyond our flamboyant speeches, now, at this moment, as we promised and, unfortunately, we have done so little. The Commission's proposal for the introduction of autonomous emergency trade measures for Tunisia is part of this urgent aid package. I therefore ask all my colleagues to support the text of this report as proposed by the rapporteur and, in particular, to avoid the trialogue, which would be likely to take us out of any relevant timetable for Tunisia. This is a key measure for a Tunisian economy so affected by the crisis, and olive oil remains Tunisia's main export product.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, the terrorist attacks in Tunisia have had a tremendous impact on that country’s already weak economy. Therefore, the Commission’s initiative on additional exports of olive oil is to be welcomed. I hear some honourable Members complaining about the disastrous impact that additional imports will have, but the numbers tell a different story. Europeans are consuming more or less the same amount of oil as every year, but our production has decreased by almost 50% and the amount of oil that will eventually come into the EU from Tunisia is about 1.7%. My question to these Members is: in what way will one additional per cent destroy a European market which is lacking 48%? I can tell you how it will affect Tunisians: olive oil employs more than one million people; it is Tunisia’s main agricultural export, it brings growth, and it prevents despair. For us it is nothing, but for Tunisia it is a big deal. I hope that Parliament will show the promised solidarity in the vote tomorrow.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I personally agree with the objective that the Commission says it wants to pursue: to help Tunisian democracy and its economy, both of which are deeply affected by attacks by terrorist groups, just as I am in favour of any practice of economic and political solidarity between the peoples of the Mediterranean area. At the same time, however, I have a very strong opposition to the proposed instrument, namely a free trade agreement and additional duty-free quotas for olive oil. Liberalisation is not the means of stimulating the developing economy, quite the contrary. It would have been a really useful tool to help the Tunisian people renegotiate and cancel their debt. I think it is rhetorical to help Tunisian producers, when only large European export companies would be interested in benefiting from this measure. I would like to point out here that olive oil producers, especially in southern Europe ( I am thinking of my own Puglia), have already been hard hit by xylella and the eradication plan, which unfortunately also took place with the support of this Parliament. I shall vote against this proposal for a regulation, not only to defend European and Apulian producers, but also tunisian producers.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We want to help Tunisia, but we also expect something back from Tunisia. We want to help Tunisia by giving Tunisians olive oil quotas – in addition, low in European terms – and we want to help Tunisia by improving market access through a solid free trade agreement that offers Tunisia prospects. On the other hand, however, I would like Tunisia to take its commitments seriously. And when I see at the moment that many Tunisians are on their way to Europe, it is precisely a question of combating the causes of flight. On the other hand, however, I see that Tunisia is currently struggling to take back refugees who do not actually have any reason to flee. In my own country, for example, in 2015 there was not a single Tunisian migrant whose reason for fleeing was recognised – recognition rate of 0.0%. And if we now grant these trade facilitations, I would like Tunisia to become more cooperative in this area too and to help us solve our problems.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Madam rapporteur, it is true that this free trade agreement is being negotiated in a rather particular context. Since the revolution of 2011 and even since long before, Tunisia needs help, and I welcome the agreement on olive oil. I can only wonder at the line of defence of some of our colleagues here, who are moved by the impact of these not even 2% of imports of Tunisian olive oil on European production, when they are sometimes the best advocates of free trade agreements that could have much more devastating effects on agriculture in Europe. I therefore invite these colleagues to take a closer look at what agriculture could lose in this agreement with Tunisia. I would like us to pay attention with this ALECA to the fact that there are advances in the creation of quality jobs and sustainable development for Tunisia, that we are careful that this agreement takes into account the differences in competitiveness between economies, and finally, as you said, Commissioner, that we are careful to involve civil society in this agreement. , because it has a lot of information to give us. Thank you for your work.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that there can be no one among us who does not sympathise with the Tunisian people after the cowardly terrorist attacks of last year. But Europe is already playing its part very well through, for example, an appropriation of EUR 500 million established a few days ago, on 12 February, by the European Commission.  I do not therefore believe that this is the right response to support tunisia's young democracy, because with these 70 thousand tonnes of olive oil, which are added, as someone has said, to the 56.7 thousand already provided for in a previous agreement, all that is being done is to massacre agriculture in southern Europe, particularly Italy, in a very special temporal context. , where, as someone said, xylella – the disease that affected plants in Puglia – caused a 47% reduction in total Italian production in 2015. That is why I hope that this proposal for a regulation will not be adopted and that southern European agriculture will not continue to be slaughtered.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mrs de Sarnez for her work. Much has already been said about the situation in Tunisia. I believe that the European Union's task is to make a strong political, economic and financial contribution to ensure that the current transition process is brought to a successful conclusion, and this must be done in good time, we cannot waste time. The negotiations on trade relations must move in this direction and, in order for important and verifiable repercussions to be made on the whole of The Tunisian situation, there is a need for the agreement to be based on maximum transparency and for Tunisian civil society to be fully involved. This is an essential point that the European Parliament must demand with strength and determination. I think that the question of the purchase of Tunisian oil, on which the Council and the Commission have deliberated, must also be put on this road. I just believe that common sense should be used in the evaluation of the amendments that have been tabled. In short, I think I can say that Tunisia also expects the European Parliament to send out an important signal in order to establish a balanced framework for trade relations.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: – Madam President, of course we are in favour of the European Union's solidarity with the countries in difficulty and, in particular, those that are the target of attacks, such as Tunisia. However, we express our reservations about how solidarity, in this particular case, seeks to be exercised, not only because it can once again damage a sector with some weaknesses, but because it is possible to have other instruments existing in the context of external policies, neighbourhood policy and humanitarian policy, among others, or mechanisms for strengthening the economy and stabilising the political sector of the country under this.   At the same time, we all know the importance of the olive oil sector for the economies of the Mediterranean countries, such as Portugal. For that too, the principle of solidarity should not only apply outside the European Union, but also within the European Union, which is tantamount to saying that there must be greater protection of the key sectors for the economy of the Member States and more fair and appropriate alternatives to support the economy of third countries. My vote will therefore reflect my position on this matter.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Madam rapporteur, I agree with you that Tunisia represents the major challenge of the European neighbourhood. Everyone understands that. To help the country, the first step is to increase the country's exports, especially in the key olive oil sector. We must then quickly conclude a fair exchange partnership between the European Union and Tunisia. Our support, however, must go beyond that. Indeed, the issue of security deserves broad regional cooperation between Maghreb countries. Today, that does not exist. This is a field where the European Union must invest its full diplomatic strength. In the end, supporting the Tunisian economy means supporting its democracy. Supporting Tunisian democracy means fighting terrorism in this country. Fighting this terrorism is protecting ourselves. That is the message that everyone must hear this evening in this Chamber.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I shall vote against the proposal, I shall vote against this proposal because the aims of the proposal are right, but the instruments used to achieve the objectives are profoundly wrong. A reduction in European import duties has no advantage and does not bring any benefit to Tunisian producers and Tunisian economic operators. It will only have beneficial effects for a group of European olive oil importers who will be enriched with the taxes paid by European citizens. This is not good policy, this is not the Europe we want. It seems to me that we are heading in the wrong direction: not only are we still penalising one sector, the agricultural sector in southern Europe, in heavy terms, but we are taking action that will have no real effect. The good oil is clear, here instead we are talking about a very, very cloudy oil.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, helping Tunisia at this difficult time is a moral duty and we certainly do not want to back down. However, we believe that there would have been other, more concrete and effective ways of helping tunisia's agricultural economy, for example through programmes to enhance Tunisian oil, an excellent product that is already widely imported into the European Union. And even some Tunisian NGOs have raised doubts about the usefulness of these measures, which will benefit European traders in particular and tunisian producers very little. Our concerns are not the result of a corporatist position: we are in solidarity, but we cannot allow the already fragile European olive sector to be put at risk, without, however, being sure of the real beneficiaries of these measures. We would have preferred a completely different proposal, but at least I would ask all my fellow Members to support the amendments adopted by the Committee on Agriculture which misled the distorting effects of this proposal on the European market.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Dear President, Tunisia is one of the few countries where the removal of power as a result of the Arab Spring protests has not led to chaos and conflict as in other Arab countries, but has achieved democratic change. Tunisia therefore needs to help preserve a still fragile democracy and economically enable goods to be placed on the European market. But this must not be addressed through partial measures that will have a bad impact on European farmers as we have already seen in the example of the Russian embargo.  Olive oil is Tunisia's main agricultural product for export to the European Union, so this European Union assistance is a strong message of support. However, imports of olive oil from Tunisia to the European Union will affect the European Union's efforts to market its olive oil market, as quality degradations have been identified as a result of the entry of such oils into the European Union market. This should be added to the fact that the European Union has enough of its own olive oil. Tunisia certainly needs to be helped, and in the interest of Croatian and European olive growers, I expect this assistance to be proportionate, controlled and limited in time.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, let us start with the most important thing: the European Union already had a political obligation to be faithful to the commitment to strengthen trade relations with Tunisia; it now also has a moral obligation to further support Tunisia after the terrorist attacks that severely hit the Tunisian economy.  It is therefore of the right sense to support the olive oil sector in Tunisia, although we must also take into account that the olive oil sector is an important sector for several countries in southern Europe. Two things must therefore be made clear: first, that these are really exceptional and temporary measures to be in force for no more than two years; secondly, as proposed by our rapporteur, which is subject to an evaluation and safeguard mechanism, which allows them to be suspended in the event of serious disruption to the European olive oil market. In this way, we will be sympathetic to Tunisia, as is our duty, and give the necessary tranquility to the European olive oil sector.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – Madam President, Tunisia is going through a period of severe turmoil and is a country worthy of European solidarity. The additional quota granted for the export of olive oil to the European Union is part of this solidarity approach.  As for Tunisia, the olive oil sector is relevant to the European agricultural economy, and its resilience must be ensured. As with any bilateral trade relationship with the European Union, appropriate precautions should be taken to ensure stability in the internal sector market as well as import quality requirements.  I therefore believe that appropriate bodies should have mechanisms to alert them to potential imbalances in the functioning of the European Union's oil market, which involves regular monitoring of imported quantities. I also believe that this measure should be implemented without wanting to set any precedent in the negotiation process between the European Union and Tunisia on the establishment of a free trade area.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we stand shoulder to shoulder with the Tunisian people and as an Italian, a citizen of a country that has set the highest example of solidarity in the field of immigration, I say – like you, Commissioner – that the whole of the European Union must show solidarity. That is why it was desirable that all twenty-eight Member States should be involved in sharing the Commission's proposal on the method identified and its economic consequences in order to make this principle of solidarity effective. On the other hand, the instrument is highly penalising for one area, and only that, southern Europe, and in particular for Italy, as well as, once again, for a particular and unique sector, that of agriculture. All this without even a preventive impact study and, what is more, while it is precisely the Tunisian NGOs that tell us that they consider this agreement ineffective because, perhaps, they would have expected something else. I would therefore like to say that I shall vote against this agreement, waiting for the Commission to reform its proposal in order to actually help Tunisia.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam Chairman, I want to say right from the beginning that I will vote "yes", although I have many reservations. I will vote "yes" because a proposal has been adopted to monitor year after year what will happen to the olive oil market in the European Union. This is a well-received amendment and I believe that it will be shown that the import of olive oil into the European Union market will primarily be for the benefit of some intermediaries within the European Union, and much less, what is expected, of Tunisian olive oil producers. However, I will also vote "yes" because it is a kind of political message to Tunisia. We need to stand with this people, we need to help and show the decisions of the European Parliament, in this light, that we want to stand with Tunisia. I urge caution because there will be more benefit from this from some traders, a small number of them, who may get rich on it than Tunisian olive oil producers.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union must in every way accompany tunisia's democratisation process. Europe must support the Tunisian economy, but olive oil producers cannot bear the cost. At present, the European Commission's proposal could have a negative impact on the European olive sector, and so I think it is essential that tomorrow this Parliament votes in favour of the corrective amendments to the text that I have tabled together with my colleagues in the AGRI Committee. The first amendment aims to limit the effects of the proposal to a maximum of two years; the second specifies that the oil must be produced entirely in Tunisia, in order to avoid fraud and ensure adequate consumer protection; the most important is the fourth, the one which provides for the monthly management of the additional quantities in order to minimise their impact on the Community olive oil market and to avoid the collapse of European prices at certain months of the year. With these amendments we will be able to mitigate the negative impact of this proposal and it is clear that, if they are not adopted, I will not hesitate to vote against the whole proposal.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, this has been a good debate and shows that we all really want to help Tunisia. It is a fragile democracy, it is really struggling and the people there have chosen a courageous way, as opposed to many of their neighbours. We know the challenges from terrorism and others that have affected them, but still they keep on fighting, and we as their neighbour have a duty to try to support them. Their economy has also suffered immensely, and that is why the DCFTA has the potential not only to support the economy and a longer partnership, of course, but also a democratisation and reform process, which they are already following. We will carefully work with the Tunisian Government in order to identify the priorities to make sure that this is asymmetric and that sensitive sectors are included, excluded or phased-in very slowly and that the priorities are defined jointly but, of course, listening very carefully to our Tunisian friends. We will involve civil society, which is something we are talking to the Tunisian Government about a lot. It needs to be transparent, inclusive and as open as possible and they need to work hand in hand, because Tunisia also has this very strong and dynamic civil society, as opposed to many of their neighbours. So the DCFTA will have important effects for the future, but it will take some time before we can see the results. Bearing in mind the acute situation in Tunisia, we wanted also to support them short-term, and one way of doing so is the olive oil sector, which is so important for their economy. It was not our idea; it came from Tunisia, which wants us to support this. How can we do it? Well, we do it with what is important for Tunisia but for us is a very modest contribution – less than 2% of our total olive oil market will be affected by this. We have, of course, closely monitored the situation, and it will have a very marginal effect on our market. So I think, honourable Members – even if I hear what you are saying – that many of your fears are exaggerated. We will continue to monitor the situation. It is a two—year thing. This is a concrete way to support Tunisia on a short—term basis. It will signal that our solidarity is not only beautiful words but that we are also accompanying these with action. That is why the Commission really hopes that this House will support the rapporteur and the proposal by the Committee on International Trade in the vote tomorrow.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, I thank all the speakers in this debate. I think that we are all pursuing here, despite our different sensibilities, one goal: we want Tunisia to succeed and that this success also benefits all Tunisians. Two words about the partnership agreement. I think the message from our Parliament is clear. We do not just want a free trade agreement or a trade agreement: we want to start a real political partnership with Tunisia. We call on the Commission to be imaginative and to really involve Tunisian civil society in this partnership. I know that the Commissioner hears us and will hear us on this issue. It is very important that Tunisians take ownership of these negotiations, that these negotiations do not fall out of nowhere with, in quotation marks, experts, but that this is really the business of Tunisians and Europeans. As for the second question, it is clear that we need to help Tunisia in the short term. That is why we need these emergency measures, and you have made it clear that it is the Tunisians who are asking for them. It is not the Commission that woke up one day and said, "This is what we are going to do." This is a request from Tunisia. It is very important that all of our colleagues hear from us this evening. Various and varied things, but also inaccurate things, have been said about this. There will be no increase in the overall volume of olive oil imports from Tunisia: the overall volume will remain exactly the same. In addition, we take every precaution. If the amendments we have tabled in committee are adopted tomorrow morning - they were adopted in committee - we will have a precise assessment of the mechanism after one year. And if imbalance problems arise, which I do not believe at all, the Commission will propose measures to remedy them. That is why I really call on all colleagues to be at the level of solidarity where our Parliament must be. Tunisians are waiting for a strong political signal from our Parliament tomorrow, let's be at this meeting!

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 25 February 2016. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I support the EU's autonomous action to provide economic support to Tunisia. It is urgent to continue to provide economic support to the countries of North Africa so that these states can better contribute to easing the burden on the EU on the refugee issue. Nevertheless, I believe that great care must be taken in such measures. When selecting the chosen trade preferences, it should therefore be ensured that there can be no negative impact on our own productions.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – I think it is important to show solidarity with Tunisia and to use our existing instruments to help stabilise the North African country's economy and democratic political system. International terrorism poses a serious threat to the country and deters tourists without whom Tunisia's economy could collapse. Think of the aftermath of last year's horrific attack in Sousse. It is therefore appropriate to some extent to benefit from the trade preference granted to assist Tunisian olive oil producers. However, we must show solidarity with EU producers to at least the same extent. The exemption from customs duties on the additional 35 000 tonnes of olive oil granted by the Commission should not become an exceptional tool into an everyday practice. I therefore call for only monthly import licences to be issued for imports of this additional quantity, as proposed by the Spanish and Italian Ps, and, on the other hand, for the duty-free period not to be extended.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. Tunisia is going through a difficult period; the country has been hit by the attacks and the instability in the region has also affected it. I would like to point out that Tunisia is currently hosting one million eight hundred thousand Libyan refugees, or 16% of the Tunisian population to whom it provides aid and assistance.  In parallel to these difficulties, Tunisia is continuing its democratic transition and I welcome the Tunisian Dialogue's nobel peace prize. The European Union wishes, through the launch of these trade negotiations, to strengthen its support for Tunisia and to do so, the discussions around this trade agreement must allow for a genuine reflection in order to take into account the interests, objectives and concerns of each of the players.  The future agreement will have to take into account the sensitivities of the sectors concerned. It should be progressive and asymmetrical and contribute to Tunisia's stability, the consolidation of its democracy and the recovery of its economy. It is also important to reaffirm the European Union's support for Tunisia through the granting of exceptional and temporary measures aimed at stimulating the Tunisian economy while responding to and taking into account the concerns of European producers.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – There should be consensus that we need – and that Tunisia needs – this agreement. However across the divide of those signing the agreement, institutionally and economically, we are not operating at the same level. In agriculture, what trading concessions we concede to Tunisia, weak though they seem from the south of the Mediterranean, are perceived from the north as undermining the livelihood of farmers. The arrangements by which we try to detail the tax systems that the Tunisian authorities should apply, can serve to undermine Tunisia’s flexibility to enhance its endowments and attract direct investment. The institutions north and south of the Mediterranean still do not converge, are still incompatible. This is not like judging whether the institutions of the north or of the south are ‘better’. This is a question of saying things as they are. Convergence of institutions is an interactive process which cannot be finalised overnight. Believing that convergence will happen just as a result of rapprochement with Europe is an illusion. Agreement with Tunisia is imperative. Not because sensational events of the recent past must be repeated, but because in the creation of convergent institutions north and south of the Mediterranean, Tunisia occupies a principal role.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - The report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the imposition of urgent autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia proposes measures to improve the difficult economic situation Tunisia has found itself in following the recent terrorist attacks. The resolution passed a non-taxable annual quota for the export of 35 000 tonnes of virgin olive oil fully produced in Tunisia to the European Union. Given that olive oil is Tunisia's main export agricultural product for the EU, this sends a strong political message of support. It is in the interest of Croatian olive growers that this support be proportionate and limited in time to a maximum of two years. Amendments to the adopted resolutions will provide protection to Member States engaged in the industry and export of olive products. In my view, the amount of imported oil envisaged will not harm EU citizens engaged in the olive industry. Furthermore, if the Commission finds evidence that Tunisia does not comply with the conditions or finds that there is an imbalance of the European market, it may adopt an act partially or completely suspending preferential agreements with Tunisia.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
