text: Writing. - Free trade promotes freedom. And it prevents war. The great Frenchman Bastiat once said that where goods must not cross borders, armies will do so. In this sense, free trade is peace-building. And it also benefits the people – those in Tunisia and those in the EU. If Tunisians are allowed to sell their products to EU citizens and businesses, then everyone is better off: producers and buyers alike. We also benefit in other ways: an economically successful Tunisian will not soon find his only salvation in emigration. We are helping to reduce the benefits of economic migration if we allow free trade. And we should do that immediately.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on preparation for the UN General Assembly special session on drugs (2016/2561(RSP)).

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, UNGASS 2016 is a key opportunity for the international community to take stock of the achievements of the international drug control system today. It also provides an opportunity to elaborate a response to the world drug problem and to find long-term solutions in the framework of the international treaties. As an outcome, UNGASS should adopt a short and action-oriented document comprising a set of operational recommendations, and the EU supports such an approach. To be more precise, the EU advocates the following priorities. First, we emphasise that the three UN drug conventions which provide the international legal framework, and the Universal Declaration on Human Rights, should remain the cornerstone of the global response to the world drug problem. Indeed, there is sufficient scope and flexibility within the provisions of the UN drug conventions to accommodate a wide range of approaches to drug policy in accordance with national and regional specificities. Second, we highlight the importance of human rights. We call for the abolition of the death penalty for drug-related offences as well as the abolition of other practices which are not in line with the principles of human dignity, liberty, democracy, equality, solidarity, the rule of law and human rights, and the EU continues to stress that the death penalty undermines human dignity while failing to act as a deterrent to criminal behaviour. Also, the EU recalls that the application of the death penalty for drug-related crimes does not meet the threshold of the most serious crimes as set out by the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Third, we advocate drug policies based on an integrated, balanced and evidence-based approach. Clearly, a balance between drug supply and drug demand reduction measures is needed, and we also call for drug policies to be underpinned by a sound public-health approach based on scientific evidence and supported by objective monitoring systems and evaluation. While the international drug conventions call for a balanced approach, we feel that in a number of states, measures to address drug production and trafficking take priority over drug use, prevention, risk and harm reduction, treatment, rehabilitation and recovery. Therefore a stronger health approach is needed to redress this balance, and UNGASS is a unique opportunity to achieve that. The Union also calls on state parties to guarantee access to risk- and harm-reduction measures, which are not only related to HIV/AIDS prevention but also cover a whole spectrum of measures to protect public health and society. The EU consistently stresses that these measures have proved their effectiveness in improving public health. We also advocate the promotion of alternative development as a long-term and holistic approach to tackle the root causes and framework conditions of the illicit cultivation of drug crops. Finally, we attach great importance to the role of civil society and science, especially in the field of drug demand reduction. Therefore the EU is also calling for the recognition of a role for civil society in drugs policies. These priorities will reflect that, in the common EU position on UNGASS set out in November last year and in the EU contribution to the UNGASS outcome document. Currently the EU is closely involved in defending these priorities in the negotiations on the UNGASS outcome document, and we are glad to see that the UNGASS outcome document already includes many elements that are important to the EU. However, two important issues are still missing: first, a reference to the abolition of the death penalty for drug-related crimes, and second, strong language on risk- and harm-reduction measures. Clearly the EU will have to keep on advocating the inclusion of these very important elements.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission believes that the EU has a very important role to play in promoting a robust outcome at the United Nations General Assembly special session on drugs and is fully engaged in its preparation. The European Union adopted last November a common position for the UNGASS. We are determined to speak with one strong voice, and you will hear that the Commission is very much in agreement with the Council at this session. We will ensure that critical issues for the EU’s Common Position are taken on board in negotiations on the outcome document. Commissioner Avramopoulos will represent the Commission at the special session and seize the opportunity to present and promote the EU’s world—recognised model of drugs policy, and this policy is based on evidence. It drives a balanced approach between drug demand reduction and drug supply reduction and gives attention to the challenges, such as the online trade in drugs and new psychoactive substances. Some of the key issues we will focus on have already been mentioned by the Minister, but let me emphasise them again. Our priorities include respect for human rights and the call for abolition of the death penalty for drug-related crimes, because they do not meet the threshold for the most serious crimes under international law. So, we have proposed from the EU side to organise a side event, during the special session, on the death penalty to explain our views on why capital punishment for drugs-related offences is not a good policy solution – and, by the way, it is never a good solution. We will also plead for proportional criminal justice when dealing with people who use drugs, and we will advocate rebalancing our drug policy towards public health approaches. This is the primary objective of an international drugs control system. We need to do more when it comes to demand reduction, encompassing prevention, early detection and intervention treatment, risk reduction, care, recovery, rehabilitation and social integration, and we are comparatively very well placed to share our experiences and best practices in this area. We will support the draft recommendations on drug supply reduction currently on the table. We want to see greater international cooperation and coordination to prevent and respond to drug-related crimes. Primarily, the focus should be on those having a leading role in the trafficking chain. It is equally important to address the links between drug trafficking and other forms of organised crime, money laundering and corruption. The EU will remain active in regional and international networks addressing these issues. Europol is contributing decisively to this end, offering experts and facilitating information exchange and best practices. We will also call for effective international cooperation on challenges such as drug trafficking on the internet and on new psychoactive substances – threats that concern all the regions of the world. We will stress the importance of building drug policies on evidence, reliable objective monitoring and evaluation systems. We have our own agency, the European Monitoring Centre of Drugs and Drug Addiction (EMCDDA) in Lisbon, which is pursuing these goals steadily. Last but not least, we wish to see tailored measures for children, women and young people. Therefore the EU will be at the forefront of those calling for greater involvement of civil society in the definition and implementation of our drugs policy. We have an expert group of 45 NGOs in the form of the EU Civil Society Forum on Drugs, and they are a constant adviser to us. So, dear Members of Parliament, I am looking forward to hearing your interventions, which we will carefully take into account in our preparations and participation in UNGASS.

name: Michał BONI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. –  Madam President, Madam Commissioner, the UNGASS Conference will be an opportunity to promote the European approach related to drug issues in order to tackle the demand and supply, also to fight drug-related problems. The European approach is unique, as we have managed to create coordination with 28 drug policies joined together and reinforced by action taken at EU level. This is a model with a special role for EMCDDA, our agency, to do risk assessments, and we should share this experience with the regional organisations. As Europe, we should promote the abolition of the death penalty and the right to healthcare services for people affected by drugs. It is important to change the attitude, not to stigmatise or criminalise people dependent on drugs but promote a preventive approach and build an awareness of how dangerous all kinds of drugs are. Three points: firstly, the integrated approach should be further developed, with cooperation between health, justice and law enforcement, civil society focused on assistance, treatment, education and awareness-raising. On the other hand, a more coordinated fight against organised crime should be a priority as well. Secondly, we need to adjust to the new ways of drug distribution, taking into account the role of the internet. This is not only for law enforcement but also for parents and prevention organisations. And thirdly, we should understand the phenomenon of new psychoactive substances, which pose more and more of a threat. We need a proper early-warning system and the possibility to react much faster. This is why all available resources, especially related to the EMCDDA in Europe, need to be strengthened. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – I agree with the aspects you have listed, but at some point I would like to ask you a question. How much do you think coordinated policies can really be represented when, for example, in my country, Hungary, the number of people with hepatitis C has increased by 50% because the government has abolished the free needle exchange programme. That's a pretty scattered policy.

name: Michał BONI
text: blue-card answer. – I think that it is important to understand that competences relating to health are in the Member States’ hands, but that there are many efforts being made at the European level to coordinate and harmonise some activities. I think that we need to have a balance. Promotion and cooperation is one of the most important things but, on the other hand, we need to remember that many Member States will tackle their own policies in this area.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in its 2014 annual report, the Italian National Anti-Mafia Directorate felt obliged to highlight the total failure of repressive action to combat the spread of soft drugs, in particular cannabis, and called on the Italian Parliament to consider, in a European context, whether it would be appropriate to decriminalise the subject. , taking into account the potential positive repercussions in terms of deflation of the judicial burden, the release of resources to combat other criminal phenomena and, above all, the fight against mafias. Very heavy words that come from those who are at the forefront of the battle to enforce the current regulations and which are part of a debate brought to life by positive experiences in countries such as Uruguay and in several States of the United States of America, also in terms of reducing criminal phenomena. This should make us reflect precisely in view of the special session of the United Nations General Assembly on drugs, a unique opportunity to review drugs policies at global level, putting people, their health and human rights at the centre, having the courage to change course. Repressive policies have failed to reduce the illegal market, overcrowded prisons, caused the stigmatisation of drug users and encouraged the billionaire trafficking of organised crime. I therefore hope that we will use this important opportunity to reflect on a change of course that is now necessary.

name: Marek JUREK
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Public health is one of the fundamental rights that make up the common good of every nation, and no government has the right to evade responsibility for combating scourges, especially scourges spread in an organised way, that affect human health. People addicted to drugs should be helped in treatment; wholesalers, distributors, all those who spread this scourge must be combated, they must be waged in regular war.  I hear that at the moment our main message to the rest of the world is to ban the death penalty for drug offences, or maybe we will still ban the use of the military in the fight against drug mafias? Maybe we will turn to the United States, to the countries of East Asia, so that the military does not fight the drug mafia, because by chance a wholesaler will die? We have to defend people, not encourage others not to fight this evil that strikes our nations.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – I currently consider the topic of drugs to be as topical as, for example, the topic of migration. Unfortunately, it seems to me that drugs still remain behind all discussions. In recent years, there have been new trends that the international community must respond to if it wants to prevent the drug boom. When I look at the statistics, it is quite clear that the list of emerging narcotics is constantly increasing, e.g. 101 new narcotics were reported in 2014. At the same time as this phenomenon, the number of drug-related offences has been increasing for some time. Perhaps the most dangerous is the trafficking of illegal drugs on the Internet. There are already several thousand online shops in Europe where even teenagers and children can buy drugs and other intoxnate substances.  We must therefore seek solutions not only at European level, but also at world level, and work to effectively prevent this negative phenomenon.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: S&D). Madam President, in 1998 it was decided for the first time to support both police and prevention and treatment measures. But unfortunately that did not happen. We have stayed in the proclamations and so we have now reached eighty per cent of the resources available to be channelled into the police campaign, which have proved to be universally unsuccessful. Unfortunately, all they offer is the illusion that there is a powerful stalker. But the king is naked.  In order to return to the European level, it is necessary to offer treatments aimed at small-time users, alternatives to incarceration, as well as the offer of such treatment programmes for prisons. Finally, it is very important that supervised centres of use operate, which not only save users' lives, but also prevent the transmission of infectious diseases to the general population.  Think of every single life that is saved in a supervised use centre, and a free bed in an intensive care unit. What kind of relative of a man in need wouldn't beg for it.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – I agree with my pre-speechers on the role of prevention, undoubtedly the importance of not excreting people who are drug users and have thus failed in their lives. It also encourages organisations that engage these people in their lives. At the same time, I would like to draw attention, both with regard to the substance of criminal law and to the issue of genuinely new psychoactive substances, which my pre-speaking father, Mr Zdechovský, also spoke about. It is not only about how many new ones have been discovered, but also about the total volume of these substances that have been captured, for example, in the European area. In 2013, it was 2.3 tonnes. This is a huge number, and given that these new psychoactive substances must also be adequately described from the out of the respect of criminal law, the question arises as to how to combat it other than on the international stage. That is why today's debate is really about what the EU's mandate for representation at the UN General Assembly is and what specific points will be included in the common position. I hope it's the new pschoactive substances.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there is one aspect that is often not taken into account by drug strategies. It is not a question of repressive techniques, but of assessing the environmental impact of the fight against drugs. Between 2001 and 2013, more than 700,000 acres of forests in Latin America were destroyed to make way for cocaine plantations. According to a study published by Open Society Foundations, an NGO under George Soros, in the most critical areas of the world the environmental consequences of the war on international drugs would be even more devastating than the economic and social ones. It is just the umpteenth demonstration of how repressive policies alone have been an uneconomic choice, guaranteeing large profits to producers, brokers and traffickers. For these reasons, I believe that the next UN special session must also take account of this new issue, which has been raised by the independent reports of various organisations. Only in this way will it be possible to deal with the harmful effects of the war on drugs, taking into account all aspects and not just the repressive ones.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, at a time of enormous global economic crisis, poverty and unemployment, at a time of increasing global refugee and migration flows, at a time of worsening social cohesion in the major cities of Europe, the United States, Asia and Latin America, in a phase of strengthening the smuggling of crime and drug trafficking, the UN Conference on Drugs could , under conditions and conditions, to be a promising ray of light. An opportunity for global cooperation in the following areas: 1) Hitting trade and drug cultivation; 2) Imposing harsh sentences and zero tolerance on drug traffickers 3) Hitting drug trafficking networks on the spot and on the Internet; 4) Developing a policy that will help prevent and inform young people about the scourge of drugs and 5) Strengthening drug rehabilitation and social inclusion processes. So we're going to have to do it.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam Chairman, it is good that the European Union, with 28 clear votes, is coming to this special session of the United Nations General Assembly on Drugs. Our European concept, our European experience when we talk about prevention, about the role of civil society, about the reintegration of those who have tasted drugs, about the role of public health, education and campaigns that have been conducted against drugs in many countries, regions and cities, I believe that this European experience can be extremely important for the whole world. Of course, and the experience europol has. But I am nevertheless when it comes to choosing between prevention or repression always for what civil society means, prevention, public health, and less repression.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, there is indeed a very wide agenda to discuss under this headline in New York later this spring. Most of the issues you refer to are actually on the agenda, and the EU will be pursuing it: everything – smuggling, online, new substances – I think the EMCDDA is identifying at least one new substance a week, so this is really an acute problem – but also, of course, the issues of treatment, prevention, rehabilitation and so on. To the honourable lady from Italy on decriminalisation: different countries have chosen different paths, so this issue in itself is not on the agenda. But we will, of course, listen to the different experiences from those countries and take heed of the results and the possible impact, even if it is quite early to evaluate results – for instance, the countries you mentioned. So there is a lot to discuss, and I will make sure that the European Parliament is involved in the further preparation but also on the follow-up of this, and we will convey your message to Commissioner Avramopoulos, who will be representing the EU there. So we are sparing no efforts to make sure that the EU is constructively and actively contributing to the UNGASS meeting and that we can help to contribute to bring solutions to this gigantic global problem, also paving the way for the review of the United Nation political declaration and plan of action on drugs, which is foreseen in 2019.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, as was just stated by the Commissioner, most of the issues referred to are on the agenda. So yes, we will do our utmost to ensure that UNGASS follows the direction that the EU has been following already for a number of years and that this leads to a strong health and human rights-based approach in drug policies. We will also keep on voicing our opposition to the death penalty for drug—related crimes. Applying that penalty for these crimes is neither proportionate nor effective. Finally, we will also do our best to bring strong risk- and harm-reduction language into the UNGASS outcome documents, because we have proved that these measures work. Therefore we have no excuse not to use them to protect the health of our citizens.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – The European Union plays a key role in the fight against drug trafficking through its examples of good practice and must be one of the key pawns of the extraordinary session of the UN General Assembly. Beyond the criminal aspect of drug trafficking and use, we must also be aware of the problems involved in public health, with the EU repeatedly committed to ensuring the protection of citizens' health and combating drug addiction. However, the high level of deaths and the financial burden on the public health system prove to us the need for a deeper approach to reducing the supply and demand for narcotics. Our efforts need to be matched by the awareness of the danger caused by the trafficking and consumption of narcotics by citizens, both on them but, above all, on children. With basic medical training, I emphasise the danger to citizens' health, so I consider it necessary to deepen the development of policies to educate citizens, especially young people, in order to reduce the harmful impact of drugs on society.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – Unfortunately, five years after the Global Commission on Drug Policy declared that the war on drugs had failed, we are still debating whether to update a three-decade-old global drugs policy. I believe that the failure in this field comes from a lack of understanding. We require a policy that addresses today’s realities, and this is what I urge the Commission and the UN to do. We require a policy that acknowledges the increased prevalence of synthetic psychoactive substances, which are very extremely life-threatening, the new dimensions of trafficking including Silkroad and the Darknet. These are realities that can be addressed only through a shift in policy. We must safeguard the best interests of our citizens and their families and only by addressing the now can we focus on the future.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. – The world of drugs is a rapidly changing world, so it is important that international regulation keeps pace with the regrettable 'development' of the area and that it is essential to provide information for preventive purposes on new chemicals needed to produce drugs. An important milestone in this fight will be the extraordinary meeting of the United Nations General Assembly on drugs. I welcome the fact that this specific round table will address the topics of drugs and human rights, youth, women, children and communities. It is of the utmost importance that we keep up to date with new drugs that are being marketed by drug dealers and criminal networks. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly changing, exploiting legal loopholes. Every day we are confronted with new drugs that are toxic, in many cases cause death, but are often not yet considered illegal. There is only an integrated way to combat drugs: prevention, rehabilitation and law enforcement are also essential. Everything must be done to ensure that young people, teachers and parents are properly informed. Drug users should be helped to overcome addiction, thus reducing the negative social, economic and public health effects of drugs. Furthermore, appropriate means should be provided for the authorities to act effectively in the fight against drugs at international level.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing – an extraordinary meeting of the UN General Assembly on Drugs (UNGASS) will be held in Vienna on 19-21 April 2016. The objectives of the fight against narcotics have already been set in the framework of the adoption of the Political Declaration and Action Plan in 2009. This action plan aims to significantly reduce or eliminate drug demand and supply. Children and young people in general, but also women, pregnant women, ethnic minorities and those suffering from a combination of mental and physical disorders, are a particularly sensitive and susceptible group in drug use and use in drug trafficking. Problems related to drug use and drug trafficking are often defined in troubled urban areas. It is therefore necessary to adopt the right reintegration measures that offer a viable alternative to young people who have already fallen into drug addiction or have become so-called 'child soldiers' in the service of criminal organisations. However, we must be aware that, if the fight against narcotics is to be successful, we must start from prevention in families. These are one of the few effective tools in the fight against not only drugs, but also youth delinqués and other social ills that are plaguing our society. The family, which is often underestimated, is fighting a successful battle where the state and its means are failing.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the one-minute speeches on matters of political importance (Rule 163).

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam Vice-President, colleagues, the solution to the migration crisis is a fundamental issue for the European Union. However, I still do not see a significant change in the protection of the external borders and in the establishment of peace in the Middle East. It is incomprehensible to me that a decision on the establishment of a border and coast guard has still not been taken, whereas a system of mandatory quotas, which I did not agree with, would be approved relatively quickly, but it still does not work. In the meantime, we accept refugees in the Czech Republic ourselves and voluntarily, albeit to a much smaller extent than in Germany and other countries. I support the initiative of the Foundation, which has secured asylum in the Czech Republic for 153 Iraqi Christians fleeing Islamist terror. It's a small number, but they're specific people, specific families, children I know personally, and I'm glad we could help save them. There is also, of course, dissent in our country, but there are also numerous gestures of solidarity and assistance. People are willing to help, but they must not feel threatened. There is a simple equation. The more consistent and effective the european institutions will be in dealing with this crisis, the greater the willingness to accept refugees at the level of state authorities, self-government and individuals.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Italian bathing system has its roots in the tradition of businesses, almost always family-run, which have invested their heritage and their future also in areas where protecting a swimmable sea is a conquest of civilisation for entire regions. The Italian bathing economy has 87 thousand companies, 418 thousand employees and consumption for 24 billion euros. After a long life, these families are now called upon to face the effects of the definitive cessation of their right of insistence, strenuously defended in every court, now also before the Court of Justice, where they have been forcibly pushed, in an attempt to cope with the tide of the Bolkestein Directive and against which they are advancing with trepidation. I would like to support them along this path, aware that finding a balance between their family future and respect for the Community principles of the freedom to provide services is so painful that it cannot be entrusted only to them. Possible remedies, such as the dedemanialisation of areas and the recognition of surface option rights, therefore appear to be proposals compatible with a Community balance that preserves their rights in any case.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, colleagues, I am outraged by the situation that has been going on for months on the border between Greece and Bulgaria. For several years – 2009, 2010, this border was blocked by farmers and caused huge damage to Bulgarian carriers, Bulgarian producers, Bulgarian entrepreneurs and European ones. Many truck owners from Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Austria are also in this blockade and are also suffering severe financial losses.  What I would like to state and demand from the European Commission is a quick attitude and a quick decision on this blockade and that european treaties be respected, as the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union is currently being violated. This cannot continue – either there will be a European Union and there will be freedom of movement, or there will be none. And that is my requirement to the European Commission. Otherwise, there's no need for it.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: – Madam President, transport connecting the Countries of the Western Balkans with the European Union and mutually with each other will enable faster communication, faster accession of these countries to Europe, better understanding and better relations with each other. This is why, a few months ago, I proposed a declaration with my fellow MEPs to extend Europe's large TEN-T network to the Western Balkan countries. At the beginning of this month, the European Commission adopted such a decision that will achieve all these goals that I was talking about. I therefore welcome this Decision of the Commission and the declaration I mentioned can still be signed.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, these days we are witnessing the violation of all notions of European solidarity. The Austrian government has convened an extra-institutional synagogue with the participation of the countries of the western Balkans, most of which are not even members of the European Union, with the declared aim of putting pressure on Greece to supposedly ensure the protection of the Union's external borders in the refugee crisis. No one tells us, however, how this can be done in the few miles of sea between the Greek Aegean islands and the Turkish coast, without having mass drownings of people, who are not criminals, but are simply looking for a better fate.  Pressure must not be exerted on Greece, but on the regime of Turkey, which tolerates illegal traffickers in violation of its agreements with the European Union. Greek hysteria must stop and a European solution to this European problem must be found.

name: Karima DELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in recent months a small object of women's daily life has been in the spotlight, ladies and gentlemen, this is a buffer. This sanitary protection has allowed women to be freer during their period of menstruation, but in recent years, scientific studies have alerted us to the presence of toxic and dangerous substances in sanitary products, such as tampons. Despite the mobilization of thousands of Europeans who have spoken out in favour of the transparency of the industry, with a complete labelling of chemical components, the industry does not react and hides behind the fact that no European or national legislation has forced it. When questioned last December, the European Commission said it was not considering new rules. On the eve of 8 March, Women's Rights Day, we must defend the rights of consumers, which do not seem to be a priority for the Commission. I therefore call on the Commission not only to protect women, but above all to establish real rules in this area.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Madam President, in the debate earlier today we heard Mr Tusk and Mr Juncker both say that if the British people vote to remain in the European Union, then the measures in Mr Cameron’s deal will require legislation. But Mr Tusk gave the game away when he said that he ‘hoped’ they would pass into legislation. In particular, they will require amendments to the Directive on free movement, which is a fundamental principle of the European Union. Parliament may actually vote to reject or change the substance of the deal, but we will not know that until after the referendum, if indeed the British people vote to remain. Mr Cameron is trying to sell a pig in a poke. The real issue in the referendum is whether the British people want their country to be a mere region of a United States of Europe, or whether they wish to restore our former status as an independent, self-governing nation. I urge them to vote to leave.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: "Marriage and the ancient communities of the family, which fit into the divine order of creation, are in a lasting crisis. This recognition prompted the Romanian NGO Coalition for a Family to initiate a constitutional amendment stating that the family is based on a marriage created by the voluntary determination of a man and a woman. We must not allow the natural order of marriage and family on which social and human existence is based to be undermined by the demagogy of false references to human rights to gender equality or human dignity. Together with the tens of thousands of protesters at Rome's Family Day in January, let us stand up to protect our colleagues, our families, our children and our healthy European society.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: Madam President, I wanted to share with you the fact that, for almost six months, this Parliament, by a very large majority, has adopted a report which called on the European Commission to take a legislative initiative for the recognition of non-food geographical indications. This subject concerns most of our territories, since it concerns both the location of employment and the recognition of our know-how as well as our traditional products in a context where, in international competition, we are faced with territories that have their own production. While we want to support SMEs and promote employment in the European Union, the recognition of these geographical indications would be beneficial not only for our SMEs, but also for consumers, who would have a guarantee on the authenticity of the products they buy. For several years now, we have had a study that confirms the benefits of legislation in this area. I ask the Commission to take responsibility and propose legislation in the coming year, as indicated in the internal market strategy.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: – Those who remain silent agree. Anyone who is silent about injustice is partly to blame. And the EU is silent. She is silent in all languages about Turkish violence against the Kurds. I must say that I was disappointed yesterday with the answers of the High Representative and the NATO boss to my questions on this in the Committee on Foreign Affairs. In Syria, Erdoğan is attacking the Kurdish fighters fighting for us against IS. Just yesterday, the Kurds rescued a 16-year-old girl from the clutches of IS. Turkey chooses the wrong enemy. In his own country, Erdoğan is tearing down Kurdish towns and villages. Cizre is a devastated city. The violence does not distinguish between men and women, between children or the elderly. People die, burned alive, in their basements. The Turkish state's war against its own people is so immoral, so reprehensible, but neither Mogherini nor NATO boss Stoltenberg dares to name evil and bring Erdoğan to order. If no one else dares stand up for these people, we must do so.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, the importance of the EU Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Kosovo is tremendous. The agreement sends a clear signal to the citizens of Kosovo that we stand behind their European aspirations and paves the way for a more democratic and prosperous Kosovo. However, as we stand here, the agreement and the European path of Kosovo is being jeopardised. The opposition has been throwing tear gas grenades in the parliament, and they are staging day and night protests against the actions of the legitimately—elected government to implement the requirements under the agreement. The European Parliament and the European Commission have to send a clear signal that normalisation of Kosovo’s relations with Serbia, and respect for minorities, is a precondition for Kosovo’s European integration. The agreement has to be respected, whoever is ruling Kosovo. By sending that signal we will, hopefully, make it clear that the European integration of Kosovo is more important than the internal political fight for power and that the integration process should not be misused for the wrong purposes.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: – Madam President, the crisis in the Basque steel sector, the greatest example of which is the temporary closure of ACB Sestao, which jeopardizes a thousand jobs, is added to the employment regulation files of the companies Tubular Products and TRV.  Fundamental rights of thousands of citizens are violated because multinationals show little affection for the territory and people, but also, especially in the case of the Sestao plant, by the inaction or erroneous decisions of Brussels, Madrid or Gasteiz. By dumping in the first case, because the energy policy of the second premium to large companies and because the third evaded responsibility after selling its 10% in ACB.  Workers are not a commodity or a mere cog of the production system, but its axis, the key to driving and developing another fairer economic model: an economy at the service of people and not the elite of 1%.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. We celebrated the International Day of the Mother Tongue on 21 February. The celebration of Hungarians in Romania was overshadowed by the tacit adoption in the House of Representatives of an extremely nationalist, anti-Hungarian and anti-minority bill. This law would prohibit minorities from using their mother tongue in public administration. The draft is anti-Hungarian, unconstitutional and has provoked outrage from the entire Hungarian community, as its terms are contrary to Romania's constitution and contrary to the fundamental values of the European Union. In the plenum of the European Parliament, I express my conviction that the RMDSZ will make the draft rejected by the Bucharest Senate. It is against the interests of a democratic rule of law to adopt an unconstitutional, exclusionary, extreme nationalist law. This draft is incompatible with our country's membership of the European Union, which has its place in the bin.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: – Madam President, last week, the Romanian IRS requested five television stations belonging to the Intact Trust to evacuate within five days the premises in which they operate, as part of the State's action to recover damage. I consider the State's desire to recover the damage from the files to be correct. In the face of justice, we are all equal.  The court decision was implemented by the state takeover of the press trust building and does not provide for the evacuation of Antena 3, which is not part of any process and has no debt to the state. The correct solution, according to the law, is the right of pre-emption of the press trust, as a tenant.  The request by five broadcasters to evacuate the premises in such a short time means the end of the broadcast and can be interpreted as an approach designed to intimidate those media institutions and even jeopardise their activity. We can talk about the suppression of freedom of expression by administrative means. Nowhere in Europe can a television, let alone five, change its headquarters in five days.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Madam Chairman, the migrant crisis is a principle of European unity and European communion. Dublin has fallen, Schengen is in jeopardy. The crisis was so great right at the beginning that we didn't know how to react well. Unfortunately, I must note that even today we still do not have a clear solution because there is no European solidarity, because there is no European communion. It is unacceptable that non-EU countries, which are on the so-called The Balkan route and which are part of Europe, but also countries that are not in Europe have done much more for the migrant crisis and for tackling the migrant crisis than 28 countries in the rich European Union do. We need more solidarity, more unity because the whole European project will come into question if there is no such thing.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, this week I will submit an opinion to the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs aimed at protecting and enhancing the rights of persons with disabilities. The opinion will focus on the promotion of several rights, including the full implementation of the UN recommendations on the rights of persons with disabilities, full implementation of a European accessibility act, the removal of all barriers for people with disabilities and, crucially, the protection of the rights of our most vulnerable disabled people, including stateless people, homeless people, refugees and asylum seekers. The 1916 Irish Proclamation calls on us to cherish all children equally. This is at the heart of what Sinn Féin do, and I hope the Committee will take on board my proposal, as people with disabilities need our dedication, application and commitment. I can tell the House that the Sinn Féin delegation and the other delegations in the GUE/NGL Group have all of these in abundance.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – One of the most serious problems facing Europe today, which it is currently confronted with, is undoubtedly terrorism. It is not only in the context of this phenomenon that we rightly hear that we should address the causes of terrorism, not just the consequences. It is undoubtedly a very correct objection. As far as the causes are concerned, I personally believe that the policy of Saudi Arabia is an important factor behind the boom in terrorism. I have previously considered very much the role and operation of this state, but I do not think that it is appropriate to be restrained at this time. I think there is also no dispute that this state provides intellectual and material support to terrorist organisations. Although Saudi Arabia has recently been in the shadow of the Islamic State in this regard, the European Union cannot continue to pretend that everything is in order. It is time to act and apply a consistent policy with respect to Saudi Arabia that will ultimately lead to the complete elimination of support for terrorist groups. Today's Saudi Arabia poses a threat, which is why the European Union must approach it.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: – Madam President, the opportunity to request information, to express yourself and to defend your views is directly proportional to the measure of independence that we manage to provide to the press and journalists. It is the Union's common responsibility to ensure a free and independent environment in which media institutions operate.  My call to the Commission, but also to you, ladies and gentlemen, is to be vigilant and to react firmly and swiftly against any attempts to limit freedom of expression. The constant search for the truth and the correct information of the public remain the most important tasks of the journalist, who must be protected in his work. However, these days, in Romania, a CNN-affiliated media trust is ordered to evacuate its headquarters and is forced, by this action, to discontinue its broadcast.  I propose that we stop any attempts to intimidate press people and any practices of pressuring those who have a duty to present the truth. We must protect the fundamental right to free speech, as is also apparent from Article 2 of the European Treaty. It is obvious that a free press is indispensable for the success of the European project.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the leaders of the European Union and those responsible for the 28 Member States were concerned about finding a compromise to prevent Brexit. I do not dispute policies in the fight against social tourism but, in the area of child allowances, I cannot agree that they should be paid at the level of the parents' country of origin if they do not live in the Kingdom.  Children are already suffering because they are away from their parents, either emotionally or in the process of growing and educating. Allowances are also a form of compensation for these things. Parents, who pay taxes, in the UK, have left their children in their countries of origin precisely to give as much value as possible through their work.  British society also benefits from the expertise of people – whether doctors, teachers or engineers – professionally trained in other countries, without having spent a pound in this educational process. Thus, if the reduction in payments for the allowances of children left at home is called into question, the United Kingdom must be obliged to pay the Member States the professional training of all foreign nationals who, through their efforts, contribute to the economic well-being of the Kingdom.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: – The steel industry in Europe gives work to more than 350,000 people. Also in Slovakia, steel production has a long tradition and accounts for up to 6 percent of domestic product, which is the most in the whole Union. However, as long as our companies have to comply with high safety and environmental standards, China is tackling its economic problems by massively subsidising its steel exports. I am pleased that, just today, our European People's Party has taken concrete action on this matter and has approached the Commission to take really effective action. Two months ago last December, I approached the Commission to act, because the situation in the steel sector is really critical and other sectors, such as aluminium production, are finding it increasingly difficult in the Union. It is important that governments, together with the Commission at the World Trade Organisation, prepare the necessary steps to save steel production in Europe. It is important that we preserve jobs, and it is crucial that we act as soon as possible.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: Madam President, in June it will be up to British citizens to decide whether or not they want to remain in the European Union. They have their place but not at any price. I am concerned when I see that the agreement undermines the principle of freedom of movement and will create inequalities and discrimination between European workers. I am also concerned when a government that refuses to adopt the euro intends to influence the management of this area. It is essential that those who want to pursue the project of greater integration can continue to move forward. We must be careful not to open the door to a spiral that would lead other States to call for further derogations and thus weaken European cohesion. The European Union cannot be reduced to a market, to an addition of national selfishness. The European project is above all shared values, a vision of solidarity, a human dimension. It's essential.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, tugann Seachtain na Gaeilge deis dúinn ceiliúradh a dhéanamh ar ár dteanga, agus ar an tionchar dearfach atá ag an nGaolainn ar ár gcultúr agus ar ár bhféiniúlacht. Is ceart agus is cóir go mbeadh na Gaeil ar comhchéim le tíortha eile i dtaobh ár dteanga. Mar sin tá an-áthas orm fáilte a chuir roimh dhaltaí ó shé Ghaelscoil éagsúla chun cuairt a thabhairt ar Pharlaimint na hEorpa, agus úsáid a bhaint as a dteanga dhúchasach. Beidh deis ag na daltaí scoile a bheith mar Fheisirí Eorpacha ar feadh an lae, agus díospóireacht, idirbheartaíocht agus vótáil a dhéanamh le linn cluichí ról-imeartha trí mheán na Gaeilge.  Is é seo an chéad uair sa Pharlaimint go mbeidh na daltaí ag glacadh páirt sna cluichí seo trí Ghaolainn, agus is mór an onóir domsa an chuairt seo a eagrú. Sa bhliain 2016, tá dualgas ar Ghaeilgeoirí agus ar phobal na Gaeilge an ghlúin nua a spreagadh agus a mhealladh i dtreo a dteanga agus a n-oidhreachta. Is maith an rud é an t-aos óg a chumhachtú le deiseanna a dteanga agus a n-oideachas a úsáid le féinmhuinín agus bród. Táimse, mar aon le foireann Shinn Féin ar fad, go hiomlán tiomanta do chur chun cinn na Gaolainne in Éirinn, agus cothrom na Féinne a bhaint amach di san Eoraip. Faoi láthair, níl riachtanais phobal na Gaeilge á sásamh sa bhaile nó san Eoraip. Níor cheart go mbeadh stádas den dara grád ag an nGaolainn, agus leanfadsa ag troid i gcoinne na hiarrachta í a choimeád ar ísealchéim.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: That concludes the item.
